Catalogue number: N/A
Object name: HUGHES MICROPHONIC DETECTOR.
Maker/Donor: Made by Professor D. E. Hughes, F.R.S. Presented by the Executors of the late Mrs. Anna C. Hughes.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In the course of some experiments with his Induction Balance, Prof. Hughes found that if a circuit was formed by joining up in series a battery, a microphone, and one of the coils of his balance, any interruption of the circuit was accompanied by a disturbance which became audible in a telephone receiver connected to another microphone, even when the two circuits were widely separated and there was no direct connection between them. Prof. Hughes carried out a great many experiments, many of which were witnessed by eminent men of science, but whereas Prof. Hughes was convinced that they were due to some form of conduction between the two circuits, his friends eventually came to the conclusion that they could all be accounted for by the known laws of electro-magnetic induction. It is now certain that in these experiments, Hughes, like Edison in 1875, was dealing with true Hertzian waves such as now used in wireless telegraphy, and that he was unwittingly employing for their detection the coherer method of reception which was first deliberately used for this purpose by Lodge in 1889. The microphone detector exhibited consists of a steel needle hanging in light contact with a small circular hole in a block of carbon, and is one of many forms of microphone which were tried by Prof. Hughes. Others will be found in the telephony section.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922–222, S.M. 2156.

Maker/Donor: Made by Mr. E. E. Robinson. Lent by Sir Oliver Lodge, F.R.S.
Object entry information:
Throughout the experimental researches of Prof. Hertz, to which is due the rise of modern wireless telegraphy, the only means of detection was that afforded by the occurrence of a minute visible spark in a closed circuit tuned to resonance with the transmitter.
In repeating the experiments of Hertz, Sir Oliver Lodge also employed a “resonator” which, however, was made to resemble the oscillator in shape and consisted of a straight rod interrupted at the centre by an adjustable spark gap. One of these resonators is here shown, and it will be seen that the wood base on which it is mounted is blackened behind the gap in order to render the spark more easily visible.
Although thousands of times less sensitive than the coherer, which Sir Oliver Lodge and others subsequently employed, it was by means of resonators such as these that Prof. Hertz laid the foundations of modern wireless telegraphy, performing experiments involving reflection, refraction, and polarization of electro-magnetic waves.
Sir Oliver Lodge also employed resonators in conjunction with coherer detection, which he placed in the position of the spark gap. With such apparatus he transmitted signals a distance of some 60 yards in 1894, using as one of his accessory pieces of apparatus a coherer and tapper. (See No. 23.)

Catalogue number: 3.
Object name: HERTZ OSCILLATOR.
Maker/Donor: Made by Mr. E. E. Robinson. Presented by Sir Oliver Lodge, F.R.S.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This Hertzian oscillator was used by Sir Oliver Lodge in 1894, when in the course of experiments based on the work of Hertz he transmitted signals over a short distance by means of electric waves.
The oscillator is similar in every way to the type used by Prof. H. Hertz at Karlsruhe in 1886, and is known as a “dumb-bell” oscillator or “dipole.”
The only fundamental change which has taken place in the growth of such oscillators from the small experimental model (used purely for physical research) to the large modern antennæ measuring up to 800 ft. in height, is that it has become customary to replace the lower half of the dipole by an earth connection.
This important modification was made by G. Marconi in 1895.
Sir Oliver Lodge himself came very near to the experimental demonstration of electro-magnetic waves, and was the first to show the fundamental importance of tuning in wireless.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-32, S.M. 2173.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 4.
Object name: LODGE SPHERICAL OSCILLATOR.
Maker/Donor: Made by Mr. E. E. Robinson. Presented by Sir Oliver Lodge, F.R.S.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is one of the oscillators used by Sir Oliver Lodge in his lecture at the Royal Institution in 1894, when wireless signals were sent and detected by his spring coherer at a distance of some 20 yards through walls.
The sphere when excited gave sparks at the ends of a diameter to two small knobs and emitted waves 7 in. in length. The radiation was very powerful, but owing to the high rate of damping the oscillator was enclosed in a copper screening device with a variable aperture, in order to prolong the duration of the waves and project them in any desired direction.
At his Lecture in 1894, “On the work of Hertz and some of his successors,” Sir Oliver Lodge used this oscillator to transmit signals from the library of the Royal Institution to the lecture table, where they were detected by his spring coherer. He also demonstrated the quasi-optical effects of the waves by refracting and polarizing them, as Hertz had done.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-34, S.M. 2173.

Maker/Donor: Made by Mr. E. E. Robinson. Presented by Sir Oliver Lodge, F.R.S.
Object entry information:
This spark-gap, originally used for experiments on lightning guards, was employed by Sir Oliver Lodge in 1889 as a detector of electro-magnetic waves. It represents the first deliberate application of the coherer principle to wireless reception.
In that year Sir Oliver Lodge accidentally observed that when lightning struck the guard, the opposite sides of the protective air-gap became fused together. This he considered partly due to a cohesive action, resulting in adhesion and amalgamation when a spark occurred between the knobs. An extremely feeble spark was found sufficient to produce the effect provided that the surfaces were only separated by an almost imperceptible film, probably of oxide. The adhesion of the two surfaces was demonstrated by an electric bell and battery in circuit; every time a spark occurred the bell rang, and if it was placed so that its vibrations could reach the cohered surfaces a few strokes sufficed to break the contact and restore the gap to its original condition. Sir Oliver Lodge called this arrangement a "coherer," a name that has since been applied to all modes of detection using either a single specially arranged contact-gap or a multiplicity of loose contacts.

Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Object entry information: This large induction coil was used by Senatore Marconi at the Needles station in 1898. At this date the transmitter was untuned, the secondary terminals of the induction coil being connected across a multiple spark gap. (See next exhibit.) One of the outer balls of this gap was connected to earth, and the other by a wire to an insulated strip of wire netting supported by an insulator at the top of a 120 ft. mast. A large Morse key was inserted in the primary circuit of the coil and signalling thereby effected.

One of the outer balls of this gap was connected to earth, and the other by a wire to an insulated strip of wire netting supported by an insulator at the top of a 120 ft. mast. A large Morse key was inserted in the primary circuit of the coil and signalling thereby effected.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-504, S.M. 2181.

Catalogue number: 7.
Object name: MULTIPLE SPARK GAP.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Date of creation: 1898
Object entry information: In his earliest experiments (1895) Senatore Marconi made use of a spark gap of the type evolved by Prof. Righi (see No. 55), in which the two central spheres were immersed in vaseline oil. Later he adopted the type here shown. This actual example was used with the adjacent induction coil (No. 6) at the first radio telegraphic station at the Needles, Isle of Wight, in 1898. It consists of four brass balls, each about 2 in. diam., spaced about 1/4 in. apart in an ebonite frame.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-511.

Catalogue number: 8.
Object name: MARCONI WIRELESS TELEGRAPH APPARATUS. Plate 3.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers.
Date of creation: 1898-1902
Object entry information: A number of objects are shown which illustrate the work of the Marconi Company between the years 1898 and 1902. They include oscillation transformers or "jiggers" (A–G), condensers and inductance coils (H–K), and types of detectors used by Senatore Marconi (L–N). The mercury-iron anti-coherer is one of several which were used in Newfoundland when the first transatlantic wireless signals were received there in 1901. (See also No. 17.) In the mercury-iron coherer the original form of which was devised by P. Castelli, a signalman in the Italian Navy, two electrodes, either both of iron or one of iron and one of carbon, are placed in a glass tube, and between the electrodes is a drop of mercury. The Marconi magnetic detector is described at No. 33.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-434, S.M. 2159.

Object entry information: spark was found sufficient to produce the effect provided that the surfaces were only separated by an almost imperceptible film, probably of oxide. The adhesion of the two surfaces was demonstrated by an electric bell and battery in circuit; every time a spark occurred the bell rang, and if it was placed so that its vibrations could reach the cohered surfaces a few strokes sufficed to break the contact and restore the gap to its original condition. Sir Oliver Lodge called this arrangement a "coherer," a name that has since been applied to all modes of detection using either a single specially arranged contact-gap or a multiplicity of loose contacts.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-36, S.M. 2174.

Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Object entry information: This is part of the first piece of rough experimental tuned coupled-circuit transmitting apparatus employed by Senatore Marconi at his station at "The Haven," Poole Harbour, in 1899. It is the foundation of the famous "7777" patent of 1900. The improvements embodied in this patent were as follows:—At the transmitting end the original arrangement, called since then a "plain aerial," was exchanged for one consisting of two coupled circuits. The secondary of the oscillation transformer was connected in series with an adjustable inductance in the aerial circuit, while the primary circuit included a spark gap and condenser. It is this latter portion of the original experimental apparatus which is here shown. It consists of a square wooden frame over which are wound several lengths of thickly insulated copper cable joined in parallel to form a single turn of very low resistance. The condenser and the terminals of the spark gap were connected to the secondary terminals of a 10-in. induction coil (shown at No. 10). The whole oscillation transformer when in use was generally immersed in insulating oil.

Catalogue number: 10.
Object name: NEWTON 10-IN. INDUCTION COIL.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Date of creation: 1899
Object entry information: This is the induction coil used in 1899 by Senatore Marconi in conjunction with the last exhibit in the experiments which led up to the improvements contained in his Patent No. 7777 of 1900. It is interesting to record that the same coil has since been employed by him in 1921 in the later development of the directive "beam" system, the earliest experiments on a practical scale in this research being made by him in 1895.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-495.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 11.
Object name: EARLY WIRELESS TRANSMITTING KEY.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This key was the first to be specially designed for wireless work, and superseded the naval type of "Masthead" key previously used. Senatore Marconi used this key in all his experiments at the "Haven" station, Poole, leading up to his "7777" patent for tuned apparatus.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-507.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 12.
Object name: "GRASSHOPPER" SEND-RECEIVE KEY.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Date of creation: 1899
Object entry information: The "Grasshopper" key, used in 1899, had a screened terminal with a lead-covered wire aerial lead to the receiver. The terminal at the end of the ebonite rod was connected with the aerial by means of a flexible lead. While transmitting with this key, the aerial was disconnected from the receiver, but when transmission was finished the key arm fell back and connected the aerial with the receiver.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-505.

Object entry information: These Leyden jars were used in the earlier experiments with tuned transmitters. The outsides of the jars were all connected together, and the three insides on either side were in parallel, the resultant capacity being that of 1 1/2 jars.

Object name: TRAY WITH SIX LEYDEN JARS FOR TUNE "A."
Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Object entry information: These Leyden jars were used in the earlier experiments with tuned transmitters. The outsides of the jars were all connected together, and the three insides on either side were in parallel, the resultant capacity being that of 1 1/2 jars. The actual tray here shown was used in the first Tune "A" design of 60 metres wave-length. When this wave-length was standardized by the Company in 1901 the tray was lined with zinc, thus automatically connecting all the outside coatings of the jars together.

Object entry information: This is part of the first piece of rough experimental tuned coupled-circuit transmitting apparatus employed by Senatore Marconi at his station at "The Haven," Poole Harbour, in 1899. It is the foundation of the famous "7777" patent of 1900. The improvements embodied in this patent were as follows:—At the transmitting end the original arrangement, called since then a "plain aerial," was exchanged for one consisting of two coupled circuits. The secondary of the oscillation transformer was connected in series with an adjustable inductance in the aerial circuit, while the primary circuit included a spark gap and condenser. It is this latter portion of the original experimental apparatus which is here shown. It consists of a square wooden frame over which are wound several lengths of thickly insulated copper cable joined in parallel to form a single turn of very low resistance. The condenser and the terminals of the spark gap were connected to the secondary terminals of a 10-in. induction coil (shown at No. 10). The whole oscillation transformer when in use was generally immersed in insulating oil.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-494, S.M. 2183.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 10.
Object name: NEWTON 10-IN. INDUCTION COIL.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Date of creation: 1899
Object entry information: This is the induction coil used in 1899 by Senatore Marconi in conjunction with the last exhibit in the experiments which led up to the improvements contained in his Patent No. 7777 of 1900. It is interesting to record that the same coil has since been employed by him in 1921 in the later development of the directive "beam" system, the earliest experiments on a practical scale in this research being made by him in 1895.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-495.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 11.
Object name: EARLY WIRELESS TRANSMITTING KEY.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This key was the first to be specially designed for wireless work, and superseded the naval type of "Masthead" key previously used. Senatore Marconi used this key in all his experiments at the "Haven" station, Poole, leading up to his "7777" patent for tuned apparatus.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-507.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 12.
Object name: "GRASSHOPPER" SEND-RECEIVE KEY.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Date of creation: 1899
Object entry information: The "Grasshopper" key, used in 1899, had a screened terminal with a lead-covered wire aerial lead to the receiver. The terminal at the end of the ebonite rod was connected with the aerial by means of a flexible lead. While transmitting with this key, the aerial was disconnected from the receiver, but when transmission was finished the key arm fell back and connected the aerial with the receiver.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-505.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 13.
Object name: TRAY WITH SIX LEYDEN JARS FOR TUNE "A."
Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These Leyden jars were used in the earlier experiments with tuned transmitters. The outsides of the jars were all connected together, and the three insides on either side were in parallel, the resultant capacity being that of 1 1/2 jars.
Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: LLM-LINKED
description: As part of the experimental tuned transmitter apparatus lent by the Marconi Company, this tray belongs to the collection recorded under co35265. Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Object entry information: It was in 1898 that Senatore Marconi first introduced into his receiving arrangements a "jigger," or oscillation transformer. In his previous work he had placed the receiving coherer directly in the aerial circuit, but since the coherer, like most forms of detector, is a potential-operated device, and since there is always an antinode of potential at the earthed end of an aerial system, the arrangement was not an efficient one. Marconi therefore adopted the plan of inserting in the aerial circuit the primary coil of a small air-core transformer, to the secondary terminals of which the coherer was connected, and thus produced the coupled-circuit receiver which is now so familiar. Several of the earliest types of "jigger" are shown under No. 8. The example here shown was standardized in 1900 for use with the first commercial tuned apparatus working on a wave-length of 60 metres (Tune "A"). The instrument was known as Type No. 306, signifying that in the experimental investigations carried out to determine the best types of receiving transformer, the one finally adopted for Tune "A" stood 306th on the experimental list. No. 343 was standardized for Tune "B" (about 300 metres), and No. 268 for "plain aerial" working.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 16.
Object name: COHERER RECEIVER FOR WIRELESS TELEGRAPHY.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This early form of coherer-receiver was made and used by the Marconi Company. It consists of a sensitive metal filings coherer with an electro-magnetic tapper, and forms part of a circuit containing a local battery and a sensitive telegraphic relay. When electro-magnetic waves energise the transformer, or "jigger," contained in the apparatus, the metal particles cohere, causing the resistance of the tube to fall from a high value to a lower one, depending upon the strength of the received signals. A current of the order of one milliampere flows from a single cell, operating the relay, causing current from several other dry cells to operate the tapper and morse inker. The signal is thus recorded, and the tapper decoheres the tube, restoring it to a condition of high resistance.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–209.

Object entry information: Owing to the constant variations in the capacity of the aerial wire used in the first transatlantic tests, Senatore Marconi soon found that it was impossible to make use of his standard coherer receiver (see No. 16). He accordingly tried varous types of self-restoring coherers, and obtained signals with several, one of which is here shown. The instrument is known as the "Italian Navy" coherer, and is described under No. 8.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 20.
Object name: COLLECTION OF THERMIONIC VALVES (DIODES).
Maker/Donor: Made and presented by Professor J. A. Fleming, F.R.S.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These are the original thermionic tubes which were made and used by Prof. Fleming in the experiments which led him from an investigation of the so-called Edison effect in 1883 to the invention in 1904 of the two-electrode thermionic valve. These valves were the precursors of other types, and with them have given rise to highly important developments in wireless telegraphy and telephony. In 1883 Mr. T. A. Edison experimented with a glow lamp having a metal plate sealed into the exhausted bulb and a carbon filament rendered incandescent by a direct electric current. He discovered that if the metal plate was connected to the positive terminal of the filament by an external wire, a feeble electric current flowed through it, whereas hardly any current flowed when the plate was connected to the negative terminal. Mr. Edison himself gave no explanation of this effect. It was assumed in 1889 that there was an emission of negatively electrified carbon atoms from the filament, but in 1899 Sir J. J. Thomson showed that they were particles of negative electricity, now called electrons. These are projected at a high speed from the incandescent filament and attracted to a positively electrified metal plate sealed into the bulb. The effect is now known as Thermionic Emission. In 1889 Prof. Fleming commenced a systematic investigation of the Edison effect, and constructed for this purpose the series of vacuous bulbs lettered A to I. Bulb C was constructed in order to prove that thermionic emission takes place in the case of an incandescent platinum wire as well as in that of an incandescent carbon filament. Bulbs D, E and F were used to test how far from the filament the emitted particles could travel to a positively electrified metal plate, and whether they could travel round an elbow-tube or only in straight lines. It was found that the thermionic current became weaker as the distance between the filament and plate (or "anode") was increased. Bulbs G and H were used to investigate the emission from various parts of the filament, and it was shown to be prevented by enclosing the carbon filament in a glass tube. In bulb I provision was made for the interposition of a mica plate between the anode and filament in order to find out if the transfer of negative electricity was thereby stopped. It was found that this was so. Bulbs J, K, L and M are samples of the two electrode thermionic valves which were the outcome of the foregoing experiments. Electrons are evaporated from an incandescent carbon or tungsten filament and attracted to the anode which is positively charged by means of a battery. The space between the filament and anode thus allows negative electricity to pass in one direction, but not in the opposite, and it can therefore convert the high-frequency alternating current set up in a wireless receiver into a direct current (i.e., rectify it). The sensitivity of the device is about the same as that of a crystal detector but it is completely stable in its action.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922-707, S.M. 2189.

These are projected at a high speed from the incandescent filament and attracted to a positively electrified metal plate sealed into the bulb. The effect is now known as Thermionic Emission. In 1889 Prof. Fleming commenced a systematic investigation of the Edison effect, and constructed for this purpose the series of vacuous bulbs lettered A to I. Bulb C was constructed in order to prove that thermionic emission takes place in the case of an incandescent platinum wire as well as in that of an incandescent carbon filament. Bulbs D, E and F were used to test how far from the filament the emitted particles could travel to a positively electrified metal plate, and whether they could travel round an elbow-tube or only in straight lines. It was found that the thermionic current became weaker as the distance between the filament and plate (or "anode") was increased. Bulbs G and H were used to investigate the emission from various parts of the filament, and it was shown to be prevented by enclosing the carbon filament in a glass tube. In bulb I provision was made for the interposition of a mica plate between the anode and filament in order to find out if the transfer of negative electricity was thereby stopped. It was found that this was so. Bulbs J, K, L and M are samples of the two electrode thermionic valves which were the outcome of the foregoing experiments. Electrons are evaporated from an incandescent carbon or tungsten filament and attracted to the anode which is positively charged by means of a battery. The space between the filament and anode thus allows negative electricity to pass in one direction, but not in the opposite, and it can therefore convert the high-frequency alternating current set up in a wireless receiver into a direct current (i.e., rectify it). The sensitivity of the device is about the same as that of a crystal detector but it is completely stable in its action.

title: Thermionic valves

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers.
Object entry information: This lightning protector, which was patented in 1866 by C. and S. A. Varley, is a duplicate of one shown in the telegraphy section. It is repeated here because its action depends upon that coherence of semi-conducting powders which was afterwards utilised in the reception of Hertzian waves. As early as 1838, Munck, of Rosenschild, noticed a diminution of resistance in tubes containing metallic filings or semi-conducting bodies, when traversed by electric currents. He also ascertained that these powders regained their original resistance after having been subjected to some mechanical disturbance. In 1852, the high resistance of uncohered metallic powder was again noticed by S. A. Varley, and four years later he detected a sudden fall in its resistance during a thunderstorm. In 1866, Messrs. C. and S. A. Varley took out a patent for the present lightning arrestor. In the patent specification they observed that powdered conducting matter constitutes a poor conductor under low electro-motive forces, but that its conductivity is remarkably increased when it is subjected to high potentials. The connection between these discoveries, together with those of Prof. Hughes in 1879, and Prof. Calzecchi-Onesti, of Fermo, in 1884, and the later history of the coherer is one of considerable interest.

Catalogue number: 22.
Object name: LODGE SPRING COHERER. Plate 2.
Maker/Donor: Made by Mr. E. E. Robinson. Presented by Sir Oliver Lodge, F.R.S.
Date of creation: 1894
Object entry information: This very early form of coherer was used by Sir Oliver Lodge in a number of his experiments with Hertzian waves. In one such experiment exhibited before the Royal Institution in 1894, he sent and received signals over a distance of some twenty yards using the spherical oscillator shown at No. 4. The coherer consists of a spiral of thin iron wire, mounted on an adjustable spindle, and an aluminium plate. When the lever is moved clockwise the tip of the iron wire presses gently against the aluminium plate, whose end is bent at right angles and passed through into the hollow circular wooden box. The device is similar in principle to Sir Oliver Lodge's spark-gap coherer of 1889. (See No. 5.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-33, S.M. 2174.

title: Spiral spring coherer, 1890-1894
description: Spiral spring coherer, probably made by E E Robinson, England, 1890-1894.  Used by Oliver Lodge in his lecture before the Royal Institution on 1 June 1894 on ‘The work of Hertz and his successors’
maker: Lodge, Sir Oliver Joseph; Robinson, E.E.

Maker/Donor: Made by Mr. E. E. Robinson. Presented by Sir Oliver Lodge, F.R.S.
Object entry information: In 1890, Prof. E. Branly, of Paris, made the extremely important observation that an electric spark at a distance had the power of suddenly changing the electric conductivity of loose masses of powdered conductors. He showed that a tube of metallic filings loosely packed between metal plugs might be a conductor of very high resistance when the metallic filings were loosely arranged, but that if a discharge from a Leyden jar was made in the vicinity, the conductivity of the metallic powder was suddenly increased. Similar observations had been made previously by other experimenters (see No. 21), but this was the first time that a careful study was made of the phenomenon. In 1894, Sir Oliver Lodge conducted some experiments using the actual tubes shown, which were similar to those of Branly. Each consists of a glass tube filled loosely with coarse filings or borings of iron contained between two metal plugs. Sir Oliver Lodge noticed that the change of resistance of the tube was proportional to the energy of electric radiation from a source of given frequency. He arranged an electro-magnetic vibrating arrangement (shown in one specimen) to produce mechanical agitation, and so destroy the incipient cohesion caused by the electric radiation. A similar arrangement was adopted by Popoff in Russia and Marconi in Italy. One of these tubes, found to have a resistance of 2,500 ohms in the sensitive state. A feeble stimulus reduced it by 400 ohms, while a rather stronger spark reduced it by 500 and 600 ohms.

title: Two iron boring coherers (Branly type), 1894

Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Object entry information: In 1896, Signor Marconi turned his attention to the improvement of Branly’s coherer, and subsequently brought out the form of coherer shown in this exhibit. It consists of a glass tube from which the air has been exhausted by means of the side tube. Placed in this tube are two tightly fitting silver plugs to the ends of which are attached two platinum wires sealed through the glass. The ends of these plugs are polished and slightly amalgamated with mercury, and are brought within about 2 mm. of each other. The interspace is about half filled with a small quantity of nickel and 5 per cent. silver filings, 95 per cent. nickel and 5 per cent. silver, carefully sifted so as to be of a certain degree of fineness. The ends of the plugs are wedge-shaped in order to make the sensitivity of the instrument variable after the manner of the Slaby coherer. This coherer proved to be more sensitive and reliable than previous forms.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 25.
Object name: COHERER AND TAPPER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by M. Child, Esq.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is an early Marconi coherer and Admiralty pattern tapper arranged to tap the glass coherer tube on the cessation of a signal. The decoherer consists of a relay wound to a resistance of about 1,000 ohms. The relay is made to operate a small electro-magnet having a vibrating armature like an electric bell, this armature carrying a hammer. The electro-magnet is so fixed on an inclined plane that the blow is administered to the sensitive tube upwards from below. Delicate screw adjustments are also provided by means of which the exact strength of the blows, and the rate at which they are given, can be precisely controlled. In the circuit of the sensitive tube are two choking coils, the effect of which is to prevent the oscillations started by the minute sparks at the relay or vibrating hammer contacts, travelling back along the wires and causing coherence in the filings.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-396.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 26.
Object name: WIRELESS COHERER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Admiral of the Fleet, Sir Henry B. Jackson, G.C.B., K.C.V.O., F.R.S.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is the coherer used by Captain Jackson when in August, 1896, he obtained intelligible Morse signals for the first time between two ships by means of wireless telegraphy; the system was evolved by Admiral Jackson independently of other workers. The coherer, which is of conventional design, consists of an ebonite sleeve into which fit two brass plugs attached to spirals of copper wire. In the space between the two brass plugs are contained some metallic filings (these were taken from the inventor’s bicycle-bars). The pressure on these filings could be adjusted by means of a screw fitting into one end of the ebonite sleeve. These early experiments on behalf of the Navy were not made public.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-281.

Catalogue number: 29
Object name: SLABY COHERERS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: Used later in 1901
Object entry information: This is the form of coherer used in 1897 by the Allgemeine Elektricitats-Gesellschaft in the Slaby-Arco system of radio-telegraphy. It was used later by the British post office in experiments between Baldoyle and Howth in 1901. The coherer consists of an exhausted glass tube, narrower at its central portion, into which enter two tightly fitting silver plugs. The plugs serve as conductors, to which are soldered two little capsules cemented to the ends of the tube. A fine powder is enclosed between the faces of which are not parallel, one of them being cut on the skew so that the gap left for the powder is V-shaped. The powder only fills about half of this space, and if the coherer is placed in such a manner that the narrower portion of V space is downwards, the powder occupies the greater height in the gap, its pressure is greater, and the sensitiveness of the apparatus is at its maximum. If, on the contrary, the larger portion of the V is turned downwards, the powder takes a lower level, and exercises less pressure, so that the sensitiveness of the coherer is at a minimum. The tube is rested on supports that permit it to rotate; this gives a means of controlling the degree of sensitiveness.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-688.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 30
Object name: LODGE-MUIRHEAD STEEL DISC COHERER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by R. P. Howgrave-Graham, Esq.
Date of creation: Patented in 1902
Object entry information: This coherer was patented in 1902, and perfected by Sir Oliver Lodge and Dr. Alexander Muirhead, who had always advocated continuous decoherence by means of magnetic tappers then in use, wherein electro-magnetic tappers were brought into operation only on the receipt of signals. A small and perfectly true steel wheel is specially ground to a smooth knife edge and is kept in rotation by the clockwork which drives the siphon recorder used to record the messages received. The edge of the wheel grazes the convex surface of a small column of mercury contained in an ebonite cup, the height of which can be adjusted so that the wheel dips more or less below the surface. A drop of oil is placed on the top of the cup, and a small pad of wash-leather bears upon the edge of the wheel to keep it clean. An adjustable potential divider, supplied by a battery, maintains a potential difference just insufficient to break down the film of oil which the rotation of the wheel draws in between its edge and the mercury. The oscillating potential difference set up by an incoming wave-train breaks down this film, allowing a current to pass at the place of contact and operating the siphon recorder. On the cessation of each wave-train, the oil is drawn in again, decohering the instrument, i.e., restoring it to its normal resistance, which is almost infinite. In reliability and sensitiveness this appliance was superior to any detector known at the time, and signals were received with great reliability and precision in express trains at 60 m.p.h.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-441.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 31
Object name: LODGE-MUIRHEAD FILINGS COHERER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by R. P. Howgrave-Graham, Esq.
Date of creation: Introduced about 1904
Object entry information: This ingenious and very sensitive coherer was introduced about 1904 by Sir Oliver Lodge and Dr. Alexander Muirhead. The particular specimen here shown is still extremely sensitive. It is differentiated from the types common at the time in having steel electrodes of small diameter, one being threaded and arranged to turn in a metal collar. This moveable electrode carried a cross bar of iron in a glass annex so that, although the whole coherer was exhausted to prevent oxidation, the distance between the electrode tips could be varied by rotating the moveable electrode by means of a horseshoe magnet disposed outside the appliance. Decoherence was effected by continuous vibration maintained by clockwork.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-442.

Maker/Donor: Presented by R. P. Howgrave-Graham, Esq.
Date of creation: Patented in 1902
Object entry information: This coherer was patented in 1902, and perfected by Sir Oliver Lodge and Dr. Alexander Muirhead, who had always advocated continuous decoherence by means of magnetic tappers then in use, wherein electro-magnetic tappers were brought into operation only on the receipt of signals. A small and perfectly true steel wheel is specially ground to a smooth knife edge and is kept in rotation by the clockwork which drives the siphon recorder used to record the messages received. The edge of the wheel grazes the convex surface of a small column of mercury contained in an ebonite cup, the height of which can be adjusted so that the wheel dips more or less below the surface. A drop of oil is placed on the top of the cup, and a small pad of wash-leather bears upon the edge of the wheel to keep it clean. An adjustable potential divider, supplied by a battery, maintains a potential difference just insufficient to break down the film of oil which the rotation of the wheel draws in between its edge and the mercury. The oscillating potential difference set up by an incoming wave-train breaks down this film, allowing a current to pass at the place of contact and operating the siphon recorder. On the cessation of each wave-train, the oil is drawn in again, decohering the instrument, i.e., restoring it to its normal resistance, which is almost infinite. In reliability and sensitiveness this appliance was superior to any detector known at the time, and signals were received with great reliability and precision in express trains at 60 m.p.h.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-441.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 31
Object name: LODGE-MUIRHEAD FILINGS COHERER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by R. P. Howgrave-Graham, Esq.
Date of creation: Introduced about 1904
Object entry information: This ingenious and very sensitive coherer was introduced about 1904 by Sir Oliver Lodge and Dr. Alexander Muirhead. The particular specimen here shown is still extremely sensitive. It is differentiated from the types common at the time in having steel electrodes of small diameter, one being threaded and arranged to turn in a metal collar. This moveable electrode carried a cross bar of iron in a glass annex so that, although the whole coherer was exhausted to prevent oxidation, the distance between the electrode tips could be varied by rotating the moveable electrode by means of a horseshoe magnet disposed outside the appliance. Decoherence was effected by continuous vibration maintained by clockwork.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-442.

Date of creation: N/A

Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-283.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 29
Object name: SLABY COHERERS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: Used later in 1901
Object entry information: This is the form of coherer used in 1897 by the Allgemeine Elektricitats-Gesellschaft in the Slaby-Arco system of radio-telegraphy. It was used later by the British post office in experiments between Baldoyle and Howth in 1901. The coherer consists of an exhausted glass tube, narrower at its central portion, into which enter two tightly fitting silver plugs. The plugs serve as conductors, to which are soldered two little capsules cemented to the ends of the tube. A fine powder is enclosed between the faces of which are not parallel, one of them being cut on the skew so that the gap left for the powder is V-shaped. The powder only fills about half of this space, and if the coherer is placed in such a manner that the narrower portion of V space is downwards, the powder occupies the greater height in the gap, its pressure is greater, and the sensitiveness of the apparatus is at its maximum. If, on the contrary, the larger portion of the V is turned downwards, the powder takes a lower level, and exercises less pressure, so that the sensitiveness of the coherer is at a minimum. The tube is rested on supports that permit it to rotate; this gives a means of controlling the degree of sensitiveness.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-688.

description: Filings coherer, Lodge-Muirhead system, patented 1901, with arrangement for adjusting the compression of filings by using an external magnet to turn the head of a screw inside the tube. Adjustment washer inside the tube marked in handwriting ‘Dec 31 1902’.

Maker/Donor: Made and presented by Mr. S. G. Brown, Esq., F.R.S.
Object entry information: This is a detector of the self-restoring type, invented by Mr. S. G. Brown, Esq., F.R.S. It is sometimes classed as a coherer and at others as an electrolytic detector. It consists essentially of a pellet of peroxide of lead held between a plate of lead and one of platinum. If an external electromotive force from a single secondary cell is impressed upon it so that the current flows through the peroxide from platinum to lead, a counter electromotive force will be experienced by this current due to the electro-chemical action of the lead-peroxide of lead-platinum couple. Mr. Brown found that the passage of oscillations through this couple increased its counter electro-motive force by stimulating chemical action, and so reducing the current sent through it by the external cell. The couple acts, therefore, as a conductor of which the resistance is increased by electric oscillations. The pellet of peroxide is mounted in a holder in which an adjustable pressure can be applied, and placed in series with a galvanometer and single cell. When oscillations occur the deflection of the galvanometer decreases, but increases again when they cease.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 33.
Object name: MAGNETIC DETECTOR. General.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1902
Object entry information: The action of this detector is to some extent based on the results of experiments by Prof. Sir E. Rutherford and others. It was patented by Senatore Marconi in 1902, and was largely used in ship receiving sets on account of its reliability. An endless band, consisting of a number of strands of insulated iron wire, passes over two pulleys which are made to rotate slowly by clockwork. Near to a part of the band two horseshoe magnets are fixed with similar poles adjacent, and at this point, where a large number of lines of force pass into the band, the latter passes through a tube surrounded by two coils. The inner coil is connected with the aerial and earth wires, and the outer coil with the telephone receiver. This arrangement of magnets and coils is duplicated at another point of the band so that two telephones may be used or the coils may be connected in series, which often increases the strength of the signals. As the band travels slowly through the coils, the lines of force are drawn out in the direction of its motion owing to the retentivity of the iron, but when oscillatory currents arrive from the aerial circuit these lines are freed and a rapid change takes place in the magnetic field. This causes a current to flow through both coil and telephone circuit and gives a signal. (See also No. 196.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–687.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 34.
Object name: SILICON CRYSTAL.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Mrs. Gordon Langton.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The use of crystal detectors in receiving circuits renders it possible to “detect” the high-frequency currents set up in the receiving aerial, by completely rectifying the alternating current into a current whose mean value is no longer zero, and then using a polarised electro-magnetic indicator (a telephone). This is due to the fact that with certain minerals, usually crystalline, the resistance to the flow of electricity across the contact between a piece of metal, and a piece of the mineral, or between two pieces of different minerals, depends largely on the value of the current, even when the current is extremely small, and does not obey Ohm's law. Thus the P.D. current characteristic has a pronounced curvature, and consequently if an alternating E.M.F., whose mean value is zero, is applied to the crystal the mean value of the resulting current is not zero. This current is spoken of as the “rectified current.” The specimen shown is a silicon crystal, the contact being made between a crystal of silicon and steel. It is now mounted in a locket, but it was formerly used in the wireless installation of the cargo vessel S.S. “Nonsuch.” This was the first British cargo vessel to carry a wireless installation, and on September 16th, 1910, when off the coast of Morocco, she received messages from
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Presented by Mrs. Gordon Langton.
Object entry information: The use of crystal detectors in receiving circuits renders it possible to “detect” the high-frequency currents set up in the receiving aerial, by completely rectifying the alternating current into a current whose mean value is no longer zero, and then using a polarised electro-magnetic indicator (a telephone). This is due to the fact that with certain minerals, usually crystalline, the resistance to the flow of electricity across the contact between a piece of metal, and a piece of the mineral, or between two pieces of different minerals, depends largely on the value of the current, even when the current is extremely small, and does not obey Ohm's law. Thus the P.D. current characteristic has a pronounced curvature, and consequently if an alternating E.M.F., whose mean value is zero, is applied to the crystal the mean value of the resulting current is not zero. This current is spoken of as the “rectified current.” The specimen shown is a silicon crystal, the contact being made between a crystal of silicon and steel. It is now mounted in a locket, but it was formerly used in the wireless installation of the cargo vessel S.S. “Nonsuch.” This was the first British cargo vessel to carry a wireless installation, and on September 16th, 1910, when off the coast of Morocco, she received messages from the North Foreland Station, a distance of 940 nautical miles. Such a range of reception was at this time very unusual, and it was, of course, due to a fortunate conjunction of circumstances in which the crystal itself played only a secondary, though necessary, part. (See also No. 41.)

Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster General.
Object entry information: The Bronk cell is a semi-permanent rectifying detector of the galena type. It was devised by Mr. V. Bronk, of the Amalgamated Radio-telegraphy Company, and used with the Pedersen "Tikker" in the early days of continuous wave reception from Poulsen arcs.

Catalogue number: 43.
Object name: BRONK CELL DETECTOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The Bronk cell is a semi-permanent rectifying detector of the galena type. It was devised by Mr. V. Bronk, of the Amalgamated Radio-telegraphy Company, and used with the Pedersen "Tikker" in the early days of continuous wave reception from Poulsen arcs.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–690.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 44.
Object name: DE FOREST ELECTROLYTIC DETECTOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The London Telegraph Training College.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This detector, for which a patent was applied for by Dr. Lee de Forest in 1901, depends for its action on the increase of resistance in an electrollizable mixture caused by the passage of an oscillatory current. The detector itself consists of a tube containing two small metal electrode plugs, between the ends of which is a space of about 1/200 in. In this space is placed an electrollizable mixture of glycerine or vaseline mixed with water or alcohol, and a small quantity of litharge and metallic filings. These metallic filings act as secondary electrodes. If a small E.M.F. is applied to the electrodes of this tube through a resistance of about 25,000 ohms, and the two electrodes are connected to aerial and earth respectively, then theory supposes that on the arrival of a signal, oscillatory currents will pass through the cell, where they break up the chains of metallic particles. This interrupts the current passing through the telephones, and gives rise to a click. A rapid succession of oscillatory sparks is heard as a short continuous sound in the telephone receivers.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–397.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 45.
Object name: COMMERCIAL PATTERN “FLEMING” VALVE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi’s Wireless Telegraph Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This valve was the first diode to be used commercially. Though not so sensitive as a crystal detector, it was nevertheless widely used, especially for ship installations, by reason of its greater degree of immunity from the effects of mechanical vibration and of atmospheric conditions. The experimental Fleming valves shown at Nos. 20 and 73 mark the earlier stages of progress.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–488.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 46.
Object name: APPARATUS TO ILLUSTRATE THE PRINCIPLES OF SPARK TELEGRAPHY.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The apparatus here shown represents a transmitting and a receiving group constructed for demonstration purposes in the early days of wireless telegraphy. The transmitter comprises a small induction coil, to the secondary terminals of which two adjustable metal spheres are connected: a Morse key is connected in the primary circuit. The primary condenser consists of alternate sheets of tinfoil and paper, and is joined across the interrupter contacts, its functions being to reduce the break spark, and to demagnetise the core quickly. The intermittent high voltages generated in the secondary coil produce charges on the secondary condenser, setting up a state of electric strain across the gap. When the gap is set to such a width that the maximum charge on the condenser reaches a value sufficient to break down the insulation of the air, a current will flow across the gap. After a small fraction of time the discharge equalises the potentials, causing the electric strain to be removed; ultimately the condenser again charges up, and discharges across the gap, but in the opposite direction. By this means, electro-magnetic waves are generated, and radiated through the aether, the waves being heavily damped, owing to the losses in the circuit.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The Bronk cell is a semi-permanent rectifying detector of the galena type. It was devised by Mr. V. Bronk, of the Amalgamated Radio-telegraphy Company, and used with the Pedersen "Tikker" in the early days of continuous wave reception from Poulsen arcs.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–690.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 44.
Object name: DE FOREST ELECTROLYTIC DETECTOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The London Telegraph Training College.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This detector, for which a patent was applied for by Dr. Lee de Forest in 1901, depends for its action on the increase of resistance in an electrollizable mixture caused by the passage of an oscillatory current. The detector itself consists of a tube containing two small metal electrode plugs, between the ends of which is a space of about 1/200 in. In this space is placed an electrollizable mixture of glycerine or vaseline mixed with water or alcohol, and a small quantity of litharge and metallic filings. These metallic filings act as secondary electrodes. If a small E.M.F. is applied to the electrodes of this tube through a resistance of about 25,000 ohms, and the two electrodes are connected to aerial and earth respectively, then theory supposes that on the arrival of a signal, oscillatory currents will pass through the cell, where they break up the chains of metallic particles. This interrupts the current passing through the telephones, and gives rise to a click. A rapid succession of oscillatory sparks is heard as a short continuous sound in the telephone receivers.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–397.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 45.
Object name: COMMERCIAL PATTERN “FLEMING” VALVE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi’s Wireless Telegraph Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This valve was the first diode to be used commercially. Though not so sensitive as a crystal detector, it was nevertheless widely used, especially for ship installations, by reason of its greater degree of immunity from the effects of mechanical vibration and of atmospheric conditions. The experimental Fleming valves shown at Nos. 20 and 73 mark the earlier stages of progress.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–488.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 46.
Object name: APPARATUS TO ILLUSTRATE THE PRINCIPLES OF SPARK TELEGRAPHY.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The apparatus here shown represents a transmitting and a receiving group constructed for demonstration purposes in the early days of wireless telegraphy. The transmitter comprises a small induction coil, to the secondary terminals of which two adjustable metal spheres are connected: a Morse key is connected in the primary circuit. The primary condenser consists of alternate sheets of tinfoil and paper, and is joined across the interrupter contacts, its functions being to reduce the break spark, and to demagnetise the core quickly. The intermittent high voltages generated in the secondary coil produce charges on the secondary condenser, setting up a state of electric strain across the gap. When the gap is set to such a width that the maximum charge on the condenser reaches a value sufficient to break down the insulation of the air, a current will flow across the gap. After a small fraction of time the discharge equalises the potentials, causing the electric strain to be removed; ultimately the condenser again charges up, and discharges across the gap, but in the opposite direction. By this means, electro-magnetic waves are generated, and radiated through the aether, the waves being heavily damped, owing to the losses in the circuit.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

title: LLM-LINKED
description: The sources list several Fleming Oscillation Valves or Fleming Diodes. For instance, co8362216 describes an "Original Fleming oscillation valve" made by The Edison and Swan Electric Light Company (Royal Ediswan) around 1905, which matches the "Commercial Pattern" manufactured for Marconi. co467864 describes "One of Fleming's first thermionic diode valves" (accession 1925-814). The description of it being the "first diode to be used commercially" and used for ship installations aligns with the Fleming valve's history as a reliable detector superior to the coherer for naval use

Object name: APPARATUS TO ILLUSTRATE THE PRINCIPLES OF SPARK TELEGRAPHY.
Object entry information:
The apparatus here shown represents a transmitting and a receiving group constructed for demonstration purposes in the early days of wireless telegraphy. The transmitter comprises a small induction coil, to the secondary terminals of which two adjustable metal spheres are connected: a Morse key is connected in the primary circuit. The primary condenser consists of alternate sheets of tinfoil and paper, and is joined across the interrupter contacts, its functions being to reduce the break spark, and to demagnetise the core quickly. The intermittent high voltages generated in the secondary coil produce charges on the secondary condenser, setting up a state of electric strain across the gap. When the gap is set to such a width that the maximum charge on the condenser reaches a value sufficient to break down the insulation of the air, a current will flow across the gap. After a small fraction of time the discharge equalises the potentials, causing the electric strain to be removed; ultimately the condenser again charges up, and discharges across the gap, but in the opposite direction. By this means, electro-magnetic waves are generated, and radiated through the aether, the waves being heavily damped, owing to the losses in the circuit. The receiver consists of two long strips of copper foil arranged in the same line, but separated by a coherer. This consists of a narrow glass tube, exhausted of air, having two plugs of silver attached to platinum wires. Between these plugs is a space partly filled with a metallic powder, composed of 95 per cent. nickel and 5 per cent. silver. In its normal state this presents a high resistance to the passage of an electric current. When electric oscillations are set up in the coherer circuit, the resistance falls very considerably owing to an apparent cohesion of the filings, and a current can pass of sufficient strength to operate a relay.
The resistance remains at its low value until the tube is tapped and decohered.
The tapper consists of an electro-magnet having vibrating armature arranged in circuit with the coherer and battery. Immediately the coherer becomes a conductor the armature is pulled down, thereby completing another circuit containing battery and electric bell, the clapper of which communicates vibration to the metallic powder. The moment the electro-magnetic radiation ceases, the final blow of the clapper renders the coherer a non-conductor, thus breaking the bell circuit.

Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Object entry information:
This 10-in. induction coil converted for use as a telephone transformer by rewinding the primary. It was used in conjunction with a Fleming valve, at the ‘Haven’ station, Poole, in 1906, for checking the strength of signals between Clifden and Glace Bay, the first commercial trans-atlantic stations.
It is the prototype of the modern compact wireless telephone transformer.

Catalogue number: 48
Object name: MULTIPLE TUNER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Co. Presented by H.M. Post Office.
Date of creation: Patented in 1907
Object entry information: This type of receiver, patented in 1907 by Mr. C. S. Franklin and the makers, was much used on Marconi ship outfits in conjunction with the magnetic detector. The detector, being of low resistance, works on current rather than voltage effects, and hence in this receiver, capacity effects predominate and inductance effects are small.
The receiver has three circuits, aerial, intermediate, and detector, each of which must be tuned, and the tuning switches are so connected together that the three circuits may be roughly tuned simultaneously. Finer adjustments are then made by means of the three variable condensers in the three circuits. These condensers are seen on the top of the case. The degree of coupling may be altered by moving the axis of the coils of the intermediate circuit relatively to the aerial and detector circuit coils. This is effected by rotating a handle on the side of the case. The aerial loading inductance is adjusted by means of a multiple contact switch on the left front of the case.
A two-way throw-over switch is mounted on the top of the case; in the “stand-by” position it connects the detector directly into the aerial circuit, and when signals are received it is thrown over to the “tune” position so that the detector circuit is coupled to the intermediate circuit and accurate tuning can take place.
The instrument is designed to tune to all wave lengths from 300 ft. to 8,000 ft.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-685.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 49
Object name: MARK II LONG-WAVE TUNER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by the War Office.
Date of creation: Designed for the Army in 1914
Object entry information: This tuner was designed for the Army in 1914 by Major H. P. T. Lefroy, R.E. It comprises the usual aerial and closed circuits, across either of which the detector and telephones can be connected by means of a switch.
The design of the inductances should be noted. They consist of flat square spirals so connected and placed that a maximum mutual inductance effect is obtained with a minimum of resistance and capacity. These coils (one of which can be seen in the base of the instrument) are arranged to give variometer tuning in the open and closed circuits, and variable electro-magnetic coupling between them. The range of wave lengths covered is from 500 to 1,500 metres.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-162

Object name: SHORT - WAVE TUNER MARK III.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1914–18
Object entry information: This is the standard tuner used by the British Army during the War (1914–18) for the reception of wave lengths ranging from 100 to 700 metres.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Object entry information: This is the standard tuner used by the British Army during the War (1914–18) for the reception of wave lengths ranging from 100 to 700 metres. It is similar to the long wave tuner (see No. 52) except that its aerial circuit inductance is wound with fewer turns, while a variable condenser is substituted for the aerial variometer. The detector and 'phones are also connected straight across the closed circuit condenser when tuning, instead of across the optimum portion of the closed circuit inductance as with the long-wave instrument.
Raw_Response:
Continuation from previous page: TRUE
Catalogue number: N/A
Object name: N/A
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: 1904-05
Object entry information: The receiver consists of two long strips of copper foil arranged in the same line, but separated by a coherer. This consists of a narrow glass tube, exhausted of air, having two plugs of silver attached to platinum wires. Between these plugs is a space partly filled with a metallic powder, composed of 95 per cent. nickel and 5 per cent. silver. In its normal state this presents a high resistance to the passage of an electric current. When electric oscillations are set up in the coherer circuit, the resistance falls very considerably owing to an apparent cohesion of the filings, and a current can pass of sufficient strength to operate a relay.
The resistance remains at its low value until the tube is tapped and decohered.
The tapper consists of an electro-magnet having vibrating armature arranged in circuit with the coherer and battery. Immediately the coherer becomes a conductor the armature is pulled down, thereby completing another circuit containing battery and electric bell, the clapper of which communicates vibration to the metallic powder. The moment the electro-magnetic radiation ceases, the final blow of the clapper renders the coherer a non-conductor, thus breaking the bell circuit.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1904-65.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 47
Object name: TELEPHONE TRANSFORMER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This 10-in. induction coil converted for use as a telephone transformer by rewinding the primary. It was used in conjunction with a Fleming valve, at the ‘Haven’ station, Poole, in 1906, for checking the strength of signals between Clifden and Glace Bay, the first commercial trans-atlantic stations.
It is the prototype of the modern compact wireless telephone transformer.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-503

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 48
Object name: MULTIPLE TUNER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Co. Presented by H.M. Post Office.
Date of creation: Patented in 1907
Object entry information: This type of receiver, patented in 1907 by Mr. C. S. Franklin and the makers, was much used on Marconi ship outfits in conjunction with the magnetic detector. The detector, being of low resistance, works on current rather than voltage effects, and hence in this receiver, capacity effects predominate and inductance effects are small.
The receiver has three circuits, aerial, intermediate, and detector, each of which must be tuned, and the tuning switches are so connected together that the three circuits may be roughly tuned simultaneously. Finer adjustments are then made by means of the three variable condensers in the three circuits. These condensers are seen on the top of the case. The degree of coupling may be altered by moving the axis of the coils of the intermediate circuit relatively to the aerial and detector circuit coils. This is effected by rotating a handle on the side of the case. The aerial loading inductance is adjusted by means of a multiple contact switch on the left front of the case.
A two-way throw-over switch is mounted on the top of the case; in the “stand-by” position it connects the detector directly into the aerial circuit, and when signals are received it is thrown over to the “tune” position so that the detector circuit is coupled to the intermediate circuit and accurate tuning can take place.
The instrument is designed to tune to all wave lengths from 300 ft. to 8,000 ft.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-685.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 49
Object name: MARK II LONG-WAVE TUNER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by the War Office.
Date of creation: Designed for the Army in 1914
Object entry information: This tuner was designed for the Army in 1914 by Major H. P. T. Lefroy, R.E. It comprises the usual aerial and closed circuits, across either of which the detector and telephones can be connected by means of a switch.
The design of the inductances should be noted. They consist of flat square spirals so connected and placed that a maximum mutual inductance effect is obtained with a minimum of resistance and capacity. These coils (one of which can be seen in the base of the instrument) are arranged to give variometer tuning in the open and closed circuits, and variable electro-magnetic coupling between them. The range of wave lengths covered is from 500 to 1,500 metres.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-162

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 52.
Object name: LONG-WAVE TUNER, MARK IV.
Maker/Donor: Made by Army Signals Experimental Establishment. Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: During the War (1914–1918).
Object entry information: This tuner, which was designed during the War (1914–1918), is suitable for the reception of wave lengths ranging from 2,500 to 10,500 metres. With the change-over switch at the “stand by” position, the detector is connected direct in the aerial circuit for quick searching. With the switch at “tune,” the detector is included in a closed circuit, thereby increasing the selectivity, since foreign oscillations will have little effect on the sharply tuned closed circuit, particularly if the coupling is weak. This closed circuit is completed through a roller on the switch, when the latter is at the “tune” position, but is left incomplete at other times in order to avoid energy losses. A three-way detector switch is provided so that either a perikon (chalcopyrites and zincite), a carborundum (with potentiometer) or a valve detector may be used. The valve detector is not included with this set; the terminals marked “valve” must be connected to a separate panel when crystal detection is not used. The set is also provided with a switch marked “detector tap,” which enables the detector to be connected across the optimum portion of the closed circuit inductance to minimise its damping effect. The buzzer is used for adjusting the receiver and crystal detectors. The tuner coils are “bank-wound” with litzendraht (stranded) wire. (See also No. 50).
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–112.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 53.
Object name: TELEFUNKEN RECEIVING SET.
Maker/Donor: Made by The Telefunken Company. Presented by The Shipbreaking Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This receiver is of German manufacture and was designed for crystal reception of wave lengths ranging from 200 to 6,000 metres. It was taken from the German submarine V.50. The apparatus is mounted on an ebonite panel, the internal connections being made with stiff wire, enamelled in distinctive colours, so that the various circuits can be traced out. In the centre of the panel is the adjustment “Drehkopplung” for varying the coupling between aerial and detector circuits. At the top, on the left, is provided a barrel switch, by means of which the aerial and closed circuit are adjusted in ten steps for different ranges of wave lengths. The right-hand barrel switch enables either of the detector circuits to be adjusted on each wave length for three degrees of coupling—tight, medium and loose (“fest,” “mittel,” and “lose”). The detectors used are pyrites and carborundum—for which a small two-way switch, “Detektor Wahler,” is fitted at the top of the instrument. A plug-in coil on the right-hand side must be inserted for wave lengths ranging from 3,000 to 6,000 metres. The terminals at the bottom are the aerial and closed circuit condensers, for tuning purposes.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–581.

Crystal reception is used, and all alterations of circuit and wave-length are effected by means of barrel switches and variable condensers. No metal is used in or near any coils, wooden or bone screws being employed, probably in order to cut down eddy current losses. Most of the coupling rods, cranks, etc., are of insulating material, all joints being pinned.

title: Wireless receiving set (Telefunken)
description: Wireless receiving set (Telefunken)

Maker/Donor: Made by Gesellschaft F. Drahtlose Telegraphie. Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers.
Object entry information:
This receiver, known as type E.8I, was taken from the German warship “Baden,” which was interned at Scapa Flow in February, 1919. Crystal reception is used, and all alterations of circuit and wave-length are effected by means of barrel switches and variable condensers. No metal is used in or near any coils, wooden or bone screws being employed, probably in order to cut down eddy current losses. Most of the coupling rods, cranks, etc., are of insulating material, all joints being pinned. The set, which is now incomplete, is in a box measuring 21 in. by 21 in. by 26 3/4 in., on the top of which was a small motor mounted on felt and worked off 220 volts. This motor was started and stopped by the first motor direction, clockwise or anti-clockwise, of the switch marked “ Prüfschalter ” (test-switch). This drove a small toothed wheel, the teeth bearing on a spring contact and cut and spaced so that the word “ Kiel ” was spelt out in morse. A vibratory contact was also incorporated in this circuit, which was intended to facilitate adjustment of the crystals.
Five of these were detachably fitted and chosen at will by a switch (Detektor Wähler) as well as one “ Tonprüf Detektor ” for use when listening-in.
On the right hand side of the box, at the top, was mounted the “ Syncron-Summer,” an instrument for cutting out interference from a local generator.
On the front is a switch marked “ Schaltungswähler ” (circuit-choosing switch). This has six stops marked :—
(1) Prim. (White Stud).
(2) Prim. (Yellow).
(3) Sek. (Red.)
(4) Sek. (White.)
(5) Leibenröhe (Valve circuit—Red.)
(6) Leibenröhe (White.)
The resulting change of circuit effected is shown on the diagram.
The remaining switches control the capacity, inductance and coupling valves in these circuits.
The valve circuit employed was probably a two-valve high frequency amplifier.

Object name: RIGHI PATTERN SHORT WAVE OIL-IMMERSED OSCILLATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by R. P. Howgrave-Graham, Esq.
Object entry information:
This type of oscillator was invented by Prof. Righi, of Bologna, about 1896, and was used by Senatore Marconi during his early experiments, until superseded by the type of multiple oscillator shown at No. 7. It was also used for the generation of short Hertzian waves, such as are used for demonstrating quasi-optical phenomena.
The immersion of the sparking surfaces in oil tends to increase the incon-veniently small energy of emission which is generally obtained with oscillators of such small capacity, as a high potential difference is reached before the oil breaks down.
The gap resistance is reasonably low immediately after the disruption of the spark, whereas between surfaces far enough apart in air to make the breakdown-strength equal to that of the short oil gap, the ohmic resistance of the spark would be so high that oscillations would be feeble or non-existent. Such oscillators are troublesome as high-power radiators because the oil decomposes, and if the succession of sparks is rapid the oil has not time to close in and fill the gap when a spark has taken place. In such a case only the first of a stream of sparks is oscillatory, and after its passage the oil is worse than useless.

Object entry information: This type of oscillator was invented by Prof. Righi, of Bologna, about 1896, and was used by Senatore Marconi during his early experiments, until superseded by the type of multiple oscillator shown at No. 7. It was also used for the generation of short Hertzian waves, such as are used for demonstrating quasi-optical phenomena.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 56.
Object name: ADJUSTABLE SPARK GAP.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This early form of spark gap consists of two cylindrical steel rods having flat ends, between which the spark is formed. The rods are urged apart by springs, and by compressing the springs the gap can be adjusted.
In all types of gap the passage of the spark ionises the air and makes it temporarily conducting. The gap therefore functions as an automatic switch.
Stationary spark gaps of this kind arc not constant in action. There is a tendency toward the formation of an arc across the ionised gap, wasting power and delaying the recovery of the insulating properties of the gap. Moreover, the interval between successive sparks is apt to be very uneven, as the spark takes place between a succession of pairs of points.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-179.

Catalogue number: 58
Object name: TUNED FIELD TRANSMITTER AND SPARK COIL.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Date of creation: approximately 1907
Object entry information: This represents a very early attempt to manufacture really portable wireless sets for Army use; its date is approximately 1907. The apparatus presents no unusual features.
