Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 59
Object name: ROTARY SPARK GAP.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office. (Designed by Mr. J. G. Balsillie)
Date of creation: about 1910
Object entry information: This is an early form of rotary spark gap, designed by Mr. J. G. Balsillie, about 1910. The main advantage of such gaps is that any tendency towards arcing is checked by the rotation of the electrodes, which wear out any incipient arc. In the present example this effect is heightened by the peculiar shape of the rotating electrodes, which produce a large air pressure between the surfaces when they are in close proximity. The direction of rotation is, of course, such that the convex surface of a moving electrode is the first to reach the fixed electrode. (See also No. 57.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-180.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 60
Object name: MOTOR GENERATOR.
Maker/Donor: Made by The A.E.G. Company, Berlin. Presented by The Imperial War Museum.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This set was used for wireless work in a German submarine during the late War (1914-18), and consists of a continuous current motor, coupled direct to an alternator. The D.C. motor is series-wound, taking 13 amperes at 110 volts, and running at 3,000 r.p.m. The generator yields alternating current at 220 volts and 500 cycles. This current would be fed to a transformer similar to the adjacent example, and the output from this would then be used for spark transmission.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-623.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 61
Object name: WIRELESS TELEGRAPH TRANSFORMER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Siemens-Halske. Presented by The Imperial War Museum.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a typical alternating current transformer, designed for a ship's wireless transmitter, to enable it to be operated from the main electric supply. The transformer is of the closed-core type and has a step-up ratio of 150 to 5,000 volts, the latter pressure being applied to the closed circuit of a damped wave transmitter. The winding layers are interspaced with insulating material, and when in use the transformer is impregnated with bitumen to increase the insulation. The iron case is provided with an earthing terminal. The transformer was taken from a German salvage vessel. (See also No. 47.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-626.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 62
Object name: OSCILLATION TRANSFORMER AND AERIAL TUNING INDUCTANCE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1916 (First manufactured for Army use)
Object entry information: This oscillation transformer, or "Tesla" coil, formed part of the transmitting equipment of a 1½ kw. quenched spark set, first manufactured for Army use in 1916. The set was carried on a light motor lorry, the engine of which was used to drive the transmitter alternator. The closed circuit inductance is variable by means of plugs and movable sockets, and forms a hinged coupling with the aerial circuit inductance, which is continuously variable. The range of wave-lengths is from 550 to 1,200 metres.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-186.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 63
Object name: VARIABLE TRANSMITTING INDUCTANCE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Imperial War Museum.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is an inductance coil of German make, composed of flat coils, which are normally immersed in oil in a glass container. It consists of six spiral springs from which tappings are taken to 11 contacts fixed to the inside of an ebonite cylinder, the connections thereto being insulated with concentric sleeves of cardboard and glass. The whole is contained in a small glass tank which normally contains the insulating oil; the ebonite cover has a rotating copper brush which makes contact with the coil connections.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-625.

Object entry information: This is an inductance coil of German make, composed of flat coils, which are normally immersed in oil in a glass container. It consists of six spiral springs from which tappings are taken to 11 contacts fixed to the inside of an ebonite cylinder, the connections thereto being insulated with concentric sleeves of cardboard and glass. Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Siemens-Halske. Presented by The Imperial War Museum.
Object entry information: This is a typical alternating current transformer, designed for a ship's wireless transmitter, to enable it to be operated from the main electric supply. The transformer is of the closed-core type and has a step-up ratio of 150 to 5,000 volts, the latter pressure being applied to the closed circuit of a damped wave transmitter. The winding layers are interspaced with insulating material, and when in use the transformer is impregnated with bitumen to increase the insulation. The iron case is provided with an earthing terminal. The transformer was taken from a German salvage vessel. (See also No. 47.)

Object name: TUNED FIELD TRANSMITTER AND SPARK COIL.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Date of creation: approximately 1907
Object entry information: This represents a very early attempt to manufacture really portable wireless sets for Army use; its date is approximately 1907. The apparatus presents no unusual features.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 59
Object name: ROTARY SPARK GAP.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office. (Designed by Mr. J. G. Balsillie)
Date of creation: about 1910
Object entry information: This is an early form of rotary spark gap, designed by Mr. J. G. Balsillie, about 1910. The main advantage of such gaps is that any tendency towards arcing is checked by the rotation of the electrodes, which wear out any incipient arc. In the present example this effect is heightened by the peculiar shape of the rotating electrodes, which produce a large air pressure between the surfaces when they are in close proximity. The direction of rotation is, of course, such that the convex surface of a moving electrode is the first to reach the fixed electrode. (See also No. 57.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-180.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 60
Object name: MOTOR GENERATOR.
Maker/Donor: Made by The A.E.G. Company, Berlin. Presented by The Imperial War Museum.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This set was used for wireless work in a German submarine during the late War (1914-18), and consists of a continuous current motor, coupled direct to an alternator. The D.C. motor is series-wound, taking 13 amperes at 110 volts, and running at 3,000 r.p.m. The generator yields alternating current at 220 volts and 500 cycles. This current would be fed to a transformer similar to the adjacent example, and the output from this would then be used for spark transmission.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-623.

Catalogue number: 62
Object name: OSCILLATION TRANSFORMER AND AERIAL TUNING INDUCTANCE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1916 (First manufactured for Army use)
Object entry information: This oscillation transformer, or "Tesla" coil, formed part of the transmitting equipment of a 1½ kw. quenched spark set, first manufactured for Army use in 1916. The set was carried on a light motor lorry, the engine of which was used to drive the transmitter alternator. The closed circuit inductance is variable by means of plugs and movable sockets, and forms a hinged coupling with the aerial circuit inductance, which is continuously variable. The range of wave-lengths is from 550 to 1,200 metres.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-186.

Catalogue number: 64
Object name: TRANSMITTING VARIOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Imperial War Museum.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This variable inductance comprises two sets of coils, one being fixed and the other moving. The coils are spirally wound with Litzendraht wire and are connected in parallel.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 65
Object name: TRANSMITTING VARIOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1914–1918
Object entry information: This example of a four-coil transmitting variometer was used in one of the German stations during the War (1914–1918). The apparatus consists of four coils wound of flat strip to provide a large surface for the passage of high-frequency currents, the strips being clamped between corrugated porcelain guides held in a framework of wood and red fibre screws and nuts. The four coils are connected in series, and the holders are cross-connected through gearing so that each pair of coils can be simultaneously, and uniformly, advanced and retracted to vary their mutual inductance. A coupling is provided for a remote control for moving the coils, and the whole mechanism is of a very robust nature. (The system is shown diagrammatically in Prof. Fleming's work, “The Principles of Electric Wave Telegraphy and Telephony, p. 166.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–183.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 66
Object name: CLOCKWORK TRANSMITTER AND COILS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: about 1910
Object entry information: This is a portion of some apparatus designed by Major E. D. Carden, R.E., about 1910. By means of variometers rotated continuously by clockwork, at the transmitting and receiving stations, the wave-length on which radio communication is taking place is caused to vary continuously between certain limits. The possibilities of secrecy inherent in this arrangement were not realised in practice, on account of the difficulty of obtaining sharp tuning in the apparatus then available, but with undamped waves the method might well have proved successful. The apparatus shown is an incomplete portion of the transmitter. The clockwork portion was afterwards used with contacts, for automatic Morse transmission, in connection with some high-speed experiments.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–187.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 67
Object name: 500-WATT WILSON HIGH-TENSION GENERATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by W. Hamilton Wilson, Esq.
Date of creation: Constructed in 1914.
Object entry information: This instrument is the original model, constructed in 1914, of the high-tension generators working upon the “Buffer Transformer” principle, which were extensively employed during the war in spark transmitting sets (Wilson 130-watt transmitters and 54a transmitters), and later in the Mercantile Marine for ships main and emergency spark transmitters, also in X-ray and electro-medical diathermy apparatus. The instrument takes 5 amperes at 100 volts D.C., and is designed to charge a .01 mfd. condenser to a sparking voltage of 11,000 at a spark frequency of about 600 per second. The instrument consists of a motor-driven interrupter and two transformers, (a) the high-tension transformer, the secondary of which is connected to the spark gap, .01 mfd. condenser, etc., (b) the “buffer transformer,” the secondary of which is connected to a .4 mfd. condenser. The primary windings of the transformers are connected in series with the interrupter. The interrupter consists of a disc of insulating material, mounted on the shaft of the motor, with nine equally spaced copper segments embedded in its outer surface. The copper segments serve to make and break contact with two copper brushes rubbing on the periphery of the disc. When the interrupter is rotated at the correct speed, 4,000 r.p.m., and the signalling key in the supply circuit is closed, the E.M.F.s induced at “make” in the secondary of the “buffer transformer,” set that circuit into a state of continuous oscillation. The interrupter is adjusted so that it opens and closes the primary circuit at moments when the “buffer” secondary current is passing through zero values, so that one half oscillation occurs during “make” and the other half oscillation during “break.” The coupling between these two circuits during “make” causes that half-wave to be higher in amplitude
Object/Inventory number: N/A

The interrupter consists of a disc of insulating material, mounted on the shaft of the motor, with nine equally spaced copper segments embedded in its outer surface. The copper segments serve to make and break contact with two copper brushes rubbing on the periphery of the disc. When the interrupter is rotated at the correct speed, 4,000 r.p.m., and the signalling key in the supply circuit is closed, the E.M.F.s induced at “make” in the secondary of the “buffer transformer,” set that circuit into a state of continuous oscillation. The interrupter is adjusted so that it opens and closes the primary circuit at moments when the “buffer” secondary current is passing through zero values, so that one half oscillation occurs during “make” and the other half oscillation during “break.” The coupling between these two circuits during “make” causes that half-wave to be higher in amplitude

Maker/Donor: Presented by W. Hamilton Wilson, Esq.
Object entry information: This instrument is the original model, constructed in 1914, of the high-tension generators working upon the “Buffer Transformer” principle, which were extensively employed during the war in spark transmitting sets (Wilson 130-watt transmitters and 54a transmitters), and later in the Mercantile Marine for ships main and emergency spark transmitters, also in X-ray and electro-medical diathermy apparatus. The instrument takes 5 amperes at 100 volts D.C., and is designed to charge a .01 mfd. condenser to a sparking voltage of 11,000 at a spark frequency of about 600 per second. The instrument consists of a motor-driven interrupter and two transformers, (a) the high-tension transformer, the secondary of which is connected to the spark gap, .01 mfd. condenser, etc., (b) the “buffer transformer,” the secondary of which is connected to a .4 mfd. condenser. The primary windings of the transformers are connected in series with the interrupter. The interrupter consists of a disc of insulating material, mounted on the shaft of the motor, with nine equally spaced copper segments embedded in its outer surface. The copper segments serve to make and break contact with two copper brushes rubbing on the periphery of the disc. When the interrupter is rotated at the correct speed, 4,000 r.p.m., and the signalling key in the supply circuit is closed, the E.M.F.s induced at “make” in the secondary of the “buffer transformer,” set that circuit into a state of continuous oscillation. The interrupter is adjusted so that it opens and closes the primary circuit at moments when the “buffer” secondary current is passing through zero values, so that one half oscillation occurs during “make” and the other half oscillation during “break.” The coupling between these two circuits during “make” causes that half-wave to be higher in amplitude and shorter in duration than the free half-wave during “break.” The oscillation of energy in the “buffer” secondary circuit induces E.M.Fs. in the primary assisting the supply circuit at the moment of closing the circuit and opposing it at the instant of “break.” The primary current, therefore, rises sharply to a maximum and then falls to zero again in time with the secondary oscillation. The interruption of the primary circuit, therefore, takes place when the supply current is at zero value, and there is then little tendency to spark. The effect of the high-tension transformer sets up a high E.M.F. in its secondary at each “make,” which is communicated to the condenser and spark gap connected to the high-tension circuit circuit occurs while the primary is closed and not when it is opened, as in the case in the ordinary Ruhmkorff induction coil.

Object name: TRANSMITTING VARIOMETER.

Object entry information: This variable inductance comprises two sets of coils, one being fixed and the other moving. The coils are spirally wound with Litzendraht wire and are connected in parallel.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–624.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 65
Object name: TRANSMITTING VARIOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1914–1918
Object entry information: This example of a four-coil transmitting variometer was used in one of the German stations during the War (1914–1918). The apparatus consists of four coils wound of flat strip to provide a large surface for the passage of high-frequency currents, the strips being clamped between corrugated porcelain guides held in a framework of wood and red fibre screws and nuts. The four coils are connected in series, and the holders are cross-connected through gearing so that each pair of coils can be simultaneously, and uniformly, advanced and retracted to vary their mutual inductance. A coupling is provided for a remote control for moving the coils, and the whole mechanism is of a very robust nature. (The system is shown diagrammatically in Prof. Fleming's work, “The Principles of Electric Wave Telegraphy and Telephony, p. 166.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–183.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 66
Object name: CLOCKWORK TRANSMITTER AND COILS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: about 1910
Object entry information: This is a portion of some apparatus designed by Major E. D. Carden, R.E., about 1910. By means of variometers rotated continuously by clockwork, at the transmitting and receiving stations, the wave-length on which radio communication is taking place is caused to vary continuously between certain limits. The possibilities of secrecy inherent in this arrangement were not realised in practice, on account of the difficulty of obtaining sharp tuning in the apparatus then available, but with undamped waves the method might well have proved successful. The apparatus shown is an incomplete portion of the transmitter. The clockwork portion was afterwards used with contacts, for automatic Morse transmission, in connection with some high-speed experiments.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–187.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 69.
Object name: 100-WATT HIGH-TENSION UNIT.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument consists of a vibrating converter with transformer and valve rectifier, and is designed to provide a steady H.T. supply for the transmitters of military wireless field sets. The instrument takes 5-6 amps. at 20 volts and supplies about 50 milliamps. at 1,000 volts. The converter consists essentially of an induction coil having two primary windings wound in opposite directions, and one secondary winding. The two primary windings have one common end, which is connected with the negative pole of the direct-current supply, the other two ends being connected with two contact screws on spring arms between which vibrates a polarised armature carrying a contact. This armature is connected with the positive supply, and by making contact alternately with each primary winding, an alternating E.M.F. is generated in the secondary winding. The converter is designed to give 100 volts at 350 cycles per second, and this E.M.F. is applied to the primary of a transformer and stepped up to about 3,200 volts. The ends of the secondary winding of the transformer are connected with the anodes of two U.3 rectifying valves (not shown) which become alternately about 1,500 volts positive and 1,600 volts negative with respect to a tapping in the middle of the winding. The tapping is connected with the valve filaments through a 1 mfd. condenser, the plates of which are connected with the H.T. positive and negative terminals, and are thus always charged in the same direction by pulses of current. Discharging at the same time through the valves of the transmitter the plates assume, therefore, a potential such that the quantity of electricity flowing in from the transformer is approximately equal to the quantity flowing in from the transmitter. This potential is about 1,000 volts and the "ripple" or amplitude of the alternating component of H.T. voltage is 2 to 3 per cent.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-116.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Object entry information: First This very simple set comprises an induction coil, a fixed spark gap electromagnetic coupled oscillating system with semi-variable sliding coupling, and a crystal receiver. Power was derived from a 10-volt accumulator, the consumption being some 50 watts. Three fixed wave-lengths of 350, 450 and 550 metres respectively were available, and the antenna system consisted of a single wire 150 ft. long suspended between two masts, one 15 ft. and one 4 ft. high. The same aerial circuit is used for transmitter and receiver. The latter includes a carborundum crystal with potentiometer, and the manipulation of the key during transmission disconnects the crystal so as to prevent it from becoming insensitive. The aerial circuit may be directly excited by a buzzer and the receiver closed circuit is calibrated in wave-lengths.

description: Listed as "WT Set, forward spark 20 watt B, transmitter pt B, Mk 1... 1915-1918". Object name: FORWARD SPARK B MARK II TRANSMITTING AND RECEIVING SETS.
Maker/Donor: The War Office
Object entry information: These 20-watt spark transmitters and receivers for wave-lengths of 65 or 80 metres were designed during the War of 1914–1918 for use in the forward areas. The rear transmitter consists of an induction coil, with its secondary connected across a spark gap and closed oscillatory circuit, which is coupled to a coil connected with the aerial and earth terminals. This set used an aerial; the front transmitter employed a 3 ft. loop of one turn. The front receiver is for use with two “R” type valves (not shown): The first is a retro-active amplifier-rectifier, in which rectification is performed by the cumulative grid method, the reactive coupling being introduced between the grid and plate circuits. This is coupled by a low frequency inter-valve transformer to the second valve which acts as a note-magnifier. In the plate circuit of this valve is connected a telephone transformer. This receiver only differs from the rear receiver in that two short lengths of insulated wires are connected to the aerial and earth terminals in place of the more conspicuous and troublesome aerial system.

Object entry information: Power was derived from a 10-volt accumulator, the consumption being some 50 watts. Three fixed wave-lengths of 350, 450 and 550 metres respectively were available, and the antenna system consisted of a single wire 150 ft. long suspended between two masts, one 15 ft. and one 4 ft. high. The same aerial circuit is used for transmitter and receiver. The latter includes a carborundum crystal with potentiometer, and the manipulation of the key during transmission disconnects the crystal so as to prevent it from becoming insensitive. The aerial circuit may be directly excited by a buzzer and the receiver closed circuit is calibrated in wave-lengths.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 72.
Object name: FORWARD SPARK B MARK II TRANSMITTING AND RECEIVING SETS.
Maker/Donor: The War Office
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These 20-watt spark transmitters and receivers for wave-lengths of 65 or 80 metres were designed during the War of 1914–1918 for use in the forward areas. The rear transmitter consists of an induction coil, with its secondary connected across a spark gap and closed oscillatory circuit, which is coupled to a coil connected with the aerial and earth terminals. This set used an aerial; the front transmitter employed a 3 ft. loop of one turn. The front receiver is for use with two “R” type valves (not shown): The first is a retro-active amplifier-rectifier, in which rectification is performed by the cumulative grid method, the reactive coupling being introduced between the grid and plate circuits. This is coupled by a low frequency inter-valve transformer to the second valve which acts as a note-magnifier. In the plate circuit of this valve is connected a telephone transformer. This receiver only differs from the rear receiver in that two short lengths of insulated wires are connected to the aerial and earth terminals in place of the more conspicuous and troublesome aerial system.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–125, 126 and 132.

Maker/Donor: Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company
Object entry information:
Next in importance after the invention of the original two-electrode valve by Dr. J. A. Fleming in 1904, comes the introduction of a third electrode into the evacuated bulb. This notable step was taken by Dr. Lee de Forest, of the United States, who evolved his three-electrode “Audion” tube in 1907, but did not describe it publicly until 1913; this tube, and the subsequent Lieben-Reisz Gas relay (No. 75) have led up to important achievements in many branches of physics and engineering, particularly in electrical communication. De Forest had been working on the simple rectifying diode of Fleming, which he re-named the “Audion”; but he afterwards transferred this appellation to the three-electrode tube which is his special contribution to the subject. The third electrode consists of a metal strip of wire bent into the form of a grid, and situated between the filament and the anode. It serves as a control element whereby the current between them is influenced. The revolutionary possibilities of the instrument are bound up in the almost complete absence of inertia effects, and in the dependence of the anode current on the potential existing at any time between the grid and the filament. By making appropriate use of these properties the valve may be used as a detector of high frequency currents, as was the original Fleming valve, or as a medium for the amplification of high or low frequency currents, or as a means of generating undamped oscillations. Photographs of two instruments embodying these latter functions, designed by De Forest in 1914, are exhibited.
Owing to an imperfect understanding of the rationale of the triode and to a lack of technical resources existing at the time, the Audion valve was not very highly evacuated, and belongs to a class now known as "gas valves." It remained for Dr. I. Langmuir to produce in the "Pliotron" valve the first tube to function entirely by virtue of electrons emitted from the filament. The "Pliotron" is shown at No. 76.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Right Hon. Sir Henry Norman, Bart.
Object entry information:
At about the same time that L. de Forest was investigating his three-electrode valve, Messrs. Lieben and Reisz were experimenting in Vienna with a similar appliance. They named this a "Gas Relay," and in its final form it was fully described in November, 1913.
Like the Audion, it could be used as a generator of electrical oscillations, but it was intended to be used mainly as an amplifier of speech currents, and it was the first triode to be definitely so employed.
The appearance of this tube aroused fresh interest in the whole subject, and the Lieben-Reisz Relay shares with the Audion and the Fleming valve the distinction of having brought about a revolution in methods of electrical communication.
The tube differs from the Audion in having an oxide-coated filament, a type which has since been widely used in "dull-emitter" valves. The principle is due to Wehnelt, who, in 1904, discovered that strongly heated oxides, particularly those of calcium and barium, emit electrons at very low voltages.
The cathode in this case is a platinum strip 1 metre in length and 0.02 mm. in width, wound in a zigzag form on a glass support, and is coated in the manner described above.
The grid is a circular aluminium plate perforated with holes about 3.5 mm. in diameter, while the anode is a short spiral of 2 mm. aluminium wire, placed at the apex of the tube.
The cathode is brought to a bright red heat at a temperature of about 1,000 deg. C. by a battery of 30 volts; the necessary anode voltage being 220.
In the early experiments it was found difficult to obtain a uniform discharge owing to variation of the gas pressure inside the tube. It was therefore decided to replace the gas discharge with a vapour discharge by introducing mercury vapour inside the tube, constancy of pressure being obtained by means of a small quantity of mercury amalgam placed in the side tube.
For speech frequency a magnification constant of 33 was obtained with this relay, and the inventors described a cascade connection similar to those which are now common, by means of which an amplification of 20,000 times was obtained from four tubes.
As early as 1913 Dr. A. Meissner, of the Telefunken Company, made experiments with the Lieben-Reisz tube as a generator of continuous oscillations for wireless communication. He coupled the input and output circuits, so producing the famous "Feed-back" or retroactive circuit, and actually succeeded in transmitting speech over a distance of 36 km. by means of a radio-telephone set constructed on this principle. (For a full description of the Lieben-Reisz tube, see Reisz: *Electrician*, Vol. 72, p. 726.)

Catalogue number: 76.
Object name: PLIOTRON VALVE. Plate 8 (c).
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a thermionic tube of much historical importance. In all the valves which preceded the pliotron a relatively large amount of residual gas was present in the bulb. This had a very considerable influence in supplying positive ions within it, which tended to neutralise the space charge effect of the electron currents between cathode and anode, and enabled comparatively large currents to be passed at low potentials. But the presence of such an amount of gas as is indicated by a pressure of 1/10,000 mm. of mercury, led to great instability, so that the results obtained with these gas tubes were often most uncertain.
Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: Lieben-Reisz gas valve
description: Lieben-Reisz gas valve, formerly belonging to Henry Norman MP, 1911-1913.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Object entry information: This is a thermionic tube of much historical importance. In all the valves which preceded the pliotron a relatively large amount of residual gas was present in the bulb. This had a very considerable influence in supplying positive ions within it, which tended to neutralise the space charge effect of the electron currents between cathode and anode, and enabled comparatively large currents to be passed at low potentials. But the presence of such an amount of gas as is indicated by a pressure of 1/10,000 mm. of mercury, led to great instability, so that the results obtained with these gas tubes were often most uncertain. Until 1915, however, it had been concluded that the presence of some gas was necessary in a valve. In that year Dr. Irving Langmuir, of the General Electric Company of America, as the result of research based on the earlier work of Dr. J. A> Fleming, Sir J. J. Thomson and Prof. O. W. Richardson, produced the first commercial tubes in which the action was demonstrably due to pure electron discharge from the filament, and not to the presence of minute traces of gas. One of these tubes, a diode, he named a "Kenetron." The other, an example of which is here shown, was called a "Pliotron." In this tube, which is intended for amplification of radio signals, the filament is of tungsten and the grid and anode are of nickel wire. The grid is wound with very fine wire supported on a glass framework, and the characteristic curve is such that the anode-grid slope conductance is about 0.275 ma. per grid volt. The general form of the curve is given by :- ia = A (Va + m Vg).312 where ia is the anode current, Va is the anode voltage, Vg the grid voltage and m a constant depending on the relative shapes and positions of the electrodes. By means of an original mercury condensation pump Dr. Langmuir succeeded in exhausting these tubes down to a pressure o fthe order of 1/100,000 mm. of mercury, at which pressure the characteristics of the valve are perfectly smooth and regular. It is for this reason that practically all  modern valves are of the hard type.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 104
Object name: N.R.2
Maker/Donor: General Electric Co.
Date of creation: June, 1917 (Quantity production commenced)
Object entry information: A "soft" valve filled with nitrogen gas and tested at various pressures, ranging between 0.0074 and 0.6 mm. Hg. Owing to troubles with the nitrogen disappearing through absorption by the electrodes, helium gas at 0.6 mm. was later standardized with satisfactory results in the life and steadiness of valve. Quantity production was undertaken by the General Electric Co., and commenced in June, 1917. Anode.—Nickel sheet bent to a complete cylinder, 15 mm. diam., 9 mm. length, 18.5 mm. Grid.—Helix of molybdenum wire, 0.4 mm. diam., 4 to 5 mm. internal diam., 5.5 turns per cm.; length, 20 mm.; diam., 0.083 mm. Filament.—Drawn tungsten wire, length, 20 mm.; diam., 0.083 mm. Filament P.D.—3.3 volts. Filament Current.—1.1 amps. Grid Potential.—Potentiometer adjusted in use. Anode Potential.—24–40 volts.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 105
Object name: N.R.2a
Maker/Donor: Marconi-Osram Valve Co.
Date of creation: During the War (1914–18)
Object entry information: This valve was similar to, and developed from the N.R.2, and marked the final development of gas-filled "soft" valves used in naval installations during the War (1914–18). It was manufactured by the Marconi-Osram Valve Co. Characteristics same as R.2, excepting anode volts, 28–38.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 106
Object name: N.R.4
Maker/Donor: B.T.H. Co.; General Electric Co.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: A high vacuum valve evolved by Mr. Edmundsden, of the B.T.H. Co., from results observed with a "freak" valve with distorted filament. The grid diameter was in consequence made as small as possible, the diameter and spacing of the grid helix being chosen so that the calculated value of the grid constant should be the same as observed in the freak valve. The filament leads were brought round the outside of the bulb to a screw cap secured to the sealing off point. It met practically all requirements for a vacuum valve, being very similar in characteristics to the "soft" valve, but more reliable. The slopes at an anode voltage of 50 are generally very rare, some valves surviving 8,000 hours, and in characteristics were comparable with those of the French, or the hard audion valve, at 70 or 80 volts, while the corresponding anode current was less in the proportion of 3 to 1. All the "A" series were manufactured by the General Electric Co. Anode.—Nickel sheet, 0.15 mm. thickness, 9.0 mm. diameter of cylinder, 3.5 mm. internal diam., 20 mm. length, 26 mm. length, crimped molybdenum wire, 0.15 mm. diam.; pitch, 19 turns in 20 mm. length, 26 mm. length, 20 mm.; crimped tungsten wire; 1 per cent. thoriated tungsten wire; 0.088 mm. diam. Filament P.D.—3.5 to 4.0 volts. Filament Current.—1.0 to 1.2 amps. Anode Potential.—45–55 volts.
Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: LLM-LINKED
description: Listed as "Z Electric Lamp Co. valve, type R". The "Z" Electric Lamp Co. manufactured Type R valves, which were designated N.R.5 (Navy Receiving valve No. 5) for naval use.

Catalogue number: 104
Object name: N.R.2
Maker/Donor: General Electric Co.
Date of creation: June, 1917 (Quantity production commenced)
Object entry information: A "soft" valve filled with nitrogen gas and tested at various pressures, ranging between 0.0074 and 0.6 mm. Hg. Owing to troubles with the nitrogen disappearing through absorption by the electrodes, helium gas at 0.6 mm. was later standardized with satisfactory results in the life and steadiness of valve. Quantity production was undertaken by the General Electric Co., and commenced in June, 1917. Anode.—Nickel sheet bent to a complete cylinder, 15 mm. diam., 9 mm. length, 18.5 mm. Grid.—Helix of molybdenum wire, 0.4 mm. diam., 4 to 5 mm. internal diam., 5.5 turns per cm.; length, 20 mm.; diam., 0.083 mm. Filament.—Drawn tungsten wire, length, 20 mm.; diam., 0.083 mm. Filament P.D.—3.3 volts. Filament Current.—1.1 amps. Grid Potential.—Potentiometer adjusted in use. Anode Potential.—24–40 volts.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 105
Object name: N.R.2a
Maker/Donor: Marconi-Osram Valve Co.
Date of creation: During the War (1914–18)
Object entry information: This valve was similar to, and developed from the N.R.2, and marked the final development of gas-filled "soft" valves used in naval installations during the War (1914–18). It was manufactured by the Marconi-Osram Valve Co. Characteristics same as R.2, excepting anode volts, 28–38.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 106
Object name: N.R.4
Maker/Donor: B.T.H. Co.; General Electric Co.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: A high vacuum valve evolved by Mr. Edmundsden, of the B.T.H. Co., from results observed with a "freak" valve with distorted filament. The grid diameter was in consequence made as small as possible, the diameter and spacing of the grid helix being chosen so that the calculated value of the grid constant should be the same as observed in the freak valve. The filament leads were brought round the outside of the bulb to a screw cap secured to the sealing off point. It met practically all requirements for a vacuum valve, being very similar in characteristics to the "soft" valve, but more reliable. The slopes at an anode voltage of 50 are generally very rare, some valves surviving 8,000 hours, and in characteristics were comparable with those of the French, or the hard audion valve, at 70 or 80 volts, while the corresponding anode current was less in the proportion of 3 to 1. All the "A" series were manufactured by the General Electric Co. Anode.—Nickel sheet, 0.15 mm. thickness, 9.0 mm. diameter of cylinder, 3.5 mm. internal diam., 20 mm. length, 26 mm. length, crimped molybdenum wire, 0.15 mm. diam.; pitch, 19 turns in 20 mm. length, 26 mm. length, 20 mm.; crimped tungsten wire; 1 per cent. thoriated tungsten wire; 0.088 mm. diam. Filament P.D.—3.5 to 4.0 volts. Filament Current.—1.0 to 1.2 amps. Anode Potential.—45–55 volts.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Catalogue number: 110.
Object name: N.R.5.
Maker/Donor: Manufactured by the “Z” Electric Lamp Co.
Date of creation: 1914–18
Object entry information: Another very similar valve evolved experimentally from the R.4 series, in which quantity production showed that the characteristics did not conform to those obtained experimentally, and were not so good as the round “V.24” until the filament has been redesigned to give a saturation current four times the working current, instead of about twice. The R.5 is the R.4 so modified, and showed an advantage over the V.24, giving equal results in operation just within, instead of just outside, the capabilities of a 4-volt accumulator. The R.5, among high vacuum valves, marks the final phase in naval installations during the War (1914–18). *Anode.*—Nickel sheet bent to a complete cylinder. Thickness, 0.15 mm.; length of cylinder, 9.0 mm.; diam. of cylinder, 9.0 mm. *Grid.*—Helix of molybdenum wire; 0.15 mm. diam.; pitch, 14 turns in 16 mm.; length, 16 mm.; internal diam., 3.0 mm. *Filament.*—Pure tungsten wire; length, 22.0 mm.; diam., 0.060 mm. *Filament P.D.*—3.2 to 3.9 volts. *Filament Current.*—0.60 to 0.68 amps. *Anode Potential.*—30–60 volts.

Maker/Donor: Made by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company. Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Object entry information: Amongst the first to be designed, and intermediate between the audion and the pliotron. Produced by Mr. J. H. Round, of the Marconi Company, in 1913. The cylindrical anode and grid construction, now so common, should be compared with the flat plates of the audion valve. Since the performance of the tube depends to a great extent on the degree of vacuum maintained, a means of varying this is provided. It consists of a small pouch blown in the glass and sealed inside the bulb, in which a quantity of asbestos is placed. On warming the asbestos a certain amount of the gas occluded by it is liberated, and in this way the progressive hardening which occurs under certain conditions when the tube is in use can be corrected. The transmitting tube contains three separate filaments which can be used in turn until all three have been burnt out. Successful radio-telephony was carried out by Mr. J. H. Round in June, 1914, with a continuous-wave transmitter containing a tube of this type. The filaments are of the Wehnelt oxide-coated type.

Maker/Donor: Presented by The Marconi-Osram Valve Co.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a 30-watt transmitting valve of the ordinary cylindrical type, with an impedance of about 70,000 ohms. It was designed for a maximum anode voltage of 1,500 volts, the filament taking a current of 1·8 amps. at 7 volts.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-622.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 121.
Object name: WIRELESS TRANSMITTING TRIODE.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by The Mullard Radio Valve Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is one of the largest glass triodes that it has been found practicable to construct, owing to the tendency of the glass envelope to crack at the high temperatures developed. The anode is of nickel, the supply voltage being 2,000 and upwards. The helical grid of molybdenum is supported on three rods of the same material. The filament consumes 5·5 amps. at 18 volts, and the re-entrant construction of the tube makes it possible to shorten the electron path from grid to anode. The triode can be worked without becoming unduly hot with a steady load of 1,500 watts, derived from grid and plate circuits.

Catalogue number: 118.
Object name: “ROUND” TRANSMITTING VALVE.
Maker/Donor: Made by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company. Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1913
Object entry information: Amongst the first to be designed, and intermediate between the audion and the pliotron. Produced by Mr. J. H. Round, of the Marconi Company, in 1913. The cylindrical anode and grid construction, now so common, should be compared with the flat plates of the audion valve. Since the performance of the tube depends to a great extent on the degree of vacuum maintained, a means of varying this is provided. It consists of a small pouch blown in the glass and sealed inside the bulb, in which a quantity of asbestos is placed. On warming the asbestos a certain amount of the gas occluded by it is liberated, and in this way the progressive hardening which occurs under certain conditions when the tube is in use can be corrected. The transmitting tube contains three separate filaments which can be used in turn until all three have been burnt out. Successful radio-telephony was carried out by Mr. J. H. Round in June, 1914, with a continuous-wave transmitter containing a tube of this type. The filaments are of the Wehnelt oxide-coated type.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-158.

Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922-430.

title: Transmitting valve type T.30 W/T
description: Transmitting valve type T.30 W/T

Maker/Donor: Made and lent by The Mullard Radio Valve Company.
Object entry information: This is one of the largest glass triodes that it has been found practicable to construct, owing to the tendency of the glass envelope to crack at the high temperatures developed. The anode is of nickel, the supply voltage being 2,000 and upwards. The helical grid of molybdenum is supported on three rods of the same material. The filament consumes 5·5 amps. at 18 volts, and the re-entrant construction of the tube makes it possible to shorten the electron path from grid to anode. The triode can be worked without becoming unduly hot with a steady load of 1,500 watts, derived from grid and plate circuits. tube makes it possible to renew the filament and thus indefinitely prolong the life of the triode. This construction has also the effect of providing a long leakage path from grid to anode. The triode is capable of dissipating about 500 watts of electrical energy without becoming overheated, the output of high-frequency energy being 500 to 1,500 watts, depending on the efficiency of the circuit.

title: Renewable Filament Transmitting Valve
description: Renewable Filament Transmitting Valve

Maker/Donor: Presented by The Marconi-Osram Valve Co.
Object entry information: This valve was produced in collaboration with the Signals Experimental Establishment, Woolwich. By reason of its mechanical design the valve has a low internal impedance, and is capable of dissipating considerable power at the anode. The filament takes a current of 5·8 amps. at 17 volts, the emission current being half an ampere. The valve is capable of undergoing satisfactorily a dead loss test of 500 watts.

Object name: TYPE U.I RECTIFYING VALVE.
Maker/Donor: Made and presented by The Marconi-Osram Valve Co.
Date of creation: first in use in 1918.
Object entry information: This valve, which is exactly similar to type N.T.I (see No. 125) with grid omitted, was made to Admiralty specification, and was first in use in 1918. It is of the high vacuum type and has the following characteristics: Anode.—Nickel sheet bent to form a complete cylinder. Thickness, 0·2 mm.; length of cylinder, 45 mm.; internal diam., 27 mm. Filament.—Single loop of thoriated tungsten wire; total length, 120 mm.; diam., 0·195 mm. Filament P.D.—15 volts. Filament Current.—4·2 to 4·8 amps. Anode Dissipation.— 150 watts.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922-435.

Object name: TYPE N.U.2 RECTIFYING VALVE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Admiralty.
Date of creation: used during 1918.
Object entry information: This valve, of the high vacuum type, was made to Admiralty specification by the Edison-Swan Electric Co., Ltd., and used during 1918. It was designed by Lieut. Sleeman to suit a particular set of circuit requirements. Its characteristics are: Anode.—Nickel bent to a complete cylinder. Thickness about 0·2 mm., length of cylinder, 85 mm.; diam. of cylinder, 45 mm. Filament.—Single loop of pure or thoriated tungsten wire. Total length, 177 mm. (approx.), Diam., 0·250 mm. (approx.). Filament P.D.—18 volts. Filament Amps.— 6·2 amps. Anode dissipation.—450 watts.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-378.

Catalogue number: 125.
Object name: TYPE T.I. TRANSMITTING VALVE.
Maker/Donor: Made and presented by The Marconi-Osram Valve Co.
Date of creation: early part of 1917
Object entry information: This high vacuum type was one of the first valves constructed to Admiralty specification to be manufactured in quantities. It was evolved during the early part of 1917 by the donors after a short but intensive experimental period. The chief characteristics are: Anode.—Nickel sheet bent to form a complete cylinder. Thickness, 0·2 mm.; length of cylinder, 45 mm.; internal diam. of cylinder, 27 mm. Grid.—Helix of tungsten wire, 0·2 mm. in diam.; pitch, 2·6 turns per cm.; length, 55 mm.; diam., 10 mm. Filament.—Single loop of pure tungsten wire. Total length, 120 mm.; diam. 0·195 mm. Filament Volts.—13·2 volts. Filament Amps.—4·2 amps. Anode Dissipation.—150 watts.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922-432.

Catalogue number: 122.
Object name: POWER CONTROL VALVE, A.C.500.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Marconi-Osram Valve Co.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This valve was produced in collaboration with the Signals Experimental Establishment, Woolwich. By reason of its mechanical design the valve has a low internal impedance, and is capable of dissipating considerable power at the anode. The filament takes a current of 5·8 amps. at 17 volts, the emission current being half an ampere. The valve is capable of undergoing satisfactorily a dead loss test of 500 watts.

Round) was an early type designed with low inter-electrode capacitance, often used in a horizontal position or specific holders. Other examples include the Type T (co8373126, co8373127).

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 134.
Object name: WIRELESS TRANSMITTING TRIODE.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by The Mullard Radio Valve Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This type of tube, used for wireless transmission, has a bulb of pure silica. The high melting point of this material and its low coefficient of expansion enable it to be used without fear of collapse or fracture, although within 1 cm. of the sheet molybdenum anode, the working temperature of which is about 1,500 degs. absolute. The grid is constructed of helically wound tungsten wire supported on molybdenum rods. The filament is also of tungsten wire, kept taut by a helical spring of molybdenum. The triode is capable of dissipating 1 kw. at its anode and will deliver up to 3 kw. of high-frequency energy to the transmitting antenna. The anode supply voltage is 4,000 and upwards; the filament consumes 10 amps. at 14 volts.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922–730.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 135.
Object name: CURRENT LIMITER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Radio Research Board.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This consists of a short length of iron wire enclosed in hydrogen in a glass tube. When connected in series with the filament circuit of a thermionic valve it tends to keep the filament current steady. This is due to the fact that the resistance of iron wire increases as its temperature increases.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–112.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 136.
Object name: OSCILLATORY VALVE RELAY.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1918 (invented).
Object entry information: This relay, which combines remarkable sensitivity with unusual robustness, was invented by Capt. L. B. Turner in 1918. Its action depends upon the sudden rise of mean anode current in a triode under certain conditions when passing from the non-oscillating to the oscillating state. In its later developments it has enabled considerable progress to be made in the recording of high-speed wireless signals. Valve relays can be constructed for signals of either high or low frequency. The present example is for wireless signals of wave-lengths between 1,400 and 3,000 metres. A circuit of the type shown in the accompanying diagram is so adjusted that the arrival of a signal raises momentarily the grid potential of the triode sufficiently to start oscillation, and the resultant rise of anode current is used to trip an ordinary electro-magnetic relay. The grid potential is finely adjustable on the potentiometer P, and when it is set, a small amount called the “margin,” below the critical value called the “threshold,” any signal applied to the circuit producing in it a momentary E.M.F. of the right sense and exceeding the margin in amplitude, sets the system into oscillation. The accompanying rise of current in the coils of the relay pulls over the tongue T, short-circuiting the reaction coil and thereby quenching the oscillation, which is thereupon reignited only by the arrival of another signal. As long as the grid potential remains above the threshold value the tongue will chatter against the marking contact M, and by this means the signal can be made to actuate any recording device, such as a type-printing machine. It will be noticed that unlike other receivers the oscillatory valve relay embodies neither heterodyne nor separate detector. In the form in which it is shown here it is suitable for the reception of signals transmitted at speeds up to 40 or 50 words per minute.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–192.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 137.
Object name: SINGLE-VALVE AMPLIFIER, MARK I.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: First manufactured in 1916.
Object entry information: This early high-frequency amplifier was designed for use with a gas triode of the type evolved by Mr. H. J. Round in 1915. As shown in the diagram, provision is made for negative grid bias from one or two cells controlled by a switch.

Maker/Donor: Made and lent by The Mullard Radio Valve Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This type of tube, used for wireless transmission, has a bulb of pure silica. The high melting point of this material and its low coefficient of expansion enable it to be used without fear of collapse or fracture, although within 1 cm. of the sheet molybdenum anode, the working temperature of which is about 1,500 degs. absolute. The grid is constructed of helically wound tungsten wire supported on molybdenum rods. The filament is also of tungsten wire, kept taut by a helical spring of molybdenum. The triode is capable of dissipating 1 kw. at its anode and will deliver up to 3 kw. of high-frequency energy to the transmitting antenna. The anode supply voltage is 4,000 and upwards; the filament consumes 10 amps. at 14 volts.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922–730.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 135.
Object name: CURRENT LIMITER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Radio Research Board.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This consists of a short length of iron wire enclosed in hydrogen in a glass tube. When connected in series with the filament circuit of a thermionic valve it tends to keep the filament current steady. This is due to the fact that the resistance of iron wire increases as its temperature increases.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–112.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 136.
Object name: OSCILLATORY VALVE RELAY.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1918 (invented).
Object entry information: This relay, which combines remarkable sensitivity with unusual robustness, was invented by Capt. L. B. Turner in 1918. Its action depends upon the sudden rise of mean anode current in a triode under certain conditions when passing from the non-oscillating to the oscillating state. In its later developments it has enabled considerable progress to be made in the recording of high-speed wireless signals. Valve relays can be constructed for signals of either high or low frequency. The present example is for wireless signals of wave-lengths between 1,400 and 3,000 metres. A circuit of the type shown in the accompanying diagram is so adjusted that the arrival of a signal raises momentarily the grid potential of the triode sufficiently to start oscillation, and the resultant rise of anode current is used to trip an ordinary electro-magnetic relay. The grid potential is finely adjustable on the potentiometer P, and when it is set, a small amount called the “margin,” below the critical value called the “threshold,” any signal applied to the circuit producing in it a momentary E.M.F. of the right sense and exceeding the margin in amplitude, sets the system into oscillation. The accompanying rise of current in the coils of the relay pulls over the tongue T, short-circuiting the reaction coil and thereby quenching the oscillation, which is thereupon reignited only by the arrival of another signal. As long as the grid potential remains above the threshold value the tongue will chatter against the marking contact M, and by this means the signal can be made to actuate any recording device, such as a type-printing machine. It will be noticed that unlike other receivers the oscillatory valve relay embodies neither heterodyne nor separate detector. In the form in which it is shown here it is suitable for the reception of signals transmitted at speeds up to 40 or 50 words per minute.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–192.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Object entry information: This early high-frequency amplifier was designed for use with a gas triode of the type evolved by Mr. H. J. Round in 1915. As shown in the diagram, provision is made for negative grid bias from one or two cells controlled by a switch. and adjustable retroaction is included. Since the adjustments were critical, two separate valves were fitted, either of which could be selected for use. The input terminals of the amplifier are connected to the tuner in use. The retroaction coils are flat square spirals with hinged coupling.

title: Amplifier, valve Mk 1 No. 40
description: Amplifier, valve Mk 1 No. 40.  Probably First World War.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Object entry information: This interesting amplifier represents one of the earliest attempts to make use of the triode in wireless telegraphy. It was designed for field use by the Signals Experimental Establishment during the War of 1914–18, and utilised two soft valves, a " White " valve and an " Audion " of the type evolved by L. de Forest from the Fleming two-electrode valve. (See Nos. 29 and 73.) A diagram of connections is shown, from which it will be seen that the amplifier is for high frequencies. The use of separate batteries for each valve and of a choke coil as the intervalve coupling should be noted. The first valve is arranged for retroaction and the whole amplifier is intended to be worked in conjunction with the standard pattern of tuner in use at the time. (See No. 50.)

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 139.
Object name: C MARK II AMPLIFIER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is an early three-valve low-frequency amplifier designed during the War (1914–18) for the magnification of audio-frequency signals. It consists of the orthodox connections for such an amplifier with the addition of one joining the H.T. positive terminal to a point on the primary winding of the first transformer. This connection was introduced to stabilise the instrument, which tended to self-oscillation. The primary winding of this winding has six tappings to enable the impedance of this winding to be adjusted to suit the impedance of the circuit to which it is connected. The telephone receivers are connected in the anode circuit of the last valve through the medium of a telephone transformer. The right-hand switch is for the simultaneous adjustment of the filament currents of the three valves.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–267.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 140.
Object name: C MARK IV AMPLIFIER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a three-valve audio-frequency amplifier in which the first valve may alternatively be arranged as a detector. With the switch over to L.F. and the incoming leads connected to the terminals marked L.F., the circuit is that of an orthodox three-valve low-frequency amplifier. The primary of the first transformer is provided with tappings connected to a multiple contact switch, so that the ratio of transformation may be varied. The telephone receivers are connected to the plate circuit of the third valve through the medium of a telephone transformer. This set was designed for the magnification of:— (1) Earth current signals from power buzzers. (2) Signals of audible frequency from wireless sets. (3) L.F. signals from any other sources. With the switch over to H.F. and the incoming connections made at the H.F. terminals, the first transformer is cut out, the first valve being employed as a detector using anode current rectification by adjustment of the filament current. The second and third valves are independent of the filament rheostat, and perform L.F. amplification as before. The transformers in this amplifier were not designed for distortionless speech reproduction, but the apparatus is capable, nevertheless, of fairly efficient results when used for telephony reception.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–120.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 141.
Object name: FOUR-STAGE AMPLIFIER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a French resistance-capacity four-valve amplifier for radio frequencies. The signals are rectified by the cumulative grid method and are heard in the telephone receivers connected to the last triode through a transformer. The design of this amplifier is similar to that of the adjacent instrument, with the exception that the present one is for use with the original French triodes, and so is not suitable for wave-lengths shorter than a few hundred metres.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–26.

title: Three-valve low-frequency Amplifier C Mark II No. 1, 1917
description:
Three-valve low-frequency Amplifier C Mark II No. 1 from First World War - introduced in 1916/1917.  It consisted of the orthodox connections for such an amplifier with the addition of one joining the H.T. positive terminal to a point on the primary winding of the first transformer.  This connection was introduced to stabalise the instrument, which tended to self-oscillation.  The primary winding of the input transformer had six tappings to enable the impedance of this winding to be adjusted to suit impedance of the circuit to which it is connected.

The telephone receivers were connected in the anode circuit of the last valve through the medium of a telephone transformer.

The right-hand switch is for the simultaneous adjustment of the filament currents of the three valves.

The input connections were normally marked L1 and L2. It had two controls: a studded input impedance switch and a rheostat knob for filament voltage control.

The right-hand switch is for the simultaneous adjustment of the filament currents of the three valves.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–267.

Catalogue number: 140.
Object name: C MARK IV AMPLIFIER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a three-valve audio-frequency amplifier in which the first valve may alternatively be arranged as a detector. With the switch over to L.F. and the incoming leads connected to the terminals marked L.F., the circuit is that of an orthodox three-valve low-frequency amplifier. The primary of the first transformer is provided with tappings connected to a multiple contact switch, so that the ratio of transformation may be varied. The telephone receivers are connected to the plate circuit of the third valve through the medium of a telephone transformer. This set was designed for the magnification of:— (1) Earth current signals from power buzzers. (2) Signals of audible frequency from wireless sets. (3) L.F. signals from any other sources. With the switch over to H.F. and the incoming connections made at the H.F. terminals, the first transformer is cut out, the first valve being employed as a detector using anode current rectification by adjustment of the filament current. The second and third valves are independent of the filament rheostat, and perform L.F. amplification as before. The transformers in this amplifier were not designed for distortionless speech reproduction, but the apparatus is capable, nevertheless, of fairly efficient results when used for telephony reception.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–120.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 138.
Object name: EARLY TRIODE AMPLIFIER (MARK III**).
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: First manufactured in April, 1917.
Object entry information: This interesting amplifier represents one of the earliest attempts to make use of the triode in wireless telegraphy. It was designed for field use by the Signals Experimental Establishment during the War of 1914–18, and utilised two soft valves, a " White " valve and an " Audion " of the type evolved by L. de Forest from the Fleming two-electrode valve. (See Nos. 29 and 73.) A diagram of connections is shown, from which it will be seen that the amplifier is for high frequencies. The use of separate batteries for each valve and of a choke coil as the intervalve coupling should be noted. The first valve is arranged for retroaction and the whole amplifier is intended to be worked in conjunction with the standard pattern of tuner in use at the time. (See No. 50.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–168, S.M. 2165.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 139.
Object name: C MARK II AMPLIFIER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is an early three-valve low-frequency amplifier designed during the War (1914–18) for the magnification of audio-frequency signals. It consists of the orthodox connections for such an amplifier with the addition of one joining the H.T. positive terminal to a point on the primary winding of the first transformer. This connection was introduced to stabilise the instrument, which tended to self-oscillation. The primary winding of this winding has six tappings to enable the impedance of this winding to be adjusted to suit the impedance of the circuit to which it is connected. The telephone receivers are connected in the anode circuit of the last valve through the medium of a telephone transformer. The right-hand switch is for the simultaneous adjustment of the filament currents of the three valves.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–267.

title: LLM-LINKED
description: Listed as "French Amplifier with four horn type valves". This matches the description of a French four-valve amplifier. The note about "horn type valves" likely refers to the "original French triodes" mentioned in your query (often called 'R' type or similar with horns).

Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Object entry information:
In the type of resistance-capacity high-frequency amplifier shown at No. 141, the unavoidable capacity due to the triode and its connections between grid and anode may be of the order of 20 micro-microfarads or more. This capacity acts as a shunt condenser and seriously lowers the impedance of the resistance for high frequencies. For this reason amplifiers of that type are only suitable for comparatively long wave-lengths.
By the use of special anti-capacity valves and by exercising care in the amplifier connections it is possible to make an amplifier capable of working fairly efficiently on wave-lengths as low as 200. Such an amplifier is here shown.
It will be seen that the leading-in wires to the grid and anode of the valve are separated and brought in through separate seals. The practice is now common, but was first adopted by the French Military Service in this modification of their original general-purpose valve.
A milliammeter is inserted in the anode circuit of the last triode, and serves to indicate the presence of oscillations when the reaction condenser is properly adjusted for this purpose.

title: French Amplifier with four horn type valves
description: French Amplifier with 4 horn type valves (one broken) (Two valves reported as deficient and written off by Treasury authority). 19.1.1938.

Maker/Donor: Presented by The War Office.
Object entry information:
This German amplifier was used during the War, 1914–18. The chief point of interest lies in the use of iron wire current limiters in series with the triode filaments. They consist of coils of iron wire enclosed in hydrogen in a glass tube, the resistance of iron increases with temperature, so that slight variations of filament current due to fluctuations in battery voltage are checked.
The transformers have open iron cores and are shielded both magnetically and electrically by concentric cases of iron and brass. This can be seen in the example, which has been taken apart.
The switch connects the receiver, which was made by the Telefunken Company, with the telephones, either directly or through the amplifier.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 144.
Object name: COMBINED HIGH AND LOW-FREQUENCY DETECTOR-AMPLIFIER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In this amplifier, designed by the French Military Service, there are five stages of high-frequency amplification, one of detection and two stages of low-frequency amplification. The first five stages are resistance-capacity coupled, and the last two have iron-cored transformers.
For the purpose of obtaining high-frequency retroaction, as, for example, in the reception of continuous-wave signals, a special type of condenser, having one set of moving vanes and two sets of fixed vanes, is employed. By means of this condenser and a suitably connected switch, capacity can be introduced between any two of the electrodes in the high-frequency portion of the amplifier, and when these two electrodes are in antiphase reaction will occur.
This type of amplifier was used during the War of 1914–18 with frame antennæ for the reception of long wave stations. As is well known, the use of resistance-capacity coupling for high-frequency amplification necessitates special precautions if the instrument is to be used with wave-lengths of the order of 600 metres.
Such an amplifier is shown adjacently. (See No. 142.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–189.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 145.
Object name: MULTI-STAGE AMPLIFIER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: Evolved by the French Telegraph Administration during the War of 1914–18.
Object entry information: This amplifier was evolved by the French Telegraph Administration during the War of 1914–18. It is designed to give five stages of resistance-capacity coupled high-frequency amplification, detection and three stages of note magnification.
It should be noted that the case is lined with sheet metal. This precaution is necessary when it is desired to shield the amplifier from outside disturbances caused by other electrical apparatus, or where the amplifier is used for direction-finding work.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–191.

Catalogue number: 146.
Object name: TEST SET FOR LOW-FREQUENCY AMPLIFIERS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: Designed in 1918.
Object entry information: This set was designed in 1918 for the comparison of the “C, Mark III” amplifiers (the connections of which are identical with those of the C, Mark IV when used for low-frequency amplification) against an accepted standard. The apparatus consists of three parts :—
(a) A generator giving an acoustic signal of definite pitch.
(b) A coupling unit, by means of which the signal note heard in the amplifiers can be compared with the unamplified signal.
(c) An artificial earth circuit.

The Marconi amplifier, type 55 (co35544) is a multi-stage amplifier from 1918 but is British-made (though based on French designs).

Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Object entry information:
This set was designed in 1918 for the comparison of the “C, Mark III” amplifiers (the connections of which are identical with those of the C, Mark IV when used for low-frequency amplification) against an accepted standard. The apparatus consists of three parts :—
(a) A generator giving an acoustic signal of definite pitch.
(b) A coupling unit, by means of which the signal note heard in the amplifiers can be compared with the unamplified signal.
(c) An artificial earth circuit. A diagram of the apparatus is shown. The set was also used for comparing the low-frequency magnification of the "R" valve in these amplifiers, to the shaft of a Wilson motor, to the shaft of which is fitted an aluminium disc with 24 iron teeth. These teeth pass in front of the magnet of a telephone receiver, and the combination forms a small power alternator. The shaft of the motor is fitted with a speed indicator, so that the alternator can be run to give a definite note. On the same board is an electric bell magnet, the hammer of which makes and breaks a contact which short-circuits the telephone magnet coil, and so interrupts the alternator current periodically, thus producing a current consisting of a succession of dots. Across the contacts of the electric bell magnet circuit is a 4 mfd. condenser, which prevents the noise due to the spark from passing to the amplifier. Piece B. The Coupling Board.—This consists of two large coils, one of which can slide along a graduated bar, so that the coupling between the two can be varied. The current from the alternator passes through the fixed coil; the movable coil being connected to the dummy earth (piece c) which is connected to the amplifier to be tested. The energy transferred to the amplifier can thus be varied by altering the coupling. To the fixed coil is coupled a small coil whose position cannot be varied. A change-over switch, which operates by pressing and releasing, enables one to connect the telephone to this fixed coil on pressing, and to the telephone terminals of the amplifier under test on releasing. The fixed coil yields a constant comparison signal. When the 'phones are connected to the amplifier they are shunted with a resistance of 70 ohms, which enables a louder signal to be amplified and so reduces the relative intensity of amplifier noises with the signal. Piece C. The Dummy Earth.—This consists of a choke (the primary of a transformer) and a series of resistances. The signal from the movable coil of piece “B” passes through the choke, and through a resistance of 14,000 ohms, with tappings at 50, 200, 800 and 14,000 ohms. The lines to the amplifier are tapped across these resistances by means of the 5-stud switch. The choke keeps a resistance permanently in the "earth” circuit, the respective resistances being selected to suit the earth-to-valve transformer of the C, Mark III amplifier. It will be seen that the apparatus enables the amplified signal derived from an amplifier to be compared with a signal of fixed intensity which is approximately that of an amplifier of satisfactory performance. Since the amplification from any actual instrument is not very constant, the method is more satisfactory than that of obtaining a direct comparison.

Object entry information: anode may be of the order of 20 micro-microfarads or more. This capacity acts as a shunt condenser and seriously lowers the impedance of the resistance for high frequencies. For this reason amplifiers of that type are only suitable for comparatively long wave-lengths.
By the use of special anti-capacity valves and by exercising care in the amplifier connections it is possible to make an amplifier capable of working fairly efficiently on wave-lengths as low as 200. Such an amplifier is here shown.
It will be seen that the leading-in wires to the grid and anode of the valve are separated and brought in through separate seals. The practice is now common, but was first adopted by the French Military Service in this modification of their original general-purpose valve.
A milliammeter is inserted in the anode circuit of the last triode, and serves to indicate the presence of oscillations when the reaction condenser is properly adjusted for this purpose.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–190.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 143.
Object name: TWO-VALVE LOW-FREQUENCY AMPLIFIER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The War Office.
Date of creation: Used during the War, 1914–18.
Object entry information: This German amplifier was used during the War, 1914–18. The chief point of interest lies in the use of iron wire current limiters in series with the triode filaments. They consist of coils of iron wire enclosed in hydrogen in a glass tube, the resistance of iron increases with temperature, so that slight variations of filament current due to fluctuations in battery voltage are checked.
The transformers have open iron cores and are shielded both magnetically and electrically by concentric cases of iron and brass. This can be seen in the example, which has been taken apart.
The switch connects the receiver, which was made by the Telefunken Company, with the telephones, either directly or through the amplifier.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–24.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 144.
Object name: COMBINED HIGH AND LOW-FREQUENCY DETECTOR-AMPLIFIER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In this amplifier, designed by the French Military Service, there are five stages of high-frequency amplification, one of detection and two stages of low-frequency amplification. The first five stages are resistance-capacity coupled, and the last two have iron-cored transformers.
For the purpose of obtaining high-frequency retroaction, as, for example, in the reception of continuous-wave signals, a special type of condenser, having one set of moving vanes and two sets of fixed vanes, is employed. By means of this condenser and a suitably connected switch, capacity can be introduced between any two of the electrodes in the high-frequency portion of the amplifier, and when these two electrodes are in antiphase reaction will occur.
This type of amplifier was used during the War of 1914–18 with frame antennæ for the reception of long wave stations. As is well known, the use of resistance-capacity coupling for high-frequency amplification necessitates special precautions if the instrument is to be used with wave-lengths of the order of 600 metres.
Such an amplifier is shown adjacently. (See No. 142.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–189.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 145.
Object name: MULTI-STAGE AMPLIFIER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: Evolved by the French Telegraph Administration during the War of 1914–18.
Object entry information: This amplifier was evolved by the French Telegraph Administration during the War of 1914–18. It is designed to give five stages of resistance-capacity coupled high-frequency amplification, detection and three stages of note magnification.
It should be noted that the case is lined with sheet metal. This precaution is necessary when it is desired to shield the amplifier from outside disturbances caused by other electrical apparatus, or where the amplifier is used for direction-finding work.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–191.

Maker/Donor: Made and lent by Messrs. Radio Instruments, Ltd.
Object entry information: This is a transformer with primary tappings; used, in high-frequency amplification circuits, as a coupling device between successive amplifying valves. Since the strength of the rectified telephone signal varies as the square of the amplitude of the signal applied to the detector, it follows that an amplification of 10 times before rectification is equivalent in strength to one of 100 times after rectification. Against this must be set the relatively smaller amplification per stage which practical considerations have so far imposed on high-frequency versus low-frequency amplification, together with the difficulty which is generally experienced in suppressing undesired oscillatory currents caused by inter-electrode capacities in the valve. This transformer is designed for use on wave lengths of from 150 to 4,000 metres. No tuning condenser is employed, advantage being taken of the self capacity of the coil to obtain approximate tuning.
