Object entry information: This is a tapped coil for radio-frequency amplification with reactance capacity coupling. It consists of a single winding made up of a number of connected coils of very fine wire, insulated from each other by ebonite ribs. Maker/Donor: Made and lent by Igranic Electric Company.
Object entry information: In the design of inter-valve transformers for low-frequency amplification it is important that the self capacity of the windings be kept as low as possible. The specimen here shown is interwoven with cotton yarn between successive turns and layers. The use of cotton as an interspacing medium is an advantage as it has a low specific inductive capacity, while the wire is bound tightly together and cushioned by soft non-resonating material. Such a structure prevents vibration of the wires in the coils. Five manufacturing stages are shown:— A. Paper tube to be covered with cotton. B. Completion of primary winding. C. Covering of cotton. D. Washers fitted and coil impregnated with insulating material. E. Section of finished coil. There are 3,000 primary and 15,000 secondary turns.

Catalogue number: 150 and 151.
Object name: LOW-FREQUENCY INTER-VALVE TRANSFORMER.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by Radio Instruments, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is an example of the improved form of the standard transformer manufactured by this company for voltage amplification at audible frequencies. The coil bobbin is built up of special insulating material and the coils are each in six sections, this construction permitting a very low degree of self-capacity. The primary in this example consists of 3,000 turns of 42-gauge wire. The ratio of the primary and secondary coils is 4 to 1, the latter consisting of 12,000 turns of the same gauge wire. The primary and secondary inductances are respectively 10 and 150 henries; the self capacity being 18 m. mfd., and the amplification factor 31. The core is of stalloy iron, finely laminated with paper insulation. A curve showing the voltage amplification at frequencies between 200 and 4,000 p.p. sec., taken at the National Physical Laboratory, is shown adjacent.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–524 and 525.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 152.
Object name: HIGH-TENSION ACCUMULATOR.
Maker/Donor: Made and presented by The Chloride Electrical Storage Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a 24-volt accumulator battery of one ampere hour capacity for use in place of dry cells as a source of steady high-tension supply for small thermionic valves. The accumulator is of the lead acid type, the electrolyte being contained in glass tubes, of which there are twelve: a lead strip, bent to a U-shape, terminates as the positive of one cell, and at its other end as the negative of the adjacent cell. The cells are thus all connected in series, giving an approximately steady voltage during discharge of 24 volts. It is essential that the anode voltage of a valve should remain steady since the plate current varies as the 3/2nd power of this potential.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–291.

Maker/Donor: Made by the late Mr. W. Duddell. Lent by The Delegacy of the City and Guilds (Engineering) College.
Object entry information: This was constructed by the late Mr. W. Duddell in 1900 for the generation of high-frequency currents, in connection with his experiments on the resistance of the electric arc; it was one of the first high-frequency alternators to be designed. An electric motor (not shown) was used to drive the two large metal disc pulleys, which turn a laminated soft iron inductor disc by means of a cotton belt. This disc had V-shaped notches cut on its periphery, and revolved between the two inwardly projecting poles of a laminated soft iron ring. The latter is wound with an exciting circuit, and also an armature circuit in which the high-frequency alternating current was generated. Frequencies up to nearly 120,000 cycles per second were obtained by driving one of the inductor discs (which had 204 teeth) at a speed of 35,000 r.p.m. The output of the machine was about 0·1 ampere at 2 volts, giving about 3·6 volts on open circuit.

Catalogue number: 154.
Object name: PEDERSEN TIKKER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The London Telegraph Training College.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The tikker consists of a small contact maker in which a couple of thin wires are brought together and separated by a vibrating electro-magnetic arrangement. The instrument was widely used for the reception of continuous-wave signals before the invention of the thermionic valve. If a continuous train of undamped waves is emitted from the transmitting antenna, for example in the case of a morse dash signal, the use of a simple rectifying detector at the receiving station merely gives rise to clicks in the telephone receivers corresponding to the beginning and end of the train. The principle employed in the “ Tikker ” is that of interrupting the flow of current to the telephones at an acoustic frequency by means of the vibrating contact described above. The received signals then assume an audible musical note of the same frequency. The apparatus was principally employed in conjunction with the Poulsen arc.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–398, S.M. 2175.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 155.
Object name: POULSEN ARC.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The use of the arc to generate alternating currents was first investigated by W. Duddell in 1900, but it was not until 1903 that important modifications made by V. Poulsen led to the production of high-frequency oscillations of great power by this means. The modifications which he introduced were :— (1) The substitution of a water-cooled copper anode for the carbon anode previously used. (2) The use of a gas-tight arc chamber containing hydrogen. (3) The provision of a magnetic blast tending to drive the arc away from the electrodes. It was calculated that the aggregate power handled by arc transmitters in use throughout the world in 1923 was in the neighbourhood of 20,000 kw. The largest of these are capable of dealing with 1,000 kw. The arc here shown is an early example and would probably be rated at about 2 kw. The field winding is horizontal and is formed in two parts on either side of the arc chamber. The latter has been sectioned to show the interior.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–181.

title: LLM-LINKED
description: Listed as "Elwell Poulsen Arc generator" with the inventory number 1926-595. The Elwell-Poulsen system was the British version of the Poulsen arc used for generating high-frequency oscillations for radio transmission, matching the description of the apparatus used to generate alternating currents.

Maker/Donor: Assembled in the Museum Workshops.
Object entry information: This model is intended to show how a familiar phenomenon of general physics has been made use of in wireless telegraphy. When two musical sounds of slightly different pitch fall simultaneously on the ear, a regular throbbing is heard in the combined sound. These throbs are called “ beats,” and are utilised, for example, in the metropolitan police whistle. Similarly, two superposed oscillatory electromotive forces of supersonic frequency may be combined in one circuit to give a resultant current of differential frequency. If one of these electromotive forces is set up by a train of continuous frequency. waves of frequency N, and the other is due to a local source of frequency N', the resultant frequency will be (N–N'), and after rectification may be made audible in a telephone receiver. This “heterodyne” method of reception was invented by R. A. Fessenden in the United States in 1902, and is now almost universally employed in the reception of continuous waves. In the accompanying model, which may be operated with the controls provided, both frequencies have been brought within the audible range for demonstration purposes. One of the beats can be made by slowly turning the handle, and the beats can be made to cease owing to automatic synchronisation of the two oscillators caused by unavoidable coupling between them. In operating the model the triode filaments must first be switched on by means of the plunger. A diagram of connections is given, from which it will be seen that two triodes are associated with appropriate iron-core transformers and tuning condensers for the generation of two undamped oscillations of low frequency. These oscillations are combined in one circuit and are handed to a two-stage audio-frequency amplifier, the output of which is connected to a loud-speaking telephone.

Maker/Donor: Made by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company. Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Object entry information: This set is similar to the Marconi multiple tuner (see No. 48), and is interesting as having been designed to work with the early two-electrode valve of Prof. J. A. Fleming, F.R.S. With the switch in the “STD.BI” (stand-by) position, the antenna circuit includes a coil coupled to a closed circuit connected with the valve. When the switch is in the “tune” position a tuned intermediate circuit is interposed, giving heightened selectivity, since foreign oscillations and highly damped or aperiodic atmospheric disturbances act with diminishing force on the successive tuned circuits. A switch enables either of two valves to be used; a safety micrometer spark gap is connected between antenna and earth terminals.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 158.
Object name: TYPE W AIRCRAFT TRANSMITTER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: First manufactured in 1916.
Object entry information: This is a service transmitter to employ the “R” type triode. It consists of a simple tuned anode circuit with aperiodic grid coil. The approximate range of wavelengths was from 300 to 1,000 metres. The antenna consisted of a single trailing wire 250 ft. long. An artificial aerial was used for testing purposes.
Object/Inventory number: Inv 1924–167.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 159.
Object name: EARLY VALVE TUNER FOR AIRCRAFT.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: First manufactured in 1916.
Object entry information: This was the first valve receiver for use on aircraft. A “White” triode is employed with reaction for heterodyne purposes. Various combinations of inductances and condensers are given by the switches provided, but part of the antenna inductance is in all cases arranged with fixed electro-magnetic coupling on to the grid reaction coil. The grid potential is adjustable. All the inductances are of the basket type except the variometer, which has a rotary action.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–166.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 160.
Object name: CONTINUOUS - WAVE TRENCH SET, MARK I**.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: First manufactured in 1917.
Object entry information: The first continuous-wave sets for field use were made in 1916. They were designed in such a manner that a single triode with its appropriate circuits could be used to receive and to transmit. The principal difference in the Mark I** set was the provision of an alternative high-tension supply, which took the form of a “tuned vibratory transformer ” (T.V.T. unit), and proved so successful in practice that it was retained in subsequent sets, Mark II and Mark III. The latter is exhibited in this Collection. Theoretical diagrams are exhibited of the transmitting circuit with T.V.T. unit and of the receiving circuit. With regard to the latter, it should be noted that the antenna and earth connections are made to the tuned anode circuit of the valve. A dry-cell battery of 400 volts could be used in place of the high-tension unit when required.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–169.

The latter is exhibited in this Collection. Theoretical diagrams are exhibited of the transmitting circuit with T.V.T. unit and of the receiving circuit. With regard to the latter, it should be noted that the antenna and earth connections are made to the tuned anode circuit of the valve. A dry-cell battery of 400 volts could be used in place of the high-tension unit when required.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–169.

Object entry information: waves of frequency N, and the other is due to a local source of frequency N', the resultant frequency will be (N–N'), and after rectification may be made audible in a telephone receiver. This “heterodyne” method of reception was invented by R. A. Fessenden in the United States in 1902, and is now almost universally employed in the reception of continuous waves. In the accompanying model, which may be operated with the controls provided, both frequencies have been brought within the audible range for demonstration purposes. One of the beats can be made by slowly turning the handle, and the beats can be made to cease owing to automatic synchronisation of the two oscillators caused by unavoidable coupling between them. In operating the model the triode filaments must first be switched on by means of the plunger. A diagram of connections is given, from which it will be seen that two triodes are associated with appropriate iron-core transformers and tuning condensers for the generation of two undamped oscillations of low frequency. These oscillations are combined in one circuit and are handed to a two-stage audio-frequency amplifier, the output of which is connected to a loud-speaking telephone.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–543.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 157.
Object name: MARCONI VALVE RECEIVER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company. Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This set is similar to the Marconi multiple tuner (see No. 48), and is interesting as having been designed to work with the early two-electrode valve of Prof. J. A. Fleming, F.R.S. With the switch in the “STD.BI” (stand-by) position, the antenna circuit includes a coil coupled to a closed circuit connected with the valve. When the switch is in the “tune” position a tuned intermediate circuit is interposed, giving heightened selectivity, since foreign oscillations and highly damped or aperiodic atmospheric disturbances act with diminishing force on the successive tuned circuits. A switch enables either of two valves to be used; a safety micrometer spark gap is connected between antenna and earth terminals.
Object/Inventory number: Inv 1920–686.

description: Tuner Aircraft Valve Mk. 1 marked 'Tuner Aircraft No 9,' also known as one of the earliest valve tuner for aircraft, first made in 1916.  Very few were made - possibly as few as around 100 - with all sets made at the War Department Wireless Telegraphy factory at Teddington, Middlesex.  This particular set is a very early example as indicated by 'no. 9' and is also inscribed 'W/T factory W.D. Teddington S.W.'

maker: Wireless Telegraphy Factory; H W Sullivan Limited

Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Object entry information: This early single valve receiver, unlike some others which appeared at the time, has the antenna and earth connections to the grid circuit, and the circuit therefore presents a more modern appearance. A "Round" gas triode was used with an anode potential of 100 volts, and it will be noticed that an adjustable positive grid bias was provided. A simple buzzer wavemeter was included with the set.

Catalogue number: 162.
Object name: CONTINUOUS-WAVE TRENCH SET, MARK III.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a portable military set, designed for use in the forward area for ranges up to 4,000 yards, using a low single wire aerial, suspended at an average height of 3 ft. from the ground. The transmitting group consists of a transmitter Mark III*, a 30-watt high-tension unit and 10-volt, 16-amp. accumulator. The receiving group consists of a Receiver Mark III and selector. (a) *Transmitting Group.*—The transmitter consists essentially of a valve oscillator having tuned anode and grid circuits, and normally drawing its high-tension supply from a high tension unit, the action of which is controlled by the operating key. The folding operating key, aerial ammeter and tuning lamp are mounted on a metal panel and remain accessible when the cover is closed. High-tension current is supplied from a 30-watt induction coil, which takes 2.3 amps. at 10 volts from an accumulator and supplies 15-20 milliamperes at about 1,000 volts to the transmitting valves. The primary current for the H.T. unit and the heating current for the valve filaments are supplied by the same 10-volt accumulator, 6 volts being tapped off through a resistance for the latter purpose. On pressing the key this resistance is short-circuited, and the full 6 volts are applied to the filaments. A moment later the front stop of the key makes contact and closes the primary circuit of the H.T. unit, causing the latter to operate and supply high-tension current to the valves. The valve grid is connected with an aperiodic grid leak, consisting of a condenser of 0.001 mfd., shunted by a resistance of 6,000 ohms. The tuning of the aerial circuit is effected by means of an inductance tapped off to a 10-point switch, and fine tuning between the steps of the inductance is carried out by means of a spherical variometer coil. For longer wave-lengths, a fixed condenser is connected in parallel with the aerial tuning inductance, and this may be brought into circuit or cut out. The coupling between the aerial and anode circuits is varied by means of a reaction coil. A short and flexible lead named the "Anode Tap," the anodes can be connected with either the aerial end of the aerial-tuning inductance or some other point on this inductance. The change-over switch, which forms part of the transmitter, performs the following operations: in its "send" position it connects aerial and earth with the transmitting valve filament circuit, and disconnects the receiver from the low-tension battery; in its "off" position it connects the aerial, earth, and low-tension battery from the transmitter and receiver; in its "receive" position it connects aerial and earth with the receiver, closes the receiving valve filament circuit and opens the transmitting valve circuit.—In this instructional model the component parts of the continuous wave transmitter, Mark III, are mounted on a wooden baseboard. (c) The receiver is itself a valve oscillator and is so adjusted as to generate continuous oscillations of small amplitude, having a frequency slightly different to that of the incoming oscillations. As a result of this slight difference of frequency, "beats" of an audible frequency are produced. These pulses after being amplified by a second valve, arranged for low-frequency amplification, are applied to the head receivers and produce an audible signal. The 60-volt high-tension battery (not shown) fits within a cavity in the left-hand side of the case. The receiver may be used with or without a selector. If the selector is not in use, the aerial, earth and low-tension battery are connected with the receiver by means of the change-over switch. The current from the low-tension battery then flows through the two-valve filaments in parallel and is regulated by an adjustable series resistance. One end of the aerial and earth are connected with the aerial end of the inductance is connected through a fixed condenser, shunted by a resistance of 200,000 ohms, with the grid of the first

Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Object entry information: This is a portable military set, designed for use in the forward area for ranges up to 4,000 yards, using a low single wire aerial, suspended at an average height of 3 ft. from the ground. The transmitting group consists of a transmitter Mark III*, a 30-watt high-tension unit and 10-volt, 16-amp. accumulator. The receiving group consists of a Receiver Mark III and selector. (a) *Transmitting Group.*—The transmitter consists essentially of a valve oscillator having tuned anode and grid circuits, and normally drawing its high-tension supply from a high tension unit, the action of which is controlled by the operating key. The folding operating key, aerial ammeter and tuning lamp are mounted on a metal panel and remain accessible when the cover is closed. High-tension current is supplied from a 30-watt induction coil, which takes 2.3 amps. at 10 volts from an accumulator and supplies 15-20 milliamperes at about 1,000 volts to the transmitting valves. The primary current for the H.T. unit and the heating current for the valve filaments are supplied by the same 10-volt accumulator, 6 volts being tapped off through a resistance for the latter purpose. On pressing the key this resistance is short-circuited, and the full 6 volts are applied to the filaments. A moment later the front stop of the key makes contact and closes the primary circuit of the H.T. unit, causing the latter to operate and supply high-tension current to the valves. The valve grid is connected with an aperiodic grid leak, consisting of a condenser of 0.001 mfd., shunted by a resistance of 6,000 ohms. The tuning of the aerial circuit is effected by means of an inductance tapped off to a 10-point switch, and fine tuning between the steps of the inductance is carried out by means of a spherical variometer coil. For longer wave-lengths, a fixed condenser is connected in parallel with the aerial tuning inductance, and this may be brought into circuit or cut out. The coupling between the aerial and anode circuits is varied by means of a reaction coil. A short and flexible lead named the "Anode Tap," the anodes can be connected with either the aerial end of the aerial-tuning inductance or some other point on this inductance. The change-over switch, which forms part of the transmitter, performs the following operations: in its "send" position it connects aerial and earth with the transmitting valve filament circuit, and disconnects the receiver from the low-tension battery; in its "off" position it connects the aerial, earth, and low-tension battery from the transmitter and receiver; in its "receive" position it connects aerial and earth with the receiver, closes the receiving valve filament circuit and opens the transmitting valve circuit.—In this instructional model the component parts of the continuous wave transmitter, Mark III, are mounted on a wooden baseboard. (c) The receiver is itself a valve oscillator and is so adjusted as to generate continuous oscillations of small amplitude, having a frequency slightly different to that of the incoming oscillations. As a result of this slight difference of frequency, "beats" of an audible frequency are produced. These pulses after being amplified by a second valve, arranged for low-frequency amplification, are applied to the head receivers and produce an audible signal. The 60-volt high-tension battery (not shown) fits within a cavity in the left-hand side of the case. The receiver may be used with or without a selector. If the selector is not in use, the aerial, earth and low-tension battery are connected with the receiver by means of the change-over switch. The current from the low-tension battery then flows through the two-valve filaments in parallel and is regulated by an adjustable series resistance. One end of the aerial and earth are connected with the aerial end of the inductance is connected through a fixed condenser, shunted by a resistance of 200,000 ohms, with the grid of the first valve, the other end being connected with the negative side of the high-tension battery is connected with the positive valve filaments, high-tension positive being connected through the reaction coil, with the outside winding of inter-valve transformer and the junction of a shunt condenser is connected between filament negative and the junction coil with the primary winding of the inter-valve transformer, in order to provide a path for oscillating currents. High-tension positive is also connected through the high-resistance winding of the telephone transformer with the plate of the second (amplifying) valve, the grid of this valve being connected to the secondary winding of the inter-valve transformer with filament negative. The telephone sockets are connected in parallel across the primary of the telephone transformer. (d) Heterodyne Wave-meter.—This wave-meter has a range of wave-lengths from 400 metres to 3,000 metres, and is itself a generator of continuous waves with an oscillating circuit consisting of a reaction coil, variable condenser, and a "French" type valve. The inductance and reaction coils are carried in coil boxes, one of which is used for wave lengths of 400 metres to 1,400 metres and the other for wave lengths of 1,200 metres to 3,000 metres. The variable condenser is calibrated with two scales to suit whichever coil is used. Tuning is carried out by means of a variometer. To tune the meter it is necessary to rotate the variable condenser until a silent point is reached, on either side of which "beats" at high frequency can be heard. The wave-meter may be used to tune the receiver or transmitter to a definite wave-length or to measure the wave-lengths of received or transmitted waves. (e) Selector and Rectifier.—The selector and rectifier units are optional attachments. They were used separately or in combination to obtain greater freedom from interference. The selector consists of a pair of coils with variable electro-magnetic rotary coupling between them. One of these can be connected across the primary of the inter-valve transformer, and the other has a variable condenser across it and forms part of the receiver circuit. The receiving portion of the set is thereby converted into a two-circuit instrument. The rectifier unit is for converting the alternating high-tension voltage obtained from the vibratory unit into approximately pure D.C. One or, alternatively, two triodes are used in parallel, their grids being connected together and to one terminal of the alternating high-tension supply. The heated filament is connected to one side of a reservoir condenser, the other side of which is connected to the other terminal of the high-tension supply. Half-wave rectification only is obtained by this means, so that the output is not a steady D.C., and contains an undulating component of the same frequency as the source of unrectified voltage, and a considerable lessening of interference was accordingly obtained by the use of this apparatus.

The change-over switch, which forms part of the transmitter, performs the following operations: in its "send" position it connects aerial and earth with the transmitting valve filament circuit, and disconnects the receiver from the low-tension battery; in its "off" position it connects the aerial, earth, and low-tension battery from the transmitter and receiver; in its "receive" position it connects aerial and earth with the receiver, closes the receiving valve filament circuit and opens the transmitting valve circuit.—In this instructional model the component parts of the continuous wave transmitter, Mark III, are mounted on a wooden baseboard. (c) The receiver is itself a valve oscillator and is so adjusted as to generate continuous oscillations of small amplitude, having a frequency slightly different to that of the incoming oscillations. As a result of this slight difference of frequency, "beats" of an audible frequency are produced. These pulses after being amplified by a second valve, arranged for low-frequency amplification, are applied to the head receivers and produce an audible signal. The 60-volt high-tension battery (not shown) fits within a cavity in the left-hand side of the case. The receiver may be used with or without a selector. If the selector is not in use, the aerial, earth and low-tension battery are connected with the receiver by means of the change-over switch. The current from the low-tension battery then flows through the two-valve filaments in parallel and is regulated by an adjustable series resistance. One end of the aerial and earth are connected with the aerial end of the inductance is connected through a fixed condenser, shunted by a resistance of 200,000 ohms, with the grid of the first valve, the other end being connected with the negative side of the high-tension battery is connected with the positive valve filaments, high-tension positive being connected through the reaction coil, with the outside winding of inter-valve transformer and the junction of a shunt condenser is connected between filament negative and the junction coil with the primary winding of the inter-valve transformer, in order to provide a path for oscillating currents. High-tension positive is also connected through the high-resistance winding of the telephone transformer with the plate of the second (amplifying) valve, the grid of this valve being connected to the secondary winding of the inter-valve transformer with filament negative. The telephone sockets are connected in parallel across the primary of the telephone transformer. (d) Heterodyne Wave-meter.—This wave-meter has a range of wave-lengths from 400 metres to 3,000 metres, and is itself a generator of continuous waves with an oscillating circuit consisting of a reaction coil, variable condenser, and a "French" type valve. The inductance and reaction coils are carried in coil boxes, one of which is used for wave lengths of 400 metres to 1,400 metres and the other for wave lengths of 1,200 metres to 3,000 metres. The variable condenser is calibrated with two scales to suit whichever coil is used. Tuning is carried out by means of a variometer. To tune the meter it is necessary to rotate the variable condenser until a silent point is reached, on either side of which "beats" at high frequency can be heard. The wave-meter may be used to tune the receiver or transmitter to a definite wave-length or to measure the wave-lengths of received or transmitted waves. (e) Selector and Rectifier.—The selector and rectifier units are optional attachments. They were used separately or in combination to obtain greater freedom from interference. The selector consists of a pair of coils with variable electro-magnetic rotary coupling between them. One of these can be connected across the primary of the inter-valve transformer, and the other has a variable condenser across it and forms part of the receiver circuit. The receiving portion of the set is thereby converted into a two-circuit instrument. The rectifier unit is for converting the alternating high-tension voltage obtained from the vibratory unit into approximately pure D.C. One or, alternatively, two triodes are used in parallel, their grids being connected together and to one terminal of the alternating high-tension supply. The heated filament is connected to one side of a reservoir condenser, the other side of which is connected to the other terminal of the high-tension supply. Half-wave rectification only is obtained by this means, so that the output is not a steady D.C., and contains an undulating component of the same frequency as the source of unrectified voltage, and a considerable lessening of interference was accordingly obtained by the use of this apparatus.

Object name: HETERODYNE RECEIVER, MARK II.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: First manufactured in 1916.
Object entry information: This early single valve receiver, unlike some others which appeared at the time, has the antenna and earth connections to the grid circuit, and the circuit therefore presents a more modern appearance. A "Round" gas triode was used with an anode potential of 100 volts, and it will be noticed that an adjustable positive grid bias was provided. A simple buzzer wavemeter was included with the set.

Object entry information: This is a portable military set, designed for use in the forward area for ranges up to 4,000 yards, using a low single wire aerial, suspended at an average height of 3 ft. from the ground. The transmitting group consists of a transmitter Mark III*, a 30-watt high-tension unit and 10-volt, 16-amp. accumulator. The receiving group consists of a Receiver Mark III and selector. (a) *Transmitting Group.*—The transmitter consists essentially of a valve oscillator having tuned anode and grid circuits, and normally drawing its high-tension supply from a high tension unit, the action of which is controlled by the operating key. The folding operating key, aerial ammeter and tuning lamp are mounted on a metal panel and remain accessible when the cover is closed. High-tension current is supplied from a 30-watt induction coil, which takes 2.3 amps. at 10 volts from an accumulator and supplies 15-20 milliamperes at about 1,000 volts to the transmitting valves. The primary current for the H.T. unit and the heating current for the valve filaments are supplied by the same 10-volt accumulator, 6 volts being tapped off through a resistance for the latter purpose. On pressing the key this resistance is short-circuited, and the full 6 volts are applied to the filaments. A moment later the front stop of the key makes contact and closes the primary circuit of the H.T. unit, causing the latter to operate and supply high-tension current to the valves. The valve grid is connected with an aperiodic grid leak, consisting of a condenser of 0.001 mfd., shunted by a resistance of 6,000 ohms. The tuning of the aerial circuit is effected by means of an inductance tapped off to a 10-point switch, and fine tuning between the steps of the inductance is carried out by means of a spherical variometer coil. For longer wave-lengths, a fixed condenser is connected in parallel with the aerial tuning inductance, and this may be brought into circuit or cut out. The coupling between the aerial and anode circuits is varied by means of a reaction coil. Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: Designed during the War of 1914–18 to meet the demand for apparatus with low transmitting power to minimise jamming, and was first manufactured in 1919.
Object entry information:
This set was designed during the War of 1914–18 to meet the demand for apparatus with low transmitting power to minimise jamming, and was first manufactured in 1919. For this purpose a more sensitive receiver than usual was used, consisting of three stages of semi-tuned high-frequency amplification, a separate heterodyne, and a three-valve detector-amplifier. The set was troublesome to handle, chiefly owing to instability in the high-frequency stages, but ranges of ten miles with aerials 15 ft. high were obtained, and this at the time was satisfactory. With aerials 48 ft. high 100 miles was easily obtained. The set consists of a very simple transmitter of pure C.W., a highly selective tuner, and the amplifiers already described. The transmitter has an untuned grid circuit, and is fed either from a generator or from dry cells. Fine tuning between the studs of the A.T.I. switch is obtained by means of a variometer. The coils are wound with 9/40 stranded silk-covered wire. The tuner has two circuits with variable coupling between them. The coils all consist of three-layer step windings, and tuning is carried out by variable condensers connected across these windings. The tuner carries also a send receive switch. The high-frequency amplifier transformers are wound for 2,000 metres to 5,000 metres, primary and secondary windings, being interleaved in the grooves in the ebonite bobbin. Control of grid current is given by a potentiometer.
The other amplifier is of the standard "Mark IV" pattern, described elsewhere in this collection. The heterodyne unit is also a standard instrument. (See "Heterodyne Wave-meter, No. 162 (d.).)

Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Object entry information:
This receiver is similar in general principle to that of the semi-portable 120-watt set. Two circuits are used, the secondary consisting either of a tuned circuit or of an aperiodic coil for quick searching, according to the position of a switch.
The detector and amplifier unit used with this receiver is not shown here, but an example will be found in the amplifier section (C. IV Amplifier). A heterodyne circuit is incorporated in the receiver, and this was used as a wave-meter to tune the transmitter and receiver in addition to its normal function in the reception of continuous-wave signals.
The coupling between the antenna and closed circuits is of the variable withdrawal type. The use of a grid condenser and leak of an acoustic time-period for receiver tuning is described in the label which accompanies the 120-watt field set. (See No. 165.)

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 165.
Object name: SEMI-PORTABLE FIELD WIRELESS STATION. Plate 10.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This interesting set was designed by the Army Signals Experimental Establishment in 1918 for continuous-wave transmission and reception in place of the light motor quenched gap spark set which preceded it. Rated at 120 watts input, the range of these sets was about 200 miles with a safety factor of 2.
Although not wholly satisfactory, either as regards efficiency or reliability, they represented a distinct advance on previous sets, much ingenuity being shown in the detailed design of the several units as well as in the general lay out.
Power for operating the set was drawn from non-spillable accumulators of 90 ampere-hours capacity. These, together with the set and the aerial equipment, consisting of two 48-ft. masts in sections and a twin aerial of length 300 ft. were carried in a light motor van which also served as office accommodation when the station was erected.
The transmitting apparatus on the left consists of a rotary converter fed from the accumulators and delivering alternating current at 40 volts, 900 cycles. This passes through an auto-transformer with tappings (seen in front of the transmitter) to control the power.
The voltage is now stepped up to 1,400, and is either fed direct to the two transmitting valves ("Tonic Train") or is first passed through the double-wave rectifier on the right of the transmitter, in which case approximately pure C.W. will be transmitted. The range of wave-lengths is from 600 metres to 2,500 metres.
The receiver (on the right) is of the two-circuit type, the secondary winding being provided with tappings which make it aperiodic when the switch is in the "stand by" position. Following the example of the Telefunken Company, this secondary coil is movable about two axes at right angles, so that a very loose coupling can be obtained.
A separate calibrated heterodyne circuit is incorporated in the receiver, and this can be used to tune both transmitter and receiver. For this purpose it is provided with a galvanometer and coupling coil to the transmitter so that resonance therewith may be indicated by the rise in grid current in the heterodyne circuit. A switch enables the operator to include in the grid circuit a condenser and leak resistance whose time period is of audible frequency, and when this is done the receiver can be tuned as from an ordinary buzzer wavemeter.
Detection and note magnification is carried out by means of a separate three-valve detector-amplifier.
A convenient switchboard enables the batteries to be rapidly tested, and the wiring is in all cases carried out by through lengths without joints, all connections or tappings being made at the instrument or switchboard terminals. The whole case is closed by drawing down a roller shutter for protection of the instruments. For transit this is further protected by a canvas-covered panel.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-177, S.M. 2157.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 168.
Object name: BURNDEPT TUNER AND AMPLIFIER-DETECTOR.
Maker/Donor: Messrs. Burndept, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These two instruments together form a selective four-valve receiver, in which the first valve operates at radio frequency, the second valve acts as rectifier and the last two valves as audio frequency amplifiers. The switches are arranged to allow of the rectifying valve being used alone, or the radio frequency valve being added when required, and further, of either or both the audio frequency valves being added. The radio frequency valve is coupled to the rectifier by the reactance-capacity method; the reactance consists of a coil tapped at twelve points and controlled by a switch in order that the wave-lengths between approximately equal at all wave-lengths between 200 metres and 20,000 metres. The instrument is designed for hard valves of the original "French" type, and the grid of the radio frequency valve is maintained at a slightly positive potential to secure stability, variation of that potential being effected by moving the filament rheostat of the first valve. The audio frequency valves have their grids biased negative and are transformer-coupled. The tuner comprises an aerial or "stand-by" circuit with a switch and an adjustable reaction control. Fixed inductance coils of the plug-in type are used, controlled by a switch, and adjustable reaction control. The backs of the two panels have been removed and replaced by glass in order to display the wiring, and the method of winding the inductance coils may also be seen. Four aerial tuning coils, suitable for broadcast reception wave-lengths and nine coils suitable for general reception of longer wave-lengths are shown adjacent, one being sectioned to show the method of winding to secure reduced self capacity. (See also Exhibit No. 209.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–421–422–423–424.

Catalogue number: 168.
Object name: BURNDEPT TUNER AND AMPLIFIER-DETECTOR.
Maker/Donor: Messrs. Burndept, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These two instruments together form a selective four-valve receiver, in which the first valve operates at radio frequency, the second valve acts as rectifier and the last two valves as audio frequency amplifiers. The switches are arranged to allow of the rectifying valve being used alone, or the radio frequency valve being added when required, and further, of either or both the audio frequency valves being added. The radio frequency valve is coupled to the rectifier by the reactance-capacity method; the reactance consists of a coil tapped at twelve points and controlled by a switch in order that the wave-lengths between approximately equal at all wave-lengths between 200 metres and 20,000 metres. The instrument is designed for hard valves of the original "French" type, and the grid of the radio frequency valve is maintained at a slightly positive potential to secure stability, variation of that potential being effected by moving the filament rheostat of the first valve. The audio frequency valves have their grids biased negative and are transformer-coupled. The tuner comprises an aerial or "stand-by" circuit with a switch and an adjustable reaction control. Fixed inductance coils of the plug-in type are used, controlled by a switch, and adjustable reaction control. The backs of the two panels have been removed and replaced by glass in order to display the wiring, and the method of winding the inductance coils may also be seen. Four aerial tuning coils, suitable for broadcast reception wave-lengths and nine coils suitable for general reception of longer wave-lengths are shown adjacent, one being sectioned to show the method of winding to secure reduced self capacity. (See also Exhibit No. 209.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–421–422–423–424.

Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Object entry information:
In the early days of radio-telephony, modulation was usually carried out by inserting a microphone directly in the antenna circuit. Since the microphones used in line telephony were only capable of handling a few watts without overheating, many attempts were made to provide others which could deal with heavy currents.
One such specially designed microphone is here exhibited, and was used by Capt. H. J. Round for radio-telephony experiments in 1910.
The problem of handling these large antenna currents was finally met, first by the magnetic amplifier of E. F. W. Alexanderson, and later by the introduction of thermionic methods of control, in which the microphone influences the antenna output through the medium of a chain of amplifying triodes.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 170.
Object name: EARLY RADIO-TELEPHONE ARC TRANSMITTER. Plate II.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Date of creation: 1910
Object entry information: Although the value of the discovery made by V. Poulsen in 1902, that the Duddell musical arc could be so modified as to make it suitable for wireless transmission, was immediately recognised, it was not until 1905 that the first experimental transmission were made. Some years later Dr. Lee de Forest applied the Poulsen principle to the construction of a number of small radio-telephone installations which were used in the United States Navy. The early design here shown was evolved by Capt. H. J. Round for the Marconi Company in 1910.
The usual arrangements for burning the arc in an atmosphere of hydrocarbons will be noticed, together with the provision of clockwork as a means of rotating the anode, thereby improving the steadiness of burning.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-170, S.M. 2176.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 171.
Object name: RADIO-TELEPHONE SET.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1914–18
Object entry information: This is a combined transmitter and receiver for radio-telephony. It is of early date, having been designed by the French Telegraph Administration during the War of 1914–18.
The set is designed to work with triodes of the original French pattern, three of these being used in parallel for transmission and three others in cascade for reception. The transmitting voltage was 300.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-21.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 172.
Object name: FIELD WIRELESS TELEPHONE SET.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1919
Object entry information: This interesting set, which was intended for trench warfare use, but which was never issued in quantity, was designed by Capt. L. B. Turner for the unusually low wave-length of 50 metres.
It consists of two units. One of these, the upper "unit," contains the transmitting and receiving triodes and their appropriate oscillatory circuits, and when in use is situated close to the antenna. The "lower unit" contains the necessary control apparatus and can be placed anywhere within reasonable distance of these, being connected to the upper unit by a multicore rubber cable.
The high-tension current for transmission is derived from the hand generator or from a battery of dry cells. The transmitter, which is of the choke-control type, has a fixed tuned anode circuit with an aperiodic grid coil. Coupled to these circuits, which are used for reception as well as for transmission, is the antenna circuit which is tuned by means of a semi-adjustable condenser. On account of the low wave-length, and of certain peculiarly troublesome interaction effects which were encountered, the designer found it necessary to insert a coupling condenser of one micro-microfarad capacity between the antenna and closed circuits.
Object/Inventory number: N/A.

Round (co8702308) are also listed, covering his work on radio direction finding and echo sounding.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Object entry information:
This interesting set, which was intended for trench warfare use, but which was never issued in quantity, was designed by Capt. L. B. Turner for the unusually low wave-length of 50 metres.
It consists of two units. One of these, the upper "unit," contains the transmitting and receiving triodes and their appropriate oscillatory circuits, and when in use is situated close to the antenna. The "lower unit" contains the necessary control apparatus and can be placed anywhere within reasonable distance of these, being connected to the upper unit by a multicore rubber cable.
The high-tension current for transmission is derived from the hand generator or from a battery of dry cells. The transmitter, which is of the choke-control type, has a fixed tuned anode circuit with an aperiodic grid coil. Coupled to these circuits, which are used for reception as well as for transmission, is the antenna circuit which is tuned by means of a semi-adjustable condenser. On account of the low wave-length, and of certain peculiarly troublesome interaction effects which were encountered, the designer found it necessary to insert a coupling condenser of one micro-microfarad capacity between the antenna and closed circuits. The amplifier-detector comprises three stages of transformer-coupled high-frequency amplification, a detector triode utilising simple anode rectification, and two stages of low-frequency amplification. The anode potentials of all six triodes, and the grid potentials of the second and third stages, are finely adjust-able by means of potentiometers. The standard antenna equipment con-sisted of a single 40-ft. wire suspended between two 4-ft. masts, and following the usual practice, the “ earth ” connection was made to a 4-ft. mat of copper gauze laid on the ground.
With such a low antenna and so short a wave-length, the screening effect of obstacles was naturally serious, but the range between a pair of these stations was seldom less than two miles, while in the open country six miles was by no means unusual.

Object entry information: This is a combined transmitter and receiver for radio-telephony. It is of early date, having been designed by the French Telegraph Administration during the War of 1914–18.
The set is designed to work with triodes of the original French pattern, three of these being used in parallel for transmission and three others in cascade for reception. The transmitting voltage was 300.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-21.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 172.
Object name: FIELD WIRELESS TELEPHONE SET.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: 1919
Object entry information: This interesting set, which was intended for trench warfare use, but which was never issued in quantity, was designed by Capt. L. B. Turner for the unusually low wave-length of 50 metres.
It consists of two units. One of these, the upper "unit," contains the transmitting and receiving triodes and their appropriate oscillatory circuits, and when in use is situated close to the antenna. The "lower unit" contains the necessary control apparatus and can be placed anywhere within reasonable distance of these, being connected to the upper unit by a multicore rubber cable.
The high-tension current for transmission is derived from the hand generator or from a battery of dry cells. The transmitter, which is of the choke-control type, has a fixed tuned anode circuit with an aperiodic grid coil. Coupled to these circuits, which are used for reception as well as for transmission, is the antenna circuit which is tuned by means of a semi-adjustable condenser. On account of the low wave-length, and of certain peculiarly troublesome interaction effects which were encountered, the designer found it necessary to insert a coupling condenser of one micro-microfarad capacity between the antenna and closed circuits.
Object/Inventory number: N/A.

Maker/Donor: Made and lent by The Western Electric Company.
Object entry information:
This microphone is used for broadcasting, and in conjunction with special amplifiers and loud-speaking telephone apparatus to enable a speaker without raising his voice to address large public gatherings. By making use of trunk telephone lines, several such gatherings in different towns have been simul-taneously addressed by the same person.
In the case of the Public Address System developed by the Western Electric Company, the apparatus employed comprises a microphone—such as the one exhibited, to pick up the sound of the speaker's voice—a vacuum-tube amplifying arrangement, and one or more loud-speaking telephones to distribute the amplified speech-sounds. Each portion is designed so as to be as nearly distor-tionless as possible over the range of frequencies which constitute speech.
The microphone, is of a type known as the “ push-pull ” type, having two variable resistance elements, one on each side of the diaphragm. The latter is an air-damped steel disc, tensioned so as to have a natural frequency of about 8,000 periods per second. Owing to this high natural frequency and to the fact that it is damped, it responds uniformly to all the frequencies (200–4,000) which occur in normal speech. The two carbon buttons have each a resistance of 100 ohms and are connected in series, the electrical path being from the rear carbon electrode in each case through the carbon granules to a gold-plated area on the diaphragm itself. This double-button construction almost completely eliminates the distortion caused by the non-linear nature of the pressure-resistance characteristics of granular carbon. The microphone is suspended by springs to avoid vibration, and can pick up speech from a distance of five or six feet. On account of its special construction, however, its sensitivity is only about 1/1,000th that of the ordinary telephone transmitter, and this necessitates additional amplification. No horn is fitted to the microphone, as this would introduce resonance and consequent lack of uniformity of behaviour to all frequencies.
The complete system (of which the microphone is only a representative portion) has given remarkable results. On November 11th, 1921, speeches made at Arlington, Virginia, were heard by 100,000 persons there and simultaneously by 35,000 in New York and by 20,000 in San Francisco, telephone trunk lines being used in conjunction with the system.

Catalogue number: N/A
Object name: N/A
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The amplifier-detector comprises three stages of transformer-coupled high-frequency amplification, a detector triode utilising simple anode rectification, and two stages of low-frequency amplification. The anode potentials of all six triodes, and the grid potentials of the second and third stages, are finely adjust-able by means of potentiometers. The standard antenna equipment con-sisted of a single 40-ft. wire suspended between two 4-ft. masts, and following the usual practice, the “ earth ” connection was made to a 4-ft. mat of copper gauze laid on the ground.
With such a low antenna and so short a wave-length, the screening effect of obstacles was naturally serious, but the range between a pair of these stations was seldom less than two miles, while in the open country six miles was by no means unusual.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-175.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 174.
Object name: EXPERIMENTAL BROADCASTING MICROPHONES
Maker/Donor: Lent by The British Broadcasting Co.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The distortion caused by the familiar “ multiple-contact ” microphone used in commercial telephone systems renders this microphone unsuitable, without serious modification, for the wireless transmission of music.
In seeking to develop a type of microphone which should be as free from distortion as possible, the British Broadcasting Company took as their starting point the original form designed by Graham Bell in 1876. (See Telephony Section.)
In this instrument the vibrations of a circular diaphragm cause variations in the number of lines of force which thread a coil of wire wound over a magnet, so that alternating currents are set up in the coil, corresponding to the pitch, amplitude, and timbre of the sound.
Two examples of these experimental microphones are shown; they were used in the first London Broadcasting Studio in the early part of 1923, after the carbon microphone had been discarded.
Two or three of these Bell telephone microphones, having diaphragms of different thicknesses, and therefore different natural periods, were used in con-junction with one another in order to avoid distortion.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Lent by The British Broadcasting Co.
Object entry information:
The distortion caused by the familiar “ multiple-contact ” microphone used in commercial telephone systems renders this microphone unsuitable, without serious modification, for the wireless transmission of music.
In seeking to develop a type of microphone which should be as free from distortion as possible, the British Broadcasting Company took as their starting point the original form designed by Graham Bell in 1876. (See Telephony Section.)
In this instrument the vibrations of a circular diaphragm cause variations in the number of lines of force which thread a coil of wire wound over a magnet, so that alternating currents are set up in the coil, corresponding to the pitch, amplitude, and timbre of the sound.
Two examples of these experimental microphones are shown; they were used in the first London Broadcasting Studio in the early part of 1923, after the carbon microphone had been discarded.
Two or three of these Bell telephone microphones, having diaphragms of different thicknesses, and therefore different natural periods, were used in con-junction with one another in order to avoid distortion. It will also be noted that arrangements were provided for damping the diaphragms mechanically by means of adjustable rubber feet. The subsequent development of broadcasting microphones of this type is described adjacently. (See No. 175.)

title: LLM-LINKED
description: The specific set of "Two or three of these Bell telephone microphones" mounted together for the first London Broadcasting Studio does not appear in the provided source text. Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi’s Wireless Telegraph Company.
Object entry information: This is the original Sykes microphone for broadcasting. From this instrument an improved form was developed by Capt. H. J. Round, of the Marconi Company, and was standardized for use in the London and other broadcasting stations in 1923. The Sykes microphone resembles the Bell form in that electro-magnetic reactions are utilised for the production of speech currents, but differs therefrom in the following particulars :— (a) An extremely heavy magnetic field is obtained by the use of a large electro-magnet. (b) An extremely light flat spiral coil is used as the moving element. This coil is suspended in the annular air gap of the electro-magnet, and alternating currents of acoustic frequency are set up in this coil by its own to-and-fro movement caused by acoustic vibration. The whole microphone is mounted in a rubber sling to insulate it from extraneous mechanical shock.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 176.
Object name: CRYSTAL RECEIVER.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by The British Thomson-Houston Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The oscillatory currents which are set up in a conductor by the passage of a group of electric waves are incapable of creating an audible sound in an ordinary telephone receiver on account of the frequency, which is too high. By means of a rectifying detector applied to a resonant circuit, however, the telephone receiver may be made responsive to any modulations which are taking place in the waves. These modulations may be introduced at the transmitting station for the purpose of conveying either telephonic or telegraphic signals, and the detector may take several forms. Only two, however, are now in common use, and of these the crystal detector is the simpler, though not the more sensitive. It has been used in various forms for over 16 years, and is very suitable for the reception of wireless telephony over a range of a few miles. The present receiver has been specially designed for this purpose. The receiver consists essentially of a variometer and condenser which can be connected either in series or in parallel by means of a switch ; when attached to an aerial and an earth connection it can be tuned to wave-lengths between 300 and 600 metres. Across this circuit are joined one of two alternative silicon detectors and a pair of telephone receivers. The latter are shunted by a small condenser in order to provide a path for the high-frequency component of the current. When a sensitive point has been found on one of the crystals and the circuit has been brought into resonance with the frequency of current set up by the arriving waves, an oscillating voltage is set up across the terminals of the detector, which owing to thermo-electric and other effects offers more resistance to currents in one direction than in the other. There then flows through the telephones a resultant current whose mean value is not zero and which causes them to give out a sound corresponding to any low-frequency modulations that have been introduced at the transmitter. A diagram of the connections is placed beside the instrument.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-592 and 593.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 177.
Object name: ARISTOPHONE.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by Messrs. C. F. Elwell.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a self-contained wireless receiver for telephony and spark signals transmitted on wave-lengths between 300 and 900 metres. Either one, two or three stages of low-frequency amplification can be obtained by inserting the telephone plug in the appropriate jack. The transformers are interwound with silk and are shrouded in iron to prevent interaction.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-429.

Catalogue number: 175.
Object name: SYKES MICROPHONE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi’s Wireless Telegraph Company.
Date of creation: N/A (Standardized in 1923)
Object entry information: This is the original Sykes microphone for broadcasting. From this instrument an improved form was developed by Capt. H. J. Round, of the Marconi Company, and was standardized for use in the London and other broadcasting stations in 1923. The Sykes microphone resembles the Bell form in that electro-magnetic reactions are utilised for the production of speech currents, but differs therefrom in the following particulars :— (a) An extremely heavy magnetic field is obtained by the use of a large electro-magnet. (b) An extremely light flat spiral coil is used as the moving element. This coil is suspended in the annular air gap of the electro-magnet, and alternating currents of acoustic frequency are set up in this coil by its own to-and-fro movement caused by acoustic vibration. The whole microphone is mounted in a rubber sling to insulate it from extraneous mechanical shock.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-540.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 176.
Object name: CRYSTAL RECEIVER.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by The British Thomson-Houston Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The oscillatory currents which are set up in a conductor by the passage of a group of electric waves are incapable of creating an audible sound in an ordinary telephone receiver on account of the frequency, which is too high. By means of a rectifying detector applied to a resonant circuit, however, the telephone receiver may be made responsive to any modulations which are taking place in the waves. These modulations may be introduced at the transmitting station for the purpose of conveying either telephonic or telegraphic signals, and the detector may take several forms. Only two, however, are now in common use, and of these the crystal detector is the simpler, though not the more sensitive. It has been used in various forms for over 16 years, and is very suitable for the reception of wireless telephony over a range of a few miles. The present receiver has been specially designed for this purpose. The receiver consists essentially of a variometer and condenser which can be connected either in series or in parallel by means of a switch ; when attached to an aerial and an earth connection it can be tuned to wave-lengths between 300 and 600 metres. Across this circuit are joined one of two alternative silicon detectors and a pair of telephone receivers. The latter are shunted by a small condenser in order to provide a path for the high-frequency component of the current. When a sensitive point has been found on one of the crystals and the circuit has been brought into resonance with the frequency of current set up by the arriving waves, an oscillating voltage is set up across the terminals of the detector, which owing to thermo-electric and other effects offers more resistance to currents in one direction than in the other. There then flows through the telephones a resultant current whose mean value is not zero and which causes them to give out a sound corresponding to any low-frequency modulations that have been introduced at the transmitter. A diagram of the connections is placed beside the instrument.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-592 and 593.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 177.
Object name: ARISTOPHONE.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by Messrs. C. F. Elwell.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a self-contained wireless receiver for telephony and spark signals transmitted on wave-lengths between 300 and 900 metres. Either one, two or three stages of low-frequency amplification can be obtained by inserting the telephone plug in the appropriate jack. The transformers are interwound with silk and are shrouded in iron to prevent interaction.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-429.

Maker/Donor: Invented by M. Bellini. Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Object entry information: This is an experimental radio-goniometer used by the inventor, M. Bellini, for directive wireless transmission. The British patent for this system, which has been very widely employed, was filed by Messrs Bellini & Tosi in 1907. In this system a pair of nearly closed triangular coils are fixed at right angles, and coils capable of being inserted in their lower portions, also at right angles. A third coil, which is missing from this original model, is placed close to, and within, the other two coils just mentioned, and forms part of the closed transmitting circuit. This third coil is capable of being rotated so as to be parallel with either of the fixed coils, or else occupy some intermediate position. It is found that the maximum intensity of radiation from the pair of antennæ is greatest in the direction of the plane of the primary inducing coil. The complementary apparatus for directional reception is identical with that described above, except that receiving and not transmitting apparatus is connected to the primary coil, which in this case is called the " search" coil. There are two other methods of radio-telegraphic direction finding which are widely employed at the present time; one of them is described under No. 181.

Object name: EARLY COMMERCIAL DIRECTION FINDER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Ducretet, Paris, and lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Date of creation: 1907.
Object entry information: This direction-finding apparatus was manufactured in 1907, the year in which Messrs. Bellini & Tosi filed their British patent for the system. The apparatus embodies the principles describing their first experimental radio-goniometer (No. 179.).
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–499.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 181.
Object name: EARLY COIL DIRECTION FINDER.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by The National Physical Laboratory.
Date of creation: 1916.
Object entry information: This coil, which was designed in 1916, is believed to be the first direction finder to have been taken into the air. Experiments with it were successfully carried out on aircraft in 1917 and the method was immediately adopted by the Air Ministry. Similar experiments carried out on board ship proved equally successful and form the foundation of the development of the present day direction finder. The general principle of the method of determining the direction of an incoming wireless signal by means of a rotating closed coil may be briefly described as follows:— A flat rectangular coil is suspended with its plane vertical in such a manner that it is capable of rotating about a vertical axis. The coil is connected to a tuning condenser to form a closed oscillatory circuit, and leads from the condenser are taken to the usual form of detecting receiver. When the circuit is tuned to the frequency of the incoming electro-magnetic waves, an oscillatory current is induced of sufficient strength under favourable circumstances to give audible signals in the telephone receiver. The magnitude of this current is dependent upon the angle between the axis of the coil and the direction of the transmitting station. A simple consideration of the magnetic field associated with the incoming waves shows that when the axis of the coil points towards the transmitting station, the intensity of the received waves is a minimum. By rotating the coil, therefore, the minimum position, and hence the direction of the arriving waves can be determined. There is with the type of frame under consideration an ambiguity of 180°, since no indication is given as to whether the bearing of the transmitting station is (x) or (x + 180°), but this ambiguity is removed where direction-finding stations work in pairs on the ground.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–606.
title: LLM-LINKED

Maker/Donor: Made by The American Radio and Research Corporation. Presented by Sanders Brothers.
Object entry information: This alternating current rectifier operates by gaseous conduction in helium between cold electrodes. There is no filament, and the tube is capable of handling 100 m.A. at 1,000 volts, with a working life of 3,000 hours and upwards. The tube in the form here shown was developed by the American Radio & Research Corporation in the spring of 1923. The cathode, which consists of a hollow carbon cup, is held in position by means of a spring clip. The anode, formed of a small carbon button, is placed opposite a hole in the cathode. By means of shields all paths between anode and cathode, except that through the hole, are made shorter than the mean free path of ions at the gas pressure employed, so that conduction along these paths is not possible. Considering the behaviour of the tube when an alternating potential is applied, during the half cycles when the hollow electrode is negative the tube conducts, and the space between the electrodes becomes filled with a cloud of positive ions and electrons. Positive ions dropping from the cloud on to the inner surface of the hollow cathode liberate electrons. These proceed towards the anode and on their way ionize neutral gas molecules to form new positive ions, so that the discharge is maintained. The original electrons and those formed by ionization nearly all pass out sooner or later through the hole in the cathode, and thus reach the anode, which is solid. They do this rapidly and easily owing to their mobility, which allows them to speed up more quickly than the heavy positive ions, so conduction in this direction occurs with facility. For the reverse direction the solid electrode is the cathode, and positive ions under this condition will wander out from the hollow space through the holes and impinge on the solid electrode. Progress is slow, for they are large and heavy, and the gradient of the field up inside the cloud is weak, consequently conduction is very small in this reverse direction. Thus the tube acts as a rectifier. For a fuller description of this most interesting device see “Journal of the American Institution of Electrical Engineers,” Vol. 41, 1922.
Raw_Response:

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 183.
Object name: ADJUSTABLE DISC CONDENSERS.
Maker/Donor: Made by Marconi’s Wireless Telegraph Company. Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The need for continuously variable condensers for tuning purposes was early experienced by wireless engineers. The type here shown is still in common use, and is particularly suitable for cases where a compact condenser of large capacity is required for receiving purposes. It has two sets of semicircular movable plates on one shaft, and corresponding to these, two sets of fixed plates. Thin ebonite sheets are interposed between these plates as the dielectric, and by oppositely connecting sets of fixed and moving plates the capacity is variable from a low value to about 11,000 micro-microfarads.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–216.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 184.
Object name: VARIABLE CONDENSER.
Maker/Donor: Made and presented by The Dubilier Condenser Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is an air condenser having a maximum capacity of 1,000 micro-micro-farads. Connection is made to the moving plates through a flexible phosphor-bronze strip. The capacity of an air condenser is proportional to the number of pairs of opposing plates and to the reciprocal of the distance between them. In order to obtain a compact condenser, therefore, it is necessary to preserve the minimum clearance between the plates, and this in turn necessitates accurate construction.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–425.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 185.
Object name: MICA CONDENSER.
Maker/Donor: Made and presented by The Dubilier Condenser Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a 10,000-volt, 10-ampere condenser of 0.00055 microfarads capacity. The impregnating wax has been removed to show the construction. It will be seen that the non-earthy terminal of the condenser is connected to the mid-point of the plates, so placing the two halves in parallel. Each half is composed of a number of sections separated by mica sheets, and each section contains between 40 and 50 tinfoil plates.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–390.

Maker/Donor: Made by The American Radio and Research Corporation. Presented by Sanders Brothers.
Date of creation: 1923
Object entry information: This alternating current rectifier operates by gaseous conduction in helium between cold electrodes. There is no filament, and the tube is capable of handling 100 m.A. at 1,000 volts, with a working life of 3,000 hours and upwards. The tube in the form here shown was developed by the American Radio & Research Corporation in the spring of 1923. The cathode, which consists of a hollow carbon cup, is held in position by means of a spring clip. The anode, formed of a small carbon button, is placed opposite a hole in the cathode. By means of shields all paths between anode and cathode, except that through the hole, are made shorter than the mean free path of ions at the gas pressure employed, so that conduction along these paths is not possible. Considering the behaviour of the tube when an alternating potential is applied, during the half cycles when the hollow electrode is negative the tube conducts, and the space between the electrodes becomes filled with a cloud of positive ions and electrons. Positive ions dropping from the cloud on to the inner surface of the hollow cathode liberate electrons. These proceed towards the anode and on their way ionize neutral gas molecules to form new positive ions, so that the discharge is maintained. The original electrons and those formed by ionization nearly all pass out sooner or later through the hole in the cathode, and thus reach the anode, which is solid. They do this rapidly and easily owing to their mobility, which allows them to speed up more quickly than the heavy positive ions, so conduction in this direction occurs with facility. For the reverse direction the solid electrode is the cathode, and positive ions under this condition will wander out from the hollow space through the holes and impinge on the solid electrode. Progress is slow, for they are large and heavy, and the gradient of the field up inside the cloud is weak, consequently conduction is very small in this reverse direction. Thus the tube acts as a rectifier. For a fuller description of this most interesting device see “Journal of the American Institution of Electrical Engineers,” Vol. 41, 1922.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–526.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 183.
Object name: ADJUSTABLE DISC CONDENSERS.
Maker/Donor: Made by Marconi’s Wireless Telegraph Company. Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The need for continuously variable condensers for tuning purposes was early experienced by wireless engineers. The type here shown is still in common use, and is particularly suitable for cases where a compact condenser of large capacity is required for receiving purposes. It has two sets of semicircular movable plates on one shaft, and corresponding to these, two sets of fixed plates. Thin ebonite sheets are interposed between these plates as the dielectric, and by oppositely connecting sets of fixed and moving plates the capacity is variable from a low value to about 11,000 micro-microfarads.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–216.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 184.
Object name: VARIABLE CONDENSER.
Maker/Donor: Made and presented by The Dubilier Condenser Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is an air condenser having a maximum capacity of 1,000 micro-micro-farads. Connection is made to the moving plates through a flexible phosphor-bronze strip. The capacity of an air condenser is proportional to the number of pairs of opposing plates and to the reciprocal of the distance between them. In order to obtain a compact condenser, therefore, it is necessary to preserve the minimum clearance between the plates, and this in turn necessitates accurate construction.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–425.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 185.
Object name: MICA CONDENSER.
Maker/Donor: Made and presented by The Dubilier Condenser Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a 10,000-volt, 10-ampere condenser of 0.00055 microfarads capacity. The impregnating wax has been removed to show the construction. It will be seen that the non-earthy terminal of the condenser is connected to the mid-point of the plates, so placing the two halves in parallel. Each half is composed of a number of sections separated by mica sheets, and each section contains between 40 and 50 tinfoil plates.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–390.

description: No variable air condenser made by Dubilier matching the description (1,000 micro-micro-farads, phosphor-bronze strip) appears in the sources. Date of creation: N/A
