Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–391.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 189
Object name: “POLAR” VARIABLE CONDENSERS.
Maker/Donor: The Radio Communication Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Two specimens of this type of variable condenser are shown. One of them has been taken apart in order to display the action. The use of mica in a variable condenser makes for compactness, since the specific inductive capacity of mica is roughly seven times that of air, and it is upon this that the capacity of two opposing surfaces of given area depends. The condenser plates, of which there are two, consist of sheets of copper foil mounted on resilient material and separated by sheets of mica. The condenser plates are always kept parallel and are urged apart by means of tongues bent out from a springy metal sheet inserted between the plates. By rotating the knob attached to the spindle the support of the lower plate is urged away from or towards the upper plate by virtue of the screw thread cut on the spindle.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–48 and 49.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 190
Object name: ELEMENT OF HIGH POWER CONDENSER.
Maker/Donor: The Dubilier Condenser Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The condenser, of which an experimental element and photographs are shown, was built for the Government medium-power arc station at Northolt. All the radial elements are connected in parallel by means of peripheral plates and a central busbar. Partly owing to this symmetrical construction, which equalises the load, there were no measurable losses in this condenser. The method of construction adopted enables the non-earthy terminal of the condenser to remain without special insulating precautions, since the necessary insulation is afforded by the dielectric itself.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–392.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 191
Object name: SCREENING SET.
Maker/Donor: The Western Electric Company. Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: During the War of 1914–18 it was found that the development of valve amplifiers made it possible to overhear telephone conversations or buzzer signals at distances of as much as two or three thousand yards from the line on which the signals were passing. This was effected by picking up the minute earth or induction currents, or both, on special circuits laid out in “no man’s land,” and then passing them through audio-frequency amplifiers. In order to prevent overhearing by the enemy, buzzer screening circuits of the type exhibited were laid out in an unbroken line along the front, their purpose being to set up vigorous audio-frequency currents in the earth which should create in enemy listening apparatus loud continuous or intermittent buzzing sounds through which the signals or conversations could not be read. The arrangement proved highly successful in practice, though the impossibility of obtaining definite information of its efficacy in any given case made it necessary to take other precautions as well.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Object name: ELEMENT OF HIGH POWER CONDENSER.
Maker/Donor: The Dubilier Condenser Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The condenser, of which an experimental element and photographs are shown, was built for the Government medium-power arc station at Northolt. All the radial elements are connected in parallel by means of peripheral plates and a central busbar. Partly owing to this symmetrical construction, which equalises the load, there were no measurable losses in this condenser. The method of construction adopted enables the non-earthy terminal of the condenser to remain without special insulating precautions, since the necessary insulation is afforded by the dielectric itself.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–392.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 191
Object name: SCREENING SET.
Maker/Donor: The Western Electric Company. Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: During the War of 1914–18 it was found that the development of valve amplifiers made it possible to overhear telephone conversations or buzzer signals at distances of as much as two or three thousand yards from the line on which the signals were passing. This was effected by picking up the minute earth or induction currents, or both, on special circuits laid out in “no man’s land,” and then passing them through audio-frequency amplifiers. In order to prevent overhearing by the enemy, buzzer screening circuits of the type exhibited were laid out in an unbroken line along the front, their purpose being to set up vigorous audio-frequency currents in the earth which should create in enemy listening apparatus loud continuous or intermittent buzzing sounds through which the signals or conversations could not be read. The arrangement proved highly successful in practice, though the impossibility of obtaining definite information of its efficacy in any given case made it necessary to take other precautions as well.
Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: Element of a Dubilier mica condenser
description: Element of a Dubilier mica condenser for high power radio stations

Maker/Donor: The Western Electric Company. Lent by The War Office.
Object entry information: During the War of 1914–18 it was found that the development of valve amplifiers made it possible to overhear telephone conversations or buzzer signals at distances of as much as two or three thousand yards from the line on which the signals were passing. This was effected by picking up the minute earth or induction currents, or both, on special circuits laid out in “no man’s land,” and then passing them through audio-frequency amplifiers. In order to prevent overhearing by the enemy, buzzer screening circuits of the type exhibited were laid out in an unbroken line along the front, their purpose being to set up vigorous audio-frequency currents in the earth which should create in enemy listening apparatus loud continuous or intermittent buzzing sounds through which the signals or conversations could not be read. The arrangement proved highly successful in practice, though the impossibility of obtaining definite information of its efficacy in any given case made it necessary to take other precautions as well. In this particular type of screening instrument a polarised buzzer of the pattern used in the "D III" telephone is made to give out two audio-frequency currents of different pitch. A separate interrupter armature plays between two contacts and sends these currents alternately to earth connections. Any stray signal currents picked up by hostile listening sets were then drowned by the bi-tonal accompaniment from the screening currents.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 189
Object name: “POLAR” VARIABLE CONDENSERS.
Maker/Donor: The Radio Communication Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Two specimens of this type of variable condenser are shown. One of them has been taken apart in order to display the action. The use of mica in a variable condenser makes for compactness, since the specific inductive capacity of mica is roughly seven times that of air, and it is upon this that the capacity of two opposing surfaces of given area depends. The condenser plates, of which there are two, consist of sheets of copper foil mounted on resilient material and separated by sheets of mica. The condenser plates are always kept parallel and are urged apart by means of tongues bent out from a springy metal sheet inserted between the plates. By rotating the knob attached to the spindle the support of the lower plate is urged away from or towards the upper plate by virtue of the screw thread cut on the spindle.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–48 and 49.

Maker/Donor: Lent by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Object entry information: The elimination of atmospheric disturbances and of signals of undesired frequencies is a problem which has troubled wireless engineers at all times. Partial solutions have been offered by almost every inventor, but up to the present time the difficulty has not been surmounted. The instrument which is here shown is probably the earliest attempt at atmospheric and interference elimination. It proved remarkably successful in the circumstances in which it was employed. It was developed particularly for use at Babylon shore station, near New York, in 1904, where jamming from other stations was very severe, and its use was found to enable this station to transact messages with ship stations which had previously been impossible. The apparatus, which was used by Marconi in conjunction with his magnetic detector (see No. 33), consists essentially of three acceptor circuits arranged in series. (In this instance the circuits are arranged for tune "A" reception on 60 metres wave-length.) Earth connections are taken to each of the three inductances at tapping points which are nodes of potential at this wave-length; hence they do not take energy from the receiving circuit. When signals of the desired frequency are received they are able to actuate the detector in the ordinary way, but if disturbances of any other frequency arrive they do not go through the receiver circuit, but pass to earth at the nodal tapping points.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 193.
Object name: POWER BUZZERS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Four power buzzers of different makes are shown. One is of French design, one is a British instrument, and the remaining two are of German make. The object of all such instruments is to provide a means of signalling between two points without any intervening wire or conventional wireless link. (See "Buzzer-Amplifier Set," No. 194.) Apart from the interest arising from their development and use in the War of 1914–18, it is worthy of notice that many experimenters from 1846 onwards have taken advantage of the conductivity of the soil in order to transmit messages. It was natural that with the exalted sensitivity conferred on receivers by the invention of the thermionic valve the same measures should again be resorted to in time of war, in cases where aerials would be too conspicuous and cables destroyed by shell-fire. 1. The Parleur power buzzer was designed for the French Military Service. It is a spark induction coil of special design, taking primary current at a pressure of from 10 to 20 volts. The laminated armature nearly closes the V-shaped gap between the poles of the core, the air space being only about 0.25 mm. The armature is bolted to a stiff steel spring which carries one of the interrupter contacts on a thin projecting plate. The mechanical frequency of the interruptions is determined by the stiffness and inertia of the spring, and is arranged to be some 800 periods per second. The interrupter contacts are shunted by a 4-mfd. condenser. If the resistance of the earth connections is 200 ohms the secondary current is 0.2 amperes with 20 watts input. 2. The British design is similar to the foregoing. It was provided with three alternative armatures having frequencies of 640, 730 and 540 periods per second. 3. This German power buzzer has an oscillating armature arranged so that an alternating voltage is induced in the secondary winding and not a pulsating voltage as in the previous examples. A small incandescent lamp serves as a rough indication of the secondary earth current. 4. This is a more elaborate German instrument with two alternative buzzers, a safety fuse, and a switch to regulate the power.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-12, 20, 23 and 171.

title: Lamp and buzzer set combination, in case, by Siebt
description: Lamp and buzzer set combination, in case, by Siebt

Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Object entry information:
This set is designed for sending and receiving signals by means of vibrating currents sent through the earth. It is mainly intended as a subsidiary means of communication when aerials are inadmissible or have been destroyed by barrage, and has a range from 2,000 yards to 5,000 yards according to the nature of the earth connections and sub-soil.
The set includes a buzzer for transmission and a three-valve amplifier C, Mark III, for reception. Earth pins are placed at either end of a base about six yards length and these are connected with two spring clip terminals on a six-line commutator. Three different bases may be connected with the com- mutator and the desired base connected to either the buzzer or amplifier by means of a change-over switch. The buzzer consists essentially of an induction coil, the armature of which vibrates at a definite frequency. Current is supplied to the primary winding from a 10-volt battery, and when the transmitting key is pressed, the armature vibrates and a high-tension vibrating current is sent to earth via the change-over switch and commutator. Three interchangeable armatures having different periods of vibration are provided. A condenser is connected across the break to reduce sparking.
The three-valve amplifier is carried together with its high-tension battery (not shown) in the left-hand compartment of the case. The signals received pass through the commutator and change-over switch (set to “receive”) and enter the primary of the “earth to valve transformer.” The secondary of this trans- former connects the grid of the first valve to the negative limb of the valve filament through a dry cell, so that the grid is kept at a small negative potential with respect to the filament. This permits only a small current to pass in the grid filament circuit and the valves work under conditions such that the current between grid and filament is small and constant for small changes in grid volts.
The amplified signal from the first valve passes through the primary of an “inter- valve transformer,” whose secondary forms the grid and filament circuit of the second valve, through the dry cell. Similarly the amplified signal from the three-times amplified signal passes through a “valve to 'phone transformer” to the telephones.
The valves used are of the French R or A types.

title: LLM-LINKED
description: The specific set containing the "three-valve amplifier C, Mark III" does not appear. However, related components for earth current signalling appear, such as the Power buzzer (co33141). Additionally, variations of the amplifier component appear: the Three-valve low-frequency Amplifier C Mark II (co34903) and the Three-valve L.F. Amplifier C Mk IV (co34904).

Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Object entry information:
It is well known that in order to radiate powerfully electro-magnetic waves from an open antenna it must either be earthed or else connected with some form of metallic network possessing capacity to earth. In the construction of large permanent radio-telegraphic stations these earthing or balance capacity systems receive very careful attention, and months may be spent on their installation.
In the case of portable field stations, however, where the time taken in erecting the station may be limited to a few minutes only, it has been found that the best results are obtained by the use of mats made of woven copper wire. These are simply laid flat on the ground and exercise a dual function, since in dry weather they act chiefly as a counterpoise, while in wet weather they make a reasonably efficient earth connection.
The mats vary in length from 4 ft. to 14 ft., and as many as six of them are occasionally used together.

Catalogue number: 196.
Object name: POULSEN TELEGRAPHONE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument was invented by V. Poulsen. It consists of a long steel wire which, in process of recording, is wound off one drum on to another and passes under an electro-magnet. The current through this magnet is made to vary in sympathy with the sounds to be recorded.
In this manner the wire assumes a state of permanent magnetization, forming a magnetic record of the impressed sounds.
When it is desired to reproduce this record the wire is again run beneath the poles of the electro-magnet and a reproduction of the original sounds is heard in telephone receivers connected to the windings of the magnet.
The record remains stored in the form of magnetic flux for an indefinite time, but can be obliterated when desired by passing the wire through a strong mag- netic field.
The instrument has been used for recording wireless signals and it seems likely that the system may again come into favour for various purposes. The example shown is incomplete and in a damaged condition.
The visitor is referred to No. 29 (magnetic detector) for comparison, where telegraph signals are produced by magnetization and demagnetization of a soft iron wire which is being slowly carried through a magnetic cycle.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–188.

Object entry information: of communication when aerials are inadmissible or have been destroyed by barrage, and has a range from 2,000 yards to 5,000 yards according to the nature of the earth connections and sub-soil.
The set includes a buzzer for transmission and a three-valve amplifier C, Mark III, for reception. Earth pins are placed at either end of a base about six yards length and these are connected with two spring clip terminals on a six-line commutator. Three different bases may be connected with the com- mutator and the desired base connected to either the buzzer or amplifier by means of a change-over switch. The buzzer consists essentially of an induction coil, the armature of which vibrates at a definite frequency. Current is supplied to the primary winding from a 10-volt battery, and when the transmitting key is pressed, the armature vibrates and a high-tension vibrating current is sent to earth via the change-over switch and commutator. Three interchangeable armatures having different periods of vibration are provided. A condenser is connected across the break to reduce sparking.
The three-valve amplifier is carried together with its high-tension battery (not shown) in the left-hand compartment of the case. The signals received pass through the commutator and change-over switch (set to “receive”) and enter the primary of the “earth to valve transformer.” The secondary of this trans- former connects the grid of the first valve to the negative limb of the valve filament through a dry cell, so that the grid is kept at a small negative potential with respect to the filament. This permits only a small current to pass in the grid filament circuit and the valves work under conditions such that the current between grid and filament is small and constant for small changes in grid volts.
The amplified signal from the first valve passes through the primary of an “inter- valve transformer,” whose secondary forms the grid and filament circuit of the second valve, through the dry cell. Similarly the amplified signal from the three-times amplified signal passes through a “valve to 'phone transformer” to the telephones.
The valves used are of the French R or A types.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–119.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 195.
Object name: EARTH MAT.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: It is well known that in order to radiate powerfully electro-magnetic waves from an open antenna it must either be earthed or else connected with some form of metallic network possessing capacity to earth. In the construction of large permanent radio-telegraphic stations these earthing or balance capacity systems receive very careful attention, and months may be spent on their installation.
In the case of portable field stations, however, where the time taken in erecting the station may be limited to a few minutes only, it has been found that the best results are obtained by the use of mats made of woven copper wire. These are simply laid flat on the ground and exercise a dual function, since in dry weather they act chiefly as a counterpoise, while in wet weather they make a reasonably efficient earth connection.
The mats vary in length from 4 ft. to 14 ft., and as many as six of them are occasionally used together.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–184.

Object entry information: These instruments are for use in measuring small alternating currents of high frequency without introducing into the circuit any appreciable disturbance due to capacity or inductance. The alternating current passes through a heater, near to which is placed a fine thermo-junction, and the rise of temperature due to the current is indicated on a sensitive moving-coil galvanometer.

Catalogue number: 198.
Object name: AUTOMATIC MORSE TRANSMITTER FOR AIRCRAFT.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: The apparatus was not developed until some time after the termination of the War of 1914–18, and has never been used in warfare.
Object entry information: This apparatus was designed by Mr. F. S. S. Wates to afford a means whereby untrained persons, and particularly aircraft pilots and mechanics, could transmit Morse signals. For each message a pre-established code of four letters is provided. In order to transmit one of these messages the operator places the plug in the appropriate jack and depresses the lever. A commutator drum is caused to rotate by clock-work, and the interruption of the line current by the selected series of commutator segments effects the transmission of the sender's call signal, and of the code letters, four times in succession for each operation of the instrument. A special S.O.S. attachment is provided, permitting the user to send continuous S.O.S. signals by pulling a catch out. The apparatus was not developed until some time after the termination of the War of 1914–18, and has never been used in warfare.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-196.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 199.
Object name: "WIRED WIRELESS" SETS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: Designed by Capt. H. P. T. Lefroy, R.E. in 1915.
Object entry information: These sets were designed by Capt. H. P. T. Lefroy, R.E. The term "wired wireless" has been used to describe a system of multiplex electrical communication based on the use of one or more high-frequency carrier currents which are transmitted along wires or cables in the form of telegraph or telephone signals. Although some of the principles underlying such a system were already known it was not until 1910 that General G. O. Squier, of the United States Army, pointed out the practicable possibilities and described experiments made with high-frequency alternators. He also constructed portable buzzer-operated sets for field use, but, owing to the large attenuation constant inherent in the wave length used, 1,100 metres, the range of these sets was not great. Following on preliminary experiments in 1914, Capt. Lefroy, in 1915, designed for the British Army Signal Service a series of "wired wireless" sets working at four different frequencies which could be operated simultaneously on a normal telephone line, thus providing four extra channels of high-frequency communication. Two of these sets, which were used at the battle of Loos, are exhibited. They contain fundamental improvements, in that adjustments of the carrier frequency are effected independently of the line constants; while the frequencies are so chosen that a reduction in attenuation corresponding to a tenfold increase of range is obtained. A value of coupling was chosen to give the greatest strength of signals compatible with absence of interference from other sources. The later developments of carrier-current telegraphy and telephony for non-military use have been very rapid, chiefly owing to the use of triodes, and to progress in the design of filter circuits for separating the various high-frequency currents; thus, in April, 1923, there were in operation, between Pittsburgh and Chicago, 128 full duplex channels of communication, based on three carrier-current circuits. The four sets designed were given frequencies corresponding to wave lengths of 4,000, 8,000, 16,000 and 32,000 metres, and were known as A, B, C and D sets respectively, of which the B and C sets are shown. The range of the D set on a single open wire was 40 miles. From the diagram it will be seen that a closed oscillatory circuit, energised by a battery and vibrator, is inductively coupled to an acceptor circuit which is connected to the line and earth. This acceptor circuit is known as a "tuned link," and it is important to notice that in operation it is permanently tuned to the same frequency as the closed circuit, regardless of the line constants. The same oscillatory circuits are used, both for transmission and reception, the necessary connections being made by means of contacts on the signalling key.

Date of creation: Designed by Capt. H. P. T. Lefroy, R.E. in 1915.
Object entry information: These sets were designed by Capt. H. P. T. Lefroy, R.E. The term "wired wireless" has been used to describe a system of multiplex electrical communication based on the use of one or more high-frequency carrier currents which are transmitted along wires or cables in the form of telegraph or telephone signals. Although some of the principles underlying such a system were already known it was not until 1910 that General G. O. Squier, of the United States Army, pointed out the practicable possibilities and described experiments made with high-frequency alternators. He also constructed portable buzzer-operated sets for field use, but, owing to the large attenuation constant inherent in the wave length used, 1,100 metres, the range of these sets was not great. Following on preliminary experiments in 1914, Capt. Lefroy, in 1915, designed for the British Army Signal Service a series of "wired wireless" sets working at four different frequencies which could be operated simultaneously on a normal telephone line, thus providing four extra channels of high-frequency communication. Two of these sets, which were used at the battle of Loos, are exhibited. They contain fundamental improvements, in that adjustments of the carrier frequency are effected independently of the line constants; while the frequencies are so chosen that a reduction in attenuation corresponding to a tenfold increase of range is obtained. A value of coupling was chosen to give the greatest strength of signals compatible with absence of interference from other sources. The later developments of carrier-current telegraphy and telephony for non-military use have been very rapid, chiefly owing to the use of triodes, and to progress in the design of filter circuits for separating the various high-frequency currents; thus, in April, 1923, there were in operation, between Pittsburgh and Chicago, 128 full duplex channels of communication, based on three carrier-current circuits. The four sets designed were given frequencies corresponding to wave lengths of 4,000, 8,000, 16,000 and 32,000 metres, and were known as A, B, C and D sets respectively, of which the B and C sets are shown. The range of the D set on a single open wire was 40 miles. From the diagram it will be seen that a closed oscillatory circuit, energised by a battery and vibrator, is inductively coupled to an acceptor circuit which is connected to the line and earth. This acceptor circuit is known as a "tuned link," and it is important to notice that in operation it is permanently tuned to the same frequency as the closed circuit, regardless of the line constants. The same oscillatory circuits are used, both for transmission and reception, the necessary connections being made by means of contacts on the signalling key. The buzzer-modulated high-frequency currents are transmitted along the line instead of being radiated as in normal wireless signalling, and a very small battery is used to afford a reserve of power. The received currents are rectified by a crystal in the usual manner. The design of the inductance coils should be noted; they are of the now familiar “basket” formation originated by Capt. Lefroy in 1914; they were the first low-capacity coils to be designed and possess a high ratio of inductance per unit of volume.

Maker/Donor: Made and presented by The Mullard Radio Valve Company.
Object entry information: Non-inductive resistances of the order of a few megohms, of compact form and small current-carrying capacity, are frequently required in wireless telegraphy. The examples shown consist each of a partially carbonised cellulose filament enclosed in a protecting tube. One of them has been sectioned. The raw material is cotton in the form of a rope having about 250 strands. This is first passed through a bath of sulphuric acid and then drawn on to a drum in water, where it becomes “parchmentised.” It is then washed and dried and afterwards carbonised by roasting with graphite in a furnace.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 203.
Object name: TELEPHONE RELAYS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: Patented in 1911 by Mr. S. G. Brown
Object entry information: These relays, which were patented in 1911 by Mr. S. G. Brown, are used to magnify receiver circuit currents so that messages may be printed on a tape machine or otherwise recorded, and very faint signals rendered audible. Two relays are shown fitted in a wooden case, together with transformers and a 6-volt battery. Both relays may be cut out of the telephone and receiver circuit, or one or both may be connected into it by means of a switch. Each relay consists of a permanent magnet with pole pieces on which two coils, connected into the receiver circuit, are wound. A steel reed vibrates in front of the poles of the magnet and is attached to one carbon electrode of a granular carbon microphone, the microphone chamber with the back electrode being held stationary. The microphone is joined in series with the local battery, the primary of the transformer, and an intensifying coil wound on the limbs of the magnet. The vibrations of the reed acting upon the carbon granules in the microphone cause telephonic changes of the current in the local circuit, which are intensified by the action of the intensifying coils and flow through the primary of the transformer. Currents are therefore induced in the secondary of the transformer, which act on the telephone receivers, or flow through the magnet coils of a second relay, according to the number of relays being used.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–114 and 115.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 204.
Object name: BROWN TELEPHONE RECEIVER.
Maker/Donor: Made and presented by S. G. Brown, Esq., F.R.S.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This telephone receiver, patented by S. G. Brown, is one of the most sensitive in use. Instead of the ordinary flat diaphragm there is a flexible steel reed to which is attached a thin conical diaphragm. The steel reed has one end fixed, while the other extends over the pole pieces of the magnet; it is cut away slightly at the sides, and can thus be adjusted to have a natural frequency of about 800 periods per second, which has been found the most satisfactory for wireless telegraphic purposes.

Maker/Donor: Made and presented by The Mullard Radio Valve Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Non-inductive resistances of the order of a few megohms, of compact form and small current-carrying capacity, are frequently required in wireless telegraphy. The examples shown consist each of a partially carbonised cellulose filament enclosed in a protecting tube. One of them has been sectioned. The raw material is cotton in the form of a rope having about 250 strands. This is first passed through a bath of sulphuric acid and then drawn on to a drum in water, where it becomes “parchmentised.” It is then washed and dried and afterwards carbonised by roasting with graphite in a furnace.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–110.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 203.
Object name: TELEPHONE RELAYS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: Patented in 1911 by Mr. S. G. Brown
Object entry information: These relays, which were patented in 1911 by Mr. S. G. Brown, are used to magnify receiver circuit currents so that messages may be printed on a tape machine or otherwise recorded, and very faint signals rendered audible. Two relays are shown fitted in a wooden case, together with transformers and a 6-volt battery. Both relays may be cut out of the telephone and receiver circuit, or one or both may be connected into it by means of a switch. Each relay consists of a permanent magnet with pole pieces on which two coils, connected into the receiver circuit, are wound. A steel reed vibrates in front of the poles of the magnet and is attached to one carbon electrode of a granular carbon microphone, the microphone chamber with the back electrode being held stationary. The microphone is joined in series with the local battery, the primary of the transformer, and an intensifying coil wound on the limbs of the magnet. The vibrations of the reed acting upon the carbon granules in the microphone cause telephonic changes of the current in the local circuit, which are intensified by the action of the intensifying coils and flow through the primary of the transformer. Currents are therefore induced in the secondary of the transformer, which act on the telephone receivers, or flow through the magnet coils of a second relay, according to the number of relays being used.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–114 and 115.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 204.
Object name: BROWN TELEPHONE RECEIVER.
Maker/Donor: Made and presented by S. G. Brown, Esq., F.R.S.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This telephone receiver, patented by S. G. Brown, is one of the most sensitive in use. Instead of the ordinary flat diaphragm there is a flexible steel reed to which is attached a thin conical diaphragm. The steel reed has one end fixed, while the other extends over the pole pieces of the magnet; it is cut away slightly at the sides, and can thus be adjusted to have a natural frequency of about 800 periods per second, which has been found the most satisfactory for wireless telegraphic purposes.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Made and presented by S. G. Brown, Esq., F.R.S.
Object entry information: This telephone receiver, patented by S. G. Brown, is one of the most sensitive in use. Instead of the ordinary flat diaphragm there is a flexible steel reed to which is attached a thin conical diaphragm. The steel reed has one end fixed, while the other extends over the pole pieces of the magnet; it is cut away slightly at the sides, and can thus be adjusted to have a natural frequency of about 800 periods per second, which has been found the most satisfactory for wireless telegraphic purposes. A very light aluminium cone is attached to the reed by a small screw, and is supported at the top by a brass ring which rests on a light aluminium case, fitting over the magnet. Outside the back of the case is a thumb-screw, which enables the magnet to be adjusted, so varying the distance between it and the reed; the sensitive- ness of the receiver depends largely upon this distance, which can be set very accurately by the screw adjustment.

Maker/Donor: Made and presented by The Radio Communication Company.
Object entry information: In these receivers movement of the diaphragm is partly due to electro-magnetic attractions and repulsions caused by interaction between the primary current and the eddy currents set up in the diaphragm itself. A flat ring-shaped magnet is interposed between the coil and the diaphragm. The method of construction is such that a very compact earpiece is produced.

Catalogue number: 206.
Object name: BALDWIN TELEPHONE RECEIVERS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. C. F. Elwell.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In the ordinary telephone receiver a single iron diaphragm is utilised as a vibrating armature and also as the sound-producer. In the receivers here shown two separate units are employed, a balanced armature for the electro-magnetic system and a mica diaphragm which is coupled to the armature by means of a small link.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–430.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 207.
Object name: COIL HOLDER.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by The Igranic Electric Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This form of holder, into which suitably tuned inductance coils can be plugged, is extensively used for wireless reception, particularly where a wide band of wave- lengths has to be covered. The use of a sufficient number of fixed inductances in association with a small variable condenser has the advantage of eliminating the “dead-end” losses which are experienced in a large tapped inductance.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–24.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 208.
Object name: COIL HOLDER.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by The Igranic Electric Company.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In this coil holder provision is made for axial rotation of the individual coils, and a wide variation of mutual inductance is thereby obtainable. This method of mounting inductances is otherwise similar to that shown in No. 207.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–23.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 209.
Object name: HONEYCOMB INDUCTANCE COILS.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by The Igranic Electric Company.
Date of creation: 1920 (Patent date)
Object entry information: These inductance coils, used for wireless reception, are wound on a system which was patented by the de Forest Radio-Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1920. Three manufacturing stages are shown:— A. First layer showing honeycomb formation. B. Second layer showing crossings between those of first layer. C. Finished winding. The resulting coil has considerably less self-capacity than a simple multi-layer coil. (See also No. 168.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–22.

Object name: APPARATUS FOR THE MEASUREMENT OF ABSOLUTE RADIO FREQUENCIES.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The National Physical Laboratory.
Object entry information: This is a portion of apparatus designed for the calibration of wavemeters for the three services, by means of a modification of Feddersen’s mirror. It was used for this purpose up to the end of 1915, but superior accuracy has since been obtained by the multi-vibrateur method. The complete instrument consists of two parts:— (A). A wavemeter (not shown). (B). Photographic apparatus for photographing spark trains, generated in the main oscillatory circuit by means of a gap and by help of a rotating mirror. (A) The wavemeter consisted of a variable condenser (from 100 to 900 m.mfd.) of special design, having a direct-reading scale, reading 1 in 1000 at the lower end, and 1 in 200 at the upper, carefully tested, and found by Maxwell's Commutator Method to be uniform. Three inductance coils were used, wound on ebonite formers, of stranded 7/36 wire, and having terminals removed 18.5 cm. from the centre of the coils to avoid interference from the condenser plates. A Duddell thermo-ammeter of 1.5 ohms resistance completed the coil-condenser circuit, and the point of maximum resonance was obtained by observing the point of maximum deflection. The wavemeter was very loosely coupled with the oscillatory circuit of the testing apparatus. (B). A small alternator of variable frequency (50 to 200 periods per sec.) was connected through a small high voltage transformer to a spark gap, having cadmium electrodes, shunted by a glass plate condenser, and a bare wire inductance in oil. A large variable air condenser could be put in parallel with the glass plate condenser, and by varying the capacity and inductance in circuit, oscillations of frequencies from 300,000 to 1,200,000 periods per sec. could be obtained. The special camera, which forms the exhibit, is mounted on a long slab of sandstone for rigidity. A rotating mirror was fixed on a vertical axis at one end, and driven by a small motor, the speed of which was kept constant by means of a commutator mounted on the axis. This was connected with a bridge battery and galvanometer for measuring capacity; by applying a light variable brake to the axis, the galvanometer light spot could be kept at zero, when the speed remained steady (usually about 60 r.p.m.). The other end of the camera has two branches which carry respectively the spark electrodes and means for allowing the plate carrier to be smoothly raised and lowered, whilst the rotating mirror throws the image of the spark trains as streaks upon the plate. By measurement the average distance from spark to spark was found, enabling the frequency to be calculated, taking into account the distance between the mirror and plate and the speed of rotation of the mirror. The mean of 5 to 10 spark train photographs showed an average variation giving an accuracy of 1/1000.

Maker/Donor: Made by Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company.
Object entry information: This is an early form of wavemeter designed by Prof. J. A. Fleming, F.R.S., and termed by him a cymometer. It consists of a variable condenser, constructed of a brass tube covered with ebonite, over which can slide a second close-fitting brass tube. The capacity of this condenser is variable in proportion to the displacement of the outer brass tube. Connected in parallel to form a closed oscillatory circuit is a variable inductance consisting of a wire wound helically round an ebonite tube, the turns being close together but not touching. Arranged to slide along this is an embracing clip, which is connected to the outer tube of the condenser, so that as the handle is moved the inductance is varied in proportion to the capacity of the condenser. The inner tube of the condenser is connected by means of a copper bar to one end of the helix. If electro-magnetic waves, from an outside oscillator, be allowed to fall on the copper bar, it is possible, by adjustment of the handle, to tune the cymometer to the wave-length of the oscillator, if this lies within the range of the instrument. The resonant condition is indicated by a neon tube connected to the terminals of the tubular condenser. Such a tube is remarkable for the brilliancy of the glow produced in it when placed in an alternating field, the position of maximum oscillation in the cymometer circuit being indicated by the maximum brilliancy of the tube. Since the capacity and inductance are varied proportionally, and the wave-length is proportional to the square root of the product of these two quantities, the scale of wave-length is evenly divided, the range on the particular instrument being from 100 to 1,000 metres. By the aid of this cymometer, measurements of small capacities, inductances and coefficients of coupling can also be made, but for all purposes it is now customary to use wavemeters of more compact form.

Maker/Donor: Made by The Telefunken Company. Presented by The Imperial War Museum.
Object entry information: This is a portable wavemeter consisting of a coil wound on a cardboard former, connected in parallel with a continuously variable air condenser, mounted on an ebonite panel. The arrangement can be tuned to wave-lengths ranging from 300 to 900 metres. If the switch is put to “λ 100–300,” some of the turns of the coil are short-circuited, thus decreasing the range of wave-lengths. The panel is provided with clips for holding a helium tube which glows when the meter is in resonance with as adjacent transmitter, a sharp indication being obtained if loose coupling is employed.

Object name: GERMAN WAVEMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. C. Lorentz. Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a wavemeter designed with three different arrangements of coils for wave-lengths ranging from 100 to 6,200 metres. With the two-way switch at “Summer” (Buzzer), the wavemeter can be used for transmission purposes, a small dry cell (not shown) being included in series with the buzzer. With the switch at “Zelle,” the detector cell is connected in series with the telephones in place of the battery and buzzer, and the receiver can then be tuned to the wave-length of the incoming signals by the adjustment of the condenser. The correct wave-length is read off from a chart supplied with the set.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–235.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 214.
Object name: STATION TESTER MARK II.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: Made during the War of 1914–18
Object entry information: This is a wavemeter made during the War of 1914–18 arranged in a small and portable form, so that it can be used for tuning and testing transmitters or receivers. It consists of a closed oscillatory circuit having a continuously variable air condenser and a fixed inductance coil. With the right-hand double-pole two-way switch at the “send” position, the buzzer with its battery is connected across the oscillatory circuit and energises it by a process of shock excitation. With the switch at “receive,” the battery and buzzer are replaced by a carborundum crystal detector and telephones so that the wavemeter acts as a receiver, and will respond to, and measure the wave length of, a transmitting circuit in its vicinity. The left-hand switch allows any one of three coils of varying inductances to be used, thus extending the range of the instrument.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–118.
title: Wavemeter, wireless telegraphy, German No. 469

By the aid of this cymometer, measurements of small capacities, inductances and coefficients of coupling can also be made, but for all purposes it is now customary to use wavemeters of more compact form.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1907–82.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 212.
Object name: GERMAN WAVEMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by The Telefunken Company. Presented by The Imperial War Museum.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a portable wavemeter consisting of a coil wound on a cardboard former, connected in parallel with a continuously variable air condenser, mounted on an ebonite panel. The arrangement can be tuned to wave-lengths ranging from 300 to 900 metres. If the switch is put to “λ 100–300,” some of the turns of the coil are short-circuited, thus decreasing the range of wave-lengths. The panel is provided with clips for holding a helium tube which glows when the meter is in resonance with as adjacent transmitter, a sharp indication being obtained if loose coupling is employed.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–627.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 213.
Object name: GERMAN WAVEMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. C. Lorentz. Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a wavemeter designed with three different arrangements of coils for wave-lengths ranging from 100 to 6,200 metres. With the two-way switch at “Summer” (Buzzer), the wavemeter can be used for transmission purposes, a small dry cell (not shown) being included in series with the buzzer. With the switch at “Zelle,” the detector cell is connected in series with the telephones in place of the battery and buzzer, and the receiver can then be tuned to the wave-length of the incoming signals by the adjustment of the condenser. The correct wave-length is read off from a chart supplied with the set.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–235.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 214.
Object name: STATION TESTER MARK II.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: Made during the War of 1914–18
Object entry information: This is a wavemeter made during the War of 1914–18 arranged in a small and portable form, so that it can be used for tuning and testing transmitters or receivers. It consists of a closed oscillatory circuit having a continuously variable air condenser and a fixed inductance coil. With the right-hand double-pole two-way switch at the “send” position, the buzzer with its battery is connected across the oscillatory circuit and energises it by a process of shock excitation. With the switch at “receive,” the battery and buzzer are replaced by a carborundum crystal detector and telephones so that the wavemeter acts as a receiver, and will respond to, and measure the wave length of, a transmitting circuit in its vicinity. The left-hand switch allows any one of three coils of varying inductances to be used, thus extending the range of the instrument.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–118.
